HISTORY OF DHARMA≈öƒÄSTRA

(ANCIENT AND MEDI√ÜVAL RELIGIOUS AND CIVIL LAW)

BY

PANDURANG VAMAN KANE, M. A., LL.M. ADVOCATE, HIGH COURT, BOMBAY; SENIOR ADVOCATE, FEDERAL COURT OF INDIA ; FELLOW AND VICE PRESIDENT OF THE BOMBAY ASIATIC Society; AUTHOR OF HISTORY OF SANSKRIT Poetics' &c.

VOL. II PART II

Bhandarkar Oriental Research Institute, Poona

1941

Copies can be had direct from the Bhandarkar Oriental Rosearch Institute, Poona (4), India

Price Rs. 30 for both parts (Parts not sold separately)

Printed at the Aryabhushan Press, 915/1 Shivajinagar, Poona 4 by Mr. Vithal Hari Barve, and Pablished by Dr. R. N. Dandakar, W. A., Ph. D., Secretary, Bhandarkar

Oriental Routarch Instituto, Poona 4.'

CHAPTER XIX

DEVAYAJ√ëA

Devayaj√±a –As stated in the Tai. ƒÄr. quoted above ( p. 696 ) the Devayaj√±a was performed by offering fuel sticks into fire. According to the Ap. Db. S. I. 4. 13. 1, Baud. 1688 Db. S. II. 6. 4 and Gaut. V. 8-9, the Devayaj√±a consisted in offering into fire offerings ( of food or at least a fuel stick ) with ‘svƒÅhƒÅ’ uttered after the name of the deities in the dative case. Manu also (III. 70 ) looks upon homa as devayaj√±a. The devatƒÅs to whom homa or devayaj√±a was offered are different according to different gshya or dharma s≈´trae. For example, A≈°v. gr. ( I. 2. 2) says that they are the deities of the Agnihotra (1. e. S√ºrya or Agni, and PrajƒÅpati), Soma Vanaspati, Agni and Soma, Indra and Agni, Heaven and earth, Dhanvantari, Indra, the Vi≈õve Devas, Brahman'. According to Gaut. they are Agni, Dhanvantari, Visve Devas, PrajƒÅpati, Agni Svistakst. Vide MƒÅdava-gphya II. 12. 2 where the deities are different from those in A≈õv. gr. and Gaut. In later smrtis a distinction is made between homa (or devayaj√±a ) and devap≈´jƒÅ. YƒÅj. in I. 100 speaks of the worship of gods immediately after tarpana and then in I. 102 includes homa among the five yaj√±as. Manu II. 176 also makes this distinotion. Medieval writers came to look upon Vai≈°vadeva as the devayaj√±a, while others held that home to gods was different from Vai≈°vadeva. Vide Haradatta 1886 on Ap. Dh. 8. I. 4. 13. 1. According to Marici and H√§rita quoted in the SmrtimuktƒÅphala ( abnika p. 383 ) devap≈´jƒÅ is performed after the morning homa or after brahmayaj√±s and tarpana 1687 in the noon. In medieval and modern times the ancient idea of homa

H. D. 89

706

History of Dharmasastra

[ Ch. XIX

roceded far into the back-ground and its place was taken by an elaborated procedure of devap≈´jƒÅ ( worship of images kept in the house ). Some space must be devoted to the origin and develop ment of this phase of religious practice.

It is extremely doubtful whether images were generally worshipped in the ancient Vedic times. In the Rgveda and the other Vedas, there is worship of Agni, the Sun, Varu≈Üa and various other deities; but they were worshipped in the abstract, &g powers and manifestations of the oue Divine Person or as separate deities or funotions bebind natural phenomena or cosmio processes. There are no doubt paesages where the deities of the Rgveda are spoken of as possessed of bodily attributes. A few verses may be cited in this connection. Indra is described in Rg. VIII. 17. 8 as ‘tuvigriva’ (with a powerful or thick Deck) and ‘vapodara’ (having big or capacious belly) and ‘subƒÅhu’ (having well-sbaped arms). Rg. VIII. 17. 5 speaks of the limbs and sides of Indra and prays Indra to taste honey with his tongue. In Rg. X. 96.8 Indra is spoken as having dark green (hari) hair and beard and in X. 105.7 again it is said that the hair on his chin are dark-green and his ohin is never injured ( in battle ). 1688 In Rg. II. 33.5 Rudra is said to be ‘pd≈´dara’ (whose abdomen is soft ), * babbru ‘(of brown colour ) and su≈õipra ‘( with a fine chin or nose). The V√°j. 8. 16, 7 speaks of Rudra as having a dark-blue throat and red ( complexion) and 16. 51 says he wears a skin ( kftti). In Rg. I. 155. 6 Vi≈ünu is said to approach a battle with his huge body and as a youth (*bphac-charira’ and * yuvƒÅ’). In Rg. IIL 53. 6 Indra is asked to go home at once after drinking Somas, as he has a charming wife and delightful house. In Rg. X. 26.7 god P≈´≈üan is said to shake his beard. In Rg. IV. 53.2 Savitis said to put on a yellowish dr≈´pi (armour) and in Rg. I. 25. 13 Varupa is said to wear & golden drƒÅpi. It is not necessary to multiply examples. It is possible to argue that all these descriptions are poetic and metaphoric. But there are two passages of the Rgveda that cause much more diffioulty than the above. Rg. IV. 24. 10 asks' who will 1689 purchase this

Ch. XIX)

Devayaj√±a-Origin of image worship

707

my Indra for ten cows and might return it after he ( Indra ) bas killed enemies'? Rg. VIII. 1. 5 says ‘0 Indra! I shall not give thee for even a great price, not even for a hundred, a thou sand or an ayuta ( ten thousand)’. It may be argued that here there is a reference to an image of Indra. But this is not con vinging. It is equally possible to hold that these are hyperbolic or boastful statements of the great devotion of the worshipper to Indra and that there is no reference to an image of Indra. If we look at the Vedio cult described in the BrƒÅhma·πáas where sacri fices of butter, cakes and boiled rice or other grain are offered to several deities in the fire, or animal and some sacrifices are described at great length, it is clear that the ancient sages hardly ever thought of the worship of idols, but of deities in the abstract to whom they ascribed different functions and poetically represented them as being endowed like human beings with hands and feet and other limbs. It cannot be denied that here and there occur a few passages that suggest images as objects of worship. For example, in the Tai. Br. II. 6. 17 occurs the passage may the hotƒô priest worship the three goddesses, that are golden, that are endowed with beauty ( or ornaments ) that are great ones' &o. It looks as if golden images of the three goddesses are meant. 1690 One can say without much feer of contradiction that the religious practices among the higher strata of the Vedio Aryans did not include the worship of images in the house or in temples. But we have hardly any literary materials for judg ing what the religious practices of the lower or ignorant masses of Vedic India were. In Rg. VII. 21. 5 Vasi≈üthe prays to Indra ‘may the si≈õna-devas not overwhelm our fta’ (religious order or practices ); similarly in Rg. X. 99. 3 the prayer is ‘may be ( Indra ) striking (or killing ) the si≈õnadevas overcome them by his form or power’. Scholars are sharply divided in opinion about the meaning of the word “691’sisnadeva'. Some hold that it denotes people who were worshippers of the phallus (vide Vedio Index, vol. II. p. 382 ). Others hold that the word is used in & secondary or metaphorical sense for those who are immersed in sexual gratification and do not recognize anything else (as worthy of pursuit). Y√•ska in his Nirukta (IV. 19) quotes

  1. Ptar HareTI: I Matat: ferroust: t realjufragt: 18. T. II. 6. 17. The three devƒ´s are Bharatƒ´, l·ªùi and Saragvatƒ´.

  2. A fragatan H UR 7:11. VII. 21. 5; Prsona a HT c√≥ 1 . 0.99.3; Hair: #i: hd fun and ·ªü T T T 4

History of Dharmasastra

| Ch, XIX

Rg. VII. 21. 5 and explains that the word means ‘those who do not observe rules of brahmacarya (celibacy). The preponderance of authority and evidence is in favour of the second view. In Rg. VII. 104.14(=Atharva VIII. 4. 14), the poet pleads if I be addicted to falsehood, O fire, or if I call upon the gods in vain (then you may injure me), but (not being so) why are you angry with me? May those whose speech is false incur slaughter at your hands’. Here ‘an≈£ta-devƒÅ·∏•’ is praoti. cally the same as ‘drogba-vaca·∏•’ in the fourth p√§da. In the Tai. Up. I. 11. 2 we have the words ‘mƒÅtƒõdevo bhaya, pitrdevo bhava’, where all that is meant is that one should be devoted to the parents'. Therefore ‘≈õi≈õna-deva’ could hardly mean * those who worship phallus as god'. In Rg. 169. X. 87.2 Agni is invoked as follows ‘with thy tongue reach the m≈´radevas, in thy mouth envelope the eaters of raw flesh after cutting them into bits’ and in Rg. VII. 104, 24 Indra is called upon to kill male and female yƒÅtudhƒÅnas (evil spirits or sorcerers) and it is added ‘may the m√ºradevas perish bereft of their necks and may they not see the sun rising up fron the horizon’. Yaska in commenting on Rs. X. 4. 4 explains ‘m√ºra’ as ‘m≈´dha’ (stupid ) 1683. It is possible to take ‘m≈´ra’ as meaning ‘mortal. or ‘perishable’ (since the root ‘mp’ assumes the form ‘muriya’ as in Rg. VII. 104. 15). From the above quotations it is clear that the Rgvedic poets know of low people who practised witohcraft, who were m√ºradeyas (i. e. either worshipped peri. shable objects or were stupid in their cult) and who were the enemies of the Aryans. There are also clear references to enemies who did not look upon Indra as God (Rg. X. 27. 6,

X. 48. 7, X. 86. 1).

Phallio emblems have been found in the ancient ruins at Mohenjo-daro (vide Sir John Marshall’s work, vol. I. pp. 58-63). Except these finds the earliest known lingas so far discovered do not go beyond the first century B. O. But centuries before Ohrist the worship of images had become widespread in India, According to Haradatta on Ap. gr. 20.1-3, where the offerings to

Ch. XIX) Devayajita-Origin of image worship

709

Isana, his consort and his son ‘Jayants’ (the conqueror Skanda) are desoribed, images of these three are worshipped. The M√§nava. gshya 1494 II. 15. 6 prescribes that if an image (of wood, stone or metal) were to be burnt down or to become reduced to powder (of itself) or falls (from its pedestal) or breaks into pieces, or laughs, or moves to another place, the householder (in whose houge it had been established ) should offer ten oblations into fire with certain Vedio verses. In the Baud. gr. II. 2. 13 when describing the ceremony of Upaniskramana ( taking the infant child out of the house for the first time ) it is said that the father after performing homa goes out of the house, worships the images outside (the house ), feeds the brahmanas, makes them pronounce benedictions and then brings back to the house the infant. 1995 The LaugƒÅk≈üi grhya (18.3 ) speaks of devatƒÅyatana (s temple). Gaut. (IX. 13-14 ) forbids a man from answering calls of nature in front of images or from stretching one’s feet towards them and (IX.. 66 ) requires & man to circumambulato & temple ( devatƒÅyatana ) that he may meet on his way. The ≈†ƒÅn. gr. IV. 12. 15 does the same and uses the same word (8. B. E. vol. 29, p. 125 ) and in II. 6. 6 mentions & deva-kula ( god’s house). Ap. Dh. 8. (1. 11. 30. 28 ) has a similar rule. Manu (II. 176 ) directs the brahmacƒÅrin to worship images, requires a person to circumambulate images that he may meet with when on a journey (IV. 39), not to cross the shadow of images (IV. 130 ) and ordains that witnesses be sworn in the presence of the images of gods and brƒÅhma·πáas (VIII. 87). Vide also Manu III. 117 and IX. 285. The Vi≈ünu Dh. 8. ( 23, 34, 63.27) mentions the images of gods ( devatƒÅrca ) and speaks of the worship of Bhagavat Vasudeva as an image. In Vasi≈ütha XI. 31, Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. S. 69.7, 30. 15,70 13, 91. 10 the word ‘deve. tƒÅyatana ' or dev√•yatana occurs. Unfortunately the dates of all these works are far from being certain. But no scholar will assign the M√§nava, BaudhƒÅyana and SankhyƒÅyana gƒºhyas≈´tras and the dharmas≈´tras of Gautama and Apastamba to & later date than the 5th or 4th century B.C. Panini, whom no scholar will place later than 300 B. C. (though there are some who

( Ch. XIX

place him geveral centuries earlier), teaches 1986 that an image by attending on which a person maintains himself and which is not for sale has the same name as the god whose image it is 8. g. an image is called Siva or Skanda when the worshipper makes his livelihood by attending on the image of Siva or Skanda (and appropriating the offerings placed before the image) which is not for sale. Panini also teaches (IV. 3. 98 ) that * Vasudevaka’ is a person who is & votary of V√•sudeva and Pata√±jali expressly says that VƒÅsudeva was not a mere ksatriya, but that the word is the name of God. Pata√±jali comments on the former s≈´tra and vouchsafes the very interesting information that the Mauryas who were greedy of gold established or manufactured insges, to which this rule would not apply, but it would apply to the images of gods that were in Pata√±jali’s day used for p≈´jƒÅ ( worship). According to Pata√±jali the images manufactured by the Mauryas would be called Sivaka &c. Pata√±jali, while commenting on PƒÅ·πáini IV. 1. 54, gives as examples an image with a long or high nose. The Adiparva 70. 49, Anu≈°ƒÅsana 10. 20-21, ƒÄ≈õvamedhika 70. 16 speak of devatƒÅyatanas ( temples ) and Bhisma 112. 11 in speaking of terrible portents refers to images in temples trembling and shedding tears. KhƒÅravela, king of Kalinga (latter half of 2nd century B.O.) is said to have re-established an image of Jina carried away by NandarƒÅja and be is described as ‘sarva devƒÅyatana-sankhƒÅra-karaka’( one who looked after the preber vation and repair of all temples ). In Kautilya’s ArthasƒÅstra II. 4 ( variously assigned to different dates from 300 B. C. to 250 A. D. ) it is stated that in the centre of the capital shrines of AparƒÅjita, Apratihata, Jayanta, Vaijayanta and temples of Siva, Asvins, Vaisravana, Lak≈ümi and of MadirƒÅ ( wine?) should be erected. It follows from the above discussion that long before P√•≈Üini there had arisen professional men who made their livelihood by attending on images and that temples of deities must have existed even in the 4th or 5th century B.C.

The question whether the worship of images and the erec tion of temples spontaneously arose among the Vedio Aryans

15 The fire

  1. storo eroa 197. V. 3. 99; stara rigenerante a retet fra: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§ñ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ Ordet: a truitate fagfa 1 ATT q vol. II. p. 429 ; ferruf Or fi #TH784 Vol. II. p. 222 (on 9. IV. 1. 54); Bergaat SE T. IV. 3.98; HUT Tr ai T T 1 AEITT vol. II. p. 914; vide K. I. vol. 20 p. 80 and “Vaippavism and Saiviam’ by Dr. R, Q. IV.3. 93Vol. II. p. 222Ten vol.” 11. pat,

Ch. XIX]

Devayaj√±a-Origin of image worship

711

or whether they derived the idea from some other race or sectarians has been very often discussed. There are three principal views, viz. (1) that the worship of images was derived from s≈´dras and Dravidian tribes and absorbed in the brahma nical cult; (2) that the making of images was copied from the Buddhists; (3) that this practice was a natural and spontaneous growth. The second view is not very plausible. Images of Buddha were not made for a long time after his nirvƒÅ≈Üa. He was only represented at first by symbols. If modern chrono logy about Buddha’s ministry is to be followed *(he was born about 563 B. C. and died about 483 B, C.), it is almost impossible to hold that images of gods originally came to be made in imitation of images or statues of Buddha, since, as we saw above, temples and images of gods had already become widespread throughout India in the 4th or 5th century B. C. 1888 The first view is supported with arguments of some weight by Dr. Farquhar in J. R. A. 8. for 1928 pp. 15-23. Vide also Dr. Charpentier in Indian Antiquary for 1927 pp. 89 ff. and 130 ff. But I do not hold that the reasons for this view are con vincing. There is no apparent reason why only about 400 B. C. image worship should have been copied from the g≈´dras by the brahmanas. The s√ºdra though given an inferior status had be come a part of Indian Society at least a thousand years before 400 B. C., as the Puru≈üas≈´kta shows. He had been serving the br√§bmapas for centuries before that date and brahmanas could in the times of the sutras partake of food cooked by him and could take s≈´dra women in marriage. So, if the worship of images was 8 practice borrowed from the s≈´dras, it should have prevailed at least a thousand years before 400 B. C. The fact that the devalaka brƒÅhmana (one who maintained himself by attending on images either for & salary or by appropriating what was placed before the image) was not to be invited at & ≈õr√§ddba and had thus an inferior status (Manu III. 152) is to be explained in a different way. The institution of worshippers of images had not an hoary antiquity behind it in the time of

  1. See ‘History of Buddbist thought’ by Dr. E. J. Thomas (1933) for these dates.

  2. Vide Mr. 0. C. Ganguly’s paper the antiquity of the Buddha Image' in Ostasiatische Zeitschrift Noue Folge XIV, Heft 2/3, where he adduces very weighty grounds for holding that the beginning of the cult of the worship of the image of Buddba lies somewhere between 150 B. C. to 50 B. C.

712

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

[ Ch. XIX

Manu, as that of priests officiating at the srauta or gphy & sacrifices had in his day; besides such men must have nego looted the principal duty of a brƒÅhmana (viz. study of the Veda ) and so they were looked down upon. Even in the times of the Br√•bma≈Üas the simple gphys sacrifices were being raised to the level of ≈õrauta rites, which were gradually becoming less and less frequent. The Ait. Br. (11, 8) prescribes that when a man takes up an offering to a deity and is about to say ‘ya≈üat’ he should contemplate upon that deity for whom the offering is meant. This would naturally lead the worshipper to invest the deity with anthropomorphic attributes. The Nirukta devotes some space ( VII. 6-7 ) to the consideration of the question of the form of the deities referred to in the Vedio mantras. 1700 Three views are propounded, viz. (1) they have an anthropomorphic form, (2) they have no anthromorphic form, (3) they may par take of both characters, i. e. the deities though really non anthropomorphio may assume various forms for carrying out some purpose or activity. This last view contains the doctrine of avatƒÅras. When Vedio saorifices became less and less preva lent owing to various causes (particularly because of the doctrine of ahimsƒÅ, the various upƒÅsanƒÅs and the philosophy of the Absolute set forth in the Upadi≈üads ), there arose the cult of the worship of images. Originally, it was not so universal or elaborate as it became in medieval and modern times.

The literature on the subject of image-worship is vast. The principal topics are: the substances from which images are made, the principal deities of which images were or are worshipped, the proportions of the various limbs in manufactur ing images, the consecration of images and temples, the ritual of image worship. The subject of consecration of images and temples will be dealt with later on under the topio of Prati≈ütha.

In the B»ôhat-samhita of VarƒÅhamihira (chap. 58, where images of RƒÅma, of Vi≈ünu with eight or four or two arms, of Baladeva, EkƒÅnamsƒÅ, Samba, BrahmƒÅ, Skanda, Siva, Girija as half of Siva’s body, Buddha, Jina, the Sun, the M√§trs, Yama, Varuna, Kubers are described); in the MatsyapurƒÅ≈Üa chap.

  1. go award for the foret rarter 16. . 11.8, quoted by sinar on in I. 3. 33,

  2. Sartrerat HET I STATUT: Frati … … sgua: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ …… ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ ‡§â‡§≠‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ: pri firm VII. 6-7.

Oh. XIX)

Devapƒ´jƒÅ-Image worship

713

258-264; in the AgnipurƒÅ≈Üa chap. 44-53, the Vi≈ünudharmottara (III. 44 ff.) and other pur≈´≈Üas, in the M√§nas√§ra, the Catur varga-ointƒÅ mani of Hemadri (Vratakhanda vol. II part 1, pp. 76-222 ), in several agama works, in the DevatƒÅm≈´rti-prakarana of s≈´tradhƒÅra Ma≈Üdana of the 15th century ( ed. by Upendra Mohan SƒÅnkhyatirtha, Calcutta, 1936 ) and similar works elaborate rules are given on pratimƒÅlak·π£ana ( the characteristics of the images of gods and goddesses ), They cannot be dealt with here. In modern times many works and papers, several of them illustrated with plates and photographs, have been pub. lished on this subject. 1701

Medieval digests like the Sm. O., the Sm»ôtimuktƒÅphala, the Puja-praka≈õa devote considerable space to the subjeot of deve p≈´jƒÅ (image-worship) in its various aspects, the last work containing 382 pages in print on this subject. A very concise statement of only a few topics is attempted below.

  1. Besides the Anoual Reports and Memoirs of the Archaeologi. cal Survey of India, the following is a modest list of such works :

Ars Asiatica (in French ), somo volumes of which such as vol. III (on Saiva sculpture ), vol. X (on Ajanta ), vol. XV (about images at Mathura ) are specially useful; Ludwig Baobhofor’s * Early Indian Sculpture’in two volumes (1929, Paris ) with 161 plates (from 300 B.C. to 200 A. D.); Brindaban Bbattacharya’s Indian Images' vol. I (1921, & very useful work containing original Sanskrit texts from the Vedas to the latest works and several illustrations); N. K. Bhattasali’s * Iconography of Buddhist and Brahmanical Sculptures in the Dacca Museum'; Rai Bahadur Chanda’s Medieval Indian Sculptures in the British Museum' (1936); ‘Ancient India’ (from the earliest timos to the Guptas as to architecture and sculpture ) by K. de B. Codrington 1926, with numerous plates; A. K. Coomarswamy’s History of Indian and Indonesian Art'; A. Toucber’s Beginnings of Buddbist Art' (1917 translated by L. A. Thomas and F. W. Thomas) and ‘L’ Arte Gr√©co Buddbique du Gandb√ºra'(in two vols. 1905 and 1918 ); 0. C. Gangoly’s ¬´ South Indian Bronzes' (1915, with 95 full page illustrations and 45 smaller plates); T. A. Gopinath Rao’s ¬∑ Elements of Hindu Iconography (in 4 parta, containing quotations from purƒÅ≈Üas, kilpa≈õƒÅstras and other works and numerous illustrations); Gr√ºnwedel’s “Buddbist Art in India' (English translation by Agnes C. Gibson revised by James Burgess, 1901 ); E. B. Havoll’s Indian Sculpture and Painting' (London, 1908), the Ideals of Indian Art' (London, 1911), Hand-book of Indian Art' (London, 1920); H. Krishna Sastry’s South Indian Images of Gods and Goddessed ‘; Nibar Ranjan Ray’s Brahmapical Gods of Burma’ (1932); V. A. Smith’s History of Fine Art in India' (1911, with hundreds of illustrations); ' M√ºrtivij√§√§na' (in Marathi) by G. H. Khare ( 1939, Poona ).

#. D. 90

714

History of Dharmatastra

[ Oh. XIX

The word devap≈´ja * 170% ocours in the V√•rtika on Panini I.3. 25. The digests try to show that, just as yƒÅga ( sacrifice ) consists in giving up materials accompanied by a mantra with reference to a deity that is then principally in view, so pƒÅjƒÅ also is yƒÅga, as therein also there is giving up (or dedication ) of materials to a deity. 1903

The next question is, who are entitled to perform devap≈´jƒÅ. Men and women of all varnas and even the untouchables were to worship Vi≈ü≈Üu who incarnated himself as man-lion, accord ing to the N»õsimhapur√•≈Üa and Vfddba-H√§rsta 1704 ( VI. 6 and 256 ). All the male members of a joint undivided family are to perform separately samdhyƒÅ, brahmayaj√±a and agnihotra (if they have consecrated the greuta and grhya fires) but devap≈´ja and vaisvadeva will be only one for the whole family, 1905 The time for devap≈´jƒÅ is after tarpa≈Üa at noon and before vaisva deva; but some place it after vai≈°vadeva. According to Dak≈üa II. 30-31 all devakƒÅrya ( duties and ceremonies in honour of gods ) must be performed in the first half of the day.

One of the peculiar tenets of Hinduism is adhik√§ra-bheda ( difference in rights, duties, ceremonies and worship dependent on difference in intellectual, emotional and spiritual equipment). Not every one was capable of the same discipline and regimen. Image worship was not absolutely necessary for everybody and the ancient writers never thought that when they worshipped an image they were simply paying homage to a material object. They believed that they contemplated the One Supreme Spirit in the form of the image or symbol before them, which helped ordi nary people to concentrate their mind on the Godhead to the exclusion of other external and engrossing objects and pursuits.

*** p. 1, 444 EU p. 33. 1706. Vide ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡§≤ quoted in the ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ñ p. 133.

‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ , ‡§¨‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§™‡§ú‡§æ‡§§

Oh XIX

Devayajna-Image worship

115

According 1706 to Narada, the Bhagavata-purana XL.27.9 and Vrddha-Harita (VI. 128-129) Hari is to be worshipped in water, in fire, in the heart, in the sun, on the altar, in brahmanas and in images. S√§tƒÅtapa 1907 says ‘the gods of ordinary men are in water, those of the knowing are in heaven, of the ignorant and of those of small intelligence are in wood and clay (i. e. images) and of the yogin in his own self (or heart ). God is worshipped in fire by throwing oblations, in water by throwing flowers, in the heart by contemplation and in the orb of the sun by japa.

The materials out of which images are to be made are precious stones, gold, silver, copper, brass, iron, stone, wood or clay. One made of precious stones was the best and the most inferior was that made of clay. The BhƒÅgavata-purƒÅ≈Üa (XI 27.12) says that images are eight-fold viz, made of stone, wood. iron, sandal-wood or similar paste, drawn (as a picture), made of sand, of precious stones and lastly mental 1708 The Matsya purana (258. 20-21) adds lead and bronze’ to the above eight of the Skanda. Vide also Vrddha-Harita VIII. 120. Among stones the SalagrƒÅma stone (a black stone containing fossil ammonite found in the Gandaki river near a village called Salagrama ) and the stone from Dy√°rakƒÅ marked with a cakra (disous)are highly prized in the worship of Visnu. Vrddha-Harita (VIII. 183-189) highly extols SalagrƒÅma-puja. It is stated by Vƒüddha-Harita that only dvijas can worship SƒÅlagrama and not ≈õ≈´dras. According to several purƒÅ≈Üa passages quoted in the Pujaprakasa (pp. 20-21) even women and sudras can perform

1716

History of DharmadƒÅsira

( Oh. XIX

the worship of SalagrƒÅma 19, but they should not touob it. Similarly they are not to worship lingas established in the past by sages &c. This worship of SalagrƒÅma is comparatively ancient. SamkarƒÅcƒÅrya in his commentary on the VedƒÅntas≈´tra speaks in several places of SƒÅlagrƒÅma 1710 being worshipped as a symbol of Hari. Five kinds of stones were used in worship, viz. BƒÅ≈Üa-lingas from Narmada in Sive worship, SƒÅlagrƒÅma in Vi≈ünu worship, metallic stone in DurgƒÅ worship, crystal for sun-worship and red stone in Ga≈Üe≈°s worship. The RƒÅjatarangi≈Üi ( II. 131 and VII. 185) refers to the establishment of BƒÅ≈Üalingas”?ll of Siva in Kashmir taken from the Narmada. About the images to be worshipped in the house it is stated in the MatsyapurƒÅ≈Üa ( 258, 22 ) that they should be in size as big as a part of the thumb up to 12 angulas and not more ; but an image to be established in a temple should be up to sixteen angulas and not more or its proper height should be arrived at as follows: divide the height of the door into eight parts; taking seven parts divide them into one-third and two-thirds; the pedestal of the image should be one-third and the image should be two-thirds of the seven parts (i. e. f of seven-eighths of the height of the door). Vide MatsyapurƒÅ≈Üa 258. 23-25.

Among the gods popularly worshipped the principal ones are Vispu under various names and in various avatƒÅras, Siva in his various forms, DurgƒÅ, Ganess and the Sun.‘12 The

worship of these deities ( oalled panoƒÅyatanap≈´jƒÅ) is said to have been popularised by the great Samkar√°cƒÅrya, In modern times these five devatƒÅs are still worshipped, but they are differently arranged according as the worshipper places one or other of the five in the centre. 1

West

In medieval and modern times Vi≈ünu has been deemed to have descended to earth ten times to preserve the world and its culture. A brief account of the development of this theory will not be out of place here. The ten well-known avatƒÅras are Matsya (fish), K≈´rma (tortoise ), Var√§ha (boar), Narasimha (man-lion), VƒÅmana (dwarf), Parasurama, RƒÅma, K»õ≈ü≈Üa, Buddha and Kalkin. There are faint glimmerings of the theory of avstƒÅras and of these forms even in the earliest Vedic Literature. In Rg. VIII. 17. 131713 it is said that Indra was the grandson of the sage Sr√•gavrsa. This may be interpreted as meaning that Indra was supposed to have descended on the earth in & human form. In Rg. IV, 26. 1 the sage VƒÅmadeva exclaims1914 ‘I was Manu and I was also the Sun’. This is referred to in the Br. Up. I. 4. 10 and is often relied upon in support of the doctrine of the transmigration of souls. It may be capable of that interpretation, but if that is not accepted it will at least tend to support the proposition that the Vedic sage thought that the

History of Dharmasastra

1 Oh. XIX

Sun could be born on the earth as a human being (i. e. there was an avatƒÅra of the Sun). There is another sense in which this passage of the Rg and that of the Br. Up. are understood in the VedƒÅntas≈´tra 1. 1. 30 viz. that VƒÅmadeva had realized that bis soul was non-different from the Supreme Soul, Brahma. The elements of the avatars of Matsya ere probably suggested by the story of Manu who was saved from & flood by a great horned fish to whose horn Manu tied the rope of his ship when the flood rose. Vide Sat. Br. I. 8. 1. 1-6 (8. B. E, vol. 12, pp. 216-218 ).1716

The tortoise avatƒÅra was probably suggested by the legend that PrajƒÅpati having assumed the form of a tortoise created living beings and that as the words Ic≈´rma (tortoise) and katyapa mean the same object all creatures are said to be descended from (or to belong to ) Kasyapa (Sat. Br. VII. 5. 1. 5, S. B. E. vol. 41, p. 390 ).“716 The peculiar exploit of the Boar incarnation, viz, raising up the earth from the bottom of the ocean, is alluded to in the Sat. Br. XIV. 1. 2. 11 (S. B. E. vol. 44, p. 451 ) boar called Em≈´≈üa raised the earth up and be was her lord PrajƒÅpati. “1717 In the Rg. Vi≈ünu is said to have pierced Var√°ba (1. 61. 7) and that he being incited by Indra brings to the worshipper a hundred buffaloes, rice cooked in milk, and the boar ( called ) Em≈´sa ( VIII. 77. 10). The Tai, ƒÄr. X 1 refers to this myth. In the Kathaka S. VIII. 2 PrajƒÅpati is said to have become a boar and plunged in water. Vide also Tai. S. VII. 1. 5. 1 and Tai. Br, I. 1. 3. Some elements of the story of the destruction of Hirapyakasipu by Vi≈ünu in the man-lion form are supplied by the story of the slaughter of the demon Namuci by Indrs at dawn with the foam of waters, since Indra had agreed with Namuoi that he would not slay him by day or by night, with the dry or moist

or with the palm or with the fist, or with staff or bow &o.’ (Sat. Br. XII. 7. 3. 1-4, S. B. E. vol. 44, pp. 222-223). Sat. Br. XII. 7. 3. 4 quotes Rg. VIII. 14. 13 which narrates that Indra cut off the head of Namuoi with the foam of waters.i718 In the ancient Tamil work SilappadikƒÅram (translated by Prof. V. R. Diksitar ) there is a reference to the Narasimha avat≈´ra. The special achievement of the dwarf incarnation, viz, the request of the dwarf for as much space as would be covered by his three steps, has its counter-part in the Rgveda, where the principal exploits of Vi≈ü≈Üu are the taking of three steps and making the earth steady or fast. 1719 Vide Sat. Br, I. 2.5.1 for the Dwarf incarnation. In the Chandogya Up. III. 17. 6 it is stated that the sage Ghora Angirasa imparted & certain instruction to Kr≈ü≈Üa, the son of Devak1,1720 This may have supplied some part of the legends about Kr≈ü≈Üa in the Great Epio and the PurƒÅnas.

We saw above that according to Pata√±jali Vasudeva was not a mere ksatriya but an incarnation of God. Pata√±jali quotes & quarter of a verse which speaks of Kamga being killed by V√§sudeva and refers to painted shows wherein the party of Vasudeva were dressed in blaok and of Ka·πÅsa in red (vide MahƒÅbhƒÅ≈üya, vol. II. p. 36 and p. 119). Pata√±jali also speaks of Ugrasena as a member of the Andhaka clan and Vi≈üvaksong as & Vrspi and of Baladeva also ( MahƒÅbhƒÅsya, vol. II. p. 257 on PƒÅ·πáini IV. 1. 114 ) and of SatyabhƒÅmƒÅ (vol. I. p. 111 ) and Akr≈´ra (vol. II. p. 295 ). So the main story of Krspa and persons connected with his ministry on earth as gathered from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata, the Hariva·πÅsa &c. were known to Pata√±jali and to some extent also to PƒÅ≈Üini. History of Dharmatƒ´stra

(Oh. XIX

Inscription ( vide Gupta Inscriptions p. 158 No. 36 ) refers to the Boar Incarnation. The Bhagavatapurina II. 4. 18 deolares that even KirƒÅtas, H≈´≈Üas, Andhras, Pulindas, Pukkasas, Abbfras, Suhmas, Yavanas, Khasas and others and even sinners, when they throw themselves on the meroy of Vi≈ünu as devotees, are purified. It may therefore be assumed that the theory of the avataras of Vispu ( whether ten or less or more ) had been prevalent some centuries before the Christian era.

In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa it is frequently stated that God comes down to earth often for punishing the wioked, for the protection of the good and the establish ment of dharma. 1381 In the Santiparva (339. 103-104) the avatƒÅras are stated to be ten and they are the same 88 now accepted except that Hamsa is mentioned instead of Buddha and Krsna is called SƒÅtvata. Among the PurƒÅ·πáas also several do not mention Buddha as an avatƒÅra. The M√§rkandeya ( 47, 7 ) speaks of Matsya, K≈´rma and VarƒÅha incarnations and in 4. 53-56 begins with VarƒÅha and mentiona N≈ôsimha, Vamana and Mathura (1. e. Kr≈ü≈Üa ). The Matsya ( 47. 39-45 ) speaks of 12 avatƒÅras, some of which are different from the usual ones and verse 106 states that Bh≈ôgu cursed Vi≈ünu to be born as a human being seven times, as he killed a woman, viz. his wife. The Matsya-purƒÅ≈Üa ( chap. 285. 6-7) mentions the well-known ten avatƒÅras inoluding Buddha and this passage is quoted by Apararka on p. 338. The Matsya-purƒÅ≈Üa 47. 247 speaks of Buddha as the 9th (avatƒÅra). The N»ôsimha-purana chap. 36. the Agni-pur√§na chap. 2 to 16 and the VƒÅrƒÅha-pur√§na 4. enumerate the well-known ten avatƒÅras. The Vrddha-Harita smrti!738 (X. 145-146 ) enumerates ten avatƒÅras, includes Hayagriva in them (in place of Buddha) and expressly says that Buddha should not be worshipped. In the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa (AyodhyƒÅm

721

kƒÅ≈Üda 109. 34) Buddha is reviled as a thief and an atheist. 1723 This passage may be an interpolation. In the Bhagavatapurapa there are three different lists of avatƒÅras at I. 3 ( where 22 avatƒÅras occur in which Buddha, Kalkin, VyƒÅsa, Balarama and Krspa are separately enumerated), II. 7 (where besides the well-known avatƒÅras, Kapila, Dattatreya and others are mentioned ), and at VI. 8 Buddha and Kalkin are both mentioned in verse 17. 1724 The KrtyaratnƒÅkara (pp. 159-160) quotes & passage from the BrahmapurƒÅns about a vrata on the 7th of the bright half of Vai≈°ƒÅkha where it is stated that Vi≈ünu as Buddha started the SƒÅkyadharma and that on the 7th day of Vai≈°ƒÅkba when the moon is in conjunction with the Pu≈üya constellation, the image of Buddha should be bathed to the accompaniment of sayings of the SƒÅkys and gifts of garments should be made to SƒÅkya ascetics. The same work (pp. 247-248) quotes & passage of the VarahapurƒÅ≈Üa on the observances of Buddha-dvadasi, when & golden image of Buddha was to be worshipped and given to a brƒÅhma·πáa. In memoir No. 26 of the Arch√¶ological Survey of India, it is stated (p. 5) that in an inscription from South India of about the 7th century A. D. ooours a verse in a mutilated forin in which Buddha is enume rated among the ten avatƒÅras (… narasimhotha VƒÅmanah RƒÅmo RƒÅma≈õoa Krsnasca Buddha·∏• Kalki ca te da≈õa ). 1725 From the above discussion it follows that Buddha became in popular view an avatars of Vi≈ünu for the Hindus froin about the 7th century A. D. Even about that time he was not universally so treated and orthodox writers like KumƒÅrila ( who flourished somewhere about 650 to 750 A. D.) did not admit that he was an avatƒÅra, In his Tantra vƒÅrtika (p. 195 on Jaimini I. 3. 4) KumƒÅrilabhatta says that the Sakys texts were promulgated by Buddha and others that had strayed from the path of the three Vedas and

History of Dharmas√§stra

1 Oh. XIX

that acted contrary to the Vedas and asks 1788 the question “what Assurance is there that one, who, himself being & ksatriya, trans gressed the dharma laid down for k≈üatriyas and betook bimself to the profession of a religious teacher and accepted gifts, would impart instruction in dharma that would not lead to confusion ? It has been said ‘one should leave at a distance & person who does acts contrary to the other world. How can one who deceives himself confer benefit on another’”. The B»ôhatsamhita of Varahamihira (60. 19) states the persons who are to hold the office of worshipper in the temples of several deities, viz. the Bhagavatas for Vi≈ünu, the Magas (sƒÅkadvipiya brƒÅhma·πáas) in temples of the sun, dvijas smeared with ashes in Siva temples, those who know the group of m√£trs in the temples of the Mother Goddesses, brƒÅhmapas in the temples of BrahmƒÅ, Buddhists in the temples of Buddha who was good to all and whose mind was full of peace, naked ascetics in the temples of Jinas; who ever is a devotee of a particular god should worship that god according to the procedure prescribed in his own cult. 1727

ATATI KETUAT ART4 Frei fiu TECREAT 60.19. Vide Wilson’s Vi≈üanpurƒ´na vol. V. p. 382 where an analysis of the Bhavipya purana (last 12 chapters) is given. Simba being cursed built a temple of siva and brought 18 families of Magas from Sakadvipa, with whom the Bhojas (1 sub-division of Yadavas ) entered into matrimonial alliances, whence the Magas oame to be called Bhojakas. In the Harpacerita IV B&≈Üa speaks of a Bbojaka astrologer called Taraka who predicts on Harga’s birth bis greatnons and the commontator stato: tbat Bhojaka' means ‘Maga’. Vide Sherring’s

‚Ä¢ Hindu Tribes and Castes' vol. I. pp. 102-103 wbere he describes the satadvipi brahma≈Üas as Magadha brƒÅhma·πáas and not as Magas. For Sun-worship and the Magas, vide “Vuignavigm and saivism' pp. 151-165. Vide Weber’s essay on the Mugavyakti of Kr√∏gadaga for the MagabrƒÅhmagas and E. I. vol. II. P. 330 ff, the Govindapura stone inscription of the poet Gangadhara, who was a Maga, in saka 1069 (1137-38 A, D.), where it is said that the Magas were sprung from the

(Continued on next page)

Oh. XIX)

Devap≈´jƒÅ-Ten avatƒÅras

723

K≈üemnendra ( about 1066 A. D.) in his DasavatƒÅra-carita and the Gitagovinda of Jayadeva (about 1180-1200 A. D.) speak of Buddha as an avatƒÅra of Vi≈ü≈Üu. Therefore at least before or about the 10th century A. D. Buddha had come to be looked upon as an avatƒÅra of Vis≈Üu throughout India. 1728 The total disappearance of Buddhisin from India, the land of its birth, is a most striking phenomenon, which as stated by A. Schweitzer in ‘Indian thought and its development’ (tr. by Mrs. O. E. B. Russell, 1935) p. 137, cannot be satisfactorily explained. Though Buddha did not accept the authority of the Vedas and of brƒÅhma·πáas, nor the existence of an individual soul nor the Supreme Soul, he believed in karma and punarjanma and in release from sainsƒÅra by renunciation and desirelessness. Whon his followers deified Buddha, when animal sacrifices had been almost stopped and his insistence on universal charity and kindliness and on self-restraint were universally accepted by the followers of the Vedic religion, Buddha came to be deemed an avatƒÅra of Vi≈ünu, as the raison d’√™tre for & separate cult ceased and the decadence of morals among monks and nuns hastened the downfall of Buddhism, the finishing touches being added by the Moslem invasions from about 1200 A. D. No one can affirm that persecution had anything to do with the disappearance of Buddhism from India. Though it cannot be said that there was no religious persecution whatever at any time in India, the evidence for persecution is very limited and such persecution if any as may have existed was as nothing compared to the perse oution of Christians by other Christians and of Jews in all con turies and particularly in the 20th century by several so-called Christian powers. The few well-authenticated cases of large-scale persecutions are those of Sa≈õ√§nka who persecuted the Buddhists (vide Beal’s ‘Records of the eastern world,’ vol. I p. 212, vol. II. p. 42,91, 118, 121), of Mihirakula, of a PƒÅ≈Üdya king (in the 11th

(Continued from last page) son’s own body, wers brought from Sakadvipa by Samba, the son of Kr≈ü≈Üa, and that the first Mage was a Bharadvaja. Vide also E. I. vol. IX. p. 279 the Ghatiyala Inscriptions (Dear Jodhpur) of Pratshara Kakkaka written by M√•tsravi, a Maga, in samvat 918 (861-62 A, D.) and Bhavisyapurdna, chap. 139-40 for further details, such as growing beards, being called Bhojakas &o. Bbƒ´≈üma parva chap. 11 describes Sakadvips and verse 36 speaks of the country of Mangas (Magas ?).

  1. Vide the first astapadi of the Gitagovinda yatan upan ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡•á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ …… ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§¨‡§π ‡§á‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂‡§µ

ere waiter

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

toh. XIX

century ) who persecuted the Jainas. From Asoka downwards, kings and the civil power always extended a generous tolerance to all sects (vide Asoka’s Rock Edict No. 12). The father of the great emperor Harsa was a worshipper of the Sun, while Har≈üa’s elder brother RƒÅjyavardhana was a Buddhist and Har≈üa, though himself a Saiva, speaks of his brother with greater reverence than of his own father ( vide the Madhuban copperplate inscription in E. I. vol. VII p. 155 and I p. 67). Vide Barth’s ‘Religions of India’ pp. 133-134, Farquhar’s *Outlines of the Religious Literature of India' pp. 169, 175 for general religious tolerance in ancient India,

RƒÅms and Krsna were worshipped as avatƒÅras of Vi≈ünu at least several centuries before Christ. Kalidasa in the Raghu var≈õa (XI. 22 ) and the Meghad≈´ta indioates that he regarded Vamang as an avatƒÅra of Vi≈ü≈Üu as much as RƒÅma was. Simi. larly the VarƒÅba and Narasimha AvatƒÅras are frequently spoken of in the Kadambari, The Trim≈´rli i. e, the conception of the triune combination of Brahma, Vi≈ünu and Siva into one God head is also an ancient one. The MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (Vanaparva ) gives exptession to the idea that PrajƒÅpati creates the world in the form of Brahma, sustains it in the form of the great Purusa and annihilates it in the form of Rudra. Hopkins in his ‘Epic Mythology’ p. 231 holds that this is & solitary passage about Trimurti and is & late one and that the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata in general has no doctrine of Trimurti, but rather of the equality of Vi≈ünu and Siva. Kalidasa in his Raghuvamsa (X. 16) and KumƒÅrasambhava (II. 4.) 1728 breathes the same belief. The temples of BrahmƒÅ are now very few and far between, the most well-known being that at Pu≈ükara (Ajmer). There is a temple of BrahmƒÅ in the Idar State and another at Sadhi in the Padra Taluka of the Baroda State. The PadmapurƒÅ≈Üa (Srsti khanda 17 ) shows that the worship of Brahm√§ had declined at that time owing, it is said, to the curse of Savitri.

Siva worship appears to be the most ancient worship that is still prevalent. Sir John Marshall’s work on Mohenjo-daro (vol. I. pp. 52-53 and plate XII No. 17 ) shows a figure that is most probably of Siva as a great yogin surrounded by the

Ch. XIX)

Devapuja-sira worship

725

elephant, the tiger, the rhinoceros and the buffalo ( 88 Siva is called Pasupati). Vide also the Preface to vol. I. p. VII. At Mohenjo-daro the humped and short-horned bull is among the most prominent objects. Sive as half male and half female was worshipped long before K√§lidƒÅsa (vide first verse of the Malavi. kƒÅgnimitra and KumƒÅrasambhava VII. 28). ≈öive is often spoken of as Panoatunda ( with five faces), the five aspects being respectively called SadyojƒÅta, V√°madeva, Aghora, Tat. puru≈üa and Isana ( vide Tai. ƒÄr. X. 43-47, Vi≈ünudharmottara III. 48.1). Though in later times the followers of Siva and Vi≈ü≈Üu abused each other, the MahabhƒÅrata and some of the PurƒÅnas exhibit & most tolerant spirit and say there is no difference between the two. 1730 Vide Vanaparva 39. 76 and 189. 5-6, ≈õƒÅnti 343. 132, MatsyapurƒÅ≈Üa 52, 23. The 1000 names of Vi≈ünu are enumerated in Anu≈°ƒÅsanaparva 149. 14-120 and the

1000 names of Siva in Anu≈°ƒÅsana 17 and Santi 285, 74 ff.

About the images of the sun the MatsyapurƒÅ≈Üa ( 11.31 and 33 ) enjoins that in painting pictures of the sun or in temples of the sun the feet of the sun are not to be drawn 1781 or shown.

About Ga≈Üe≈õa a few words have already been said (at pp. 213-216 ). Ga√±esa came to be worshipped even by the Jainas. Vide Acara-dinakara (composed in saivat 1468) published in the Kharataragaooha-granthamƒÅlƒÅ (part II, 1923), where on p. 210 there is the procedure of conseorating an image of Ganess even for Jainas and Journal of Indian History', vol. 18 for 1939 p. 158 for different types of Ganesa figures one of which has 18 arms. For a figure of Ganesa with sweetmeats (of about 500 A. D.) vide ‘Ancient India ' by Codrington (Plate XXXIX). The AcƒÅradinakar& says that images of Ganesa may have two, four, six, nine, 18 or 108 arms. The AgnipurƒÅna chap. 71, the MudgalapurƒÅpa and Ganesapur√¢ns deal with Ganess worship, but their dates are uncertain. The VƒÅraba. purƒ´na chap. 23 narrates a fantastio story of the birth of Ganesa. The Gapapatyatharva≈°ir≈üa ( Anan, ed.) identifies Ganesa with supreme Brahma.* The worship of the images of planets is

History of Dharmasastra

Ch. XIX

comparatively ancient. YƒÅj. I. 296-298 prescribes that the images for the worship of the nine grahas ( planets ) vize the Sun, the Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn, RƒÅbu and Ketu ( the last two are the nodal points ) should be made respectively of copper, crystal, red sandal-wood, gold (for both Mercury and Jupiter), silver, iron, lead and bronze. YƒÅj. then prescribes the details of the worship of the planets such as the clothes to be gifted, the flowers, incenses, offer ings, and the mantras ( from the VƒÅj. .), the fuel-sticks, the food, and the fee. The Mit. on YƒÅj. I. 297 quotes nine verses from the MatsyapurƒÅna, chap. 94, concerning the details of the images of the nine planets.

About Sarasvati, the goddess of learning, so early a writer AS Dandin (not later than 600 A. D.) says that she was

darvasukla’(all white ).

Another deity whose worship is very popular in the Deccan is DattƒÅtreye. His worship cannot have originated later than the first centuries of the Christian era. In the JƒÅbƒÅlopani≈üad, he is referred to as a paramahamsa and there is an Upani≈üad named after him, Vanaparva 115, Anu≈õ√§sana 153, ≈õƒÅnti 49.36, say that he conferred boons on KƒÅrtavƒ´rya. M√§rkapdeyapurƒÅ≈Üa ( chap. 16-19) gives the story of his birth, calls him a yogin and asserts that he was offered wine and meat by his devotees (19.10.12). The BhƒÅgavata IX, 23, 23, Matsya 47. 242-246 and other pura≈Üas also refer to him. In the Si≈õupƒÅlavadba of MƒÅgba he is spoken of as an avatƒÅra.

The Vi≈ünudharmas≈´tra 178 chap. 65 contains one of the earliest detailed description of devap≈´jƒÅ (of Vasudeva or Vi≈ünu). ‚ÄúAfter having well bathed and washed his hands and feet and performed ƒÅcamana (sipping of water) he should worsbip Lord Vasudeva who is without beginning or end, before an idol or on the sacrificial ground. Having given animated form in his mind to Vispu with the mantra ‘may the Asvins who possess life give thee life’ (MaitrƒÅyani Sam.

Ch. XIX)

Devapuja-Procedure

727

II. 3. 4) and having invited Vi≈ünu with the anuvƒÅka ‘yunjate mana·∏•’ (Rg. V. 81), he must worsbip God with a salutation with his knees, bands and head. With the three mantras ‘ƒÅpo hi &o.’ (Rg. After having thus worshipped Him, he must mutter the Puru≈üas≈´kta. After that he who desires to obtain eternal bliss should make oblations of clarified butter, while reciting the verses of the same hymn (Rg. X, 1) and cooked food is offered with the formula ‘devasya tvƒÅ’; then he should offer flowers to the image repeating the twelve names of Vi≈ünu, associating with each pame the verses from ‘tri≈Üi padƒÅ’ to ‘sumrdikƒÅ bhavantu na·∏•’ (Tai. Br. II. 4.6). Then they laud him with verses derived from the Rgveda, Yajurveda, SƒÅmaveda or Atharvaveda in praise of Vi≈ünu; then he should bid good bye to the Puru≈üa (i. e. Vi≈ünu) by uttering 174 the tbroe vy√§hrtis (in such formula as ‘om bh≈´·∏• puru≈üamudvƒÅs ayƒÅmi) and adding may the Lord, the Great Person, go away for (my) well-being, for conquest and for being seen again.” In case the image is immovably fixed on a pedestal &o. the invocation to come and the bidding of good-bye are omitted. The Baud. grhya-se≈üas≈´tra (II. 17) contains the procedure of the worship of Mabadova ( Siva ). It is almost on the same lines as the worship of Vis≈Üu set out above with the difference that the names of Siva such as Mahadeva, Bhava, Rudra, Tryambaka

Of

Sive

of V.

  1. Vide abovo (note 567 ) for the twelve names of Vippa. The I will ho in four formulae piz, sit WERTHUT IT : Fre, FT TO, mi a megre.

O.XIXI

Devapuja- Procedure

729

are substituted and some of the mantras are different. A fow differences will be found in the text quoted below. It is stated therein that when the worship is of a linga immovably fixed then there is no inyooation to come and no bidding of good-bye. 1786

In the P≈´j√°prak√°sa (pp. 97-149 ) and other digests the methods of devap≈´jƒÅ according to Saunaka, Grhyapari≈£i≈üta, Rgvidhana, Visnudharmottarapurana, Bhagavatapurana, the Narasimhapur√§≈Üa are set out in detail. But for want of space they are all passed over. It will have been noticed from the passages of the Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. S, and of Baudhayana cited above that devap≈´jƒÖ contains certain items and stages in the whole procedure. These are called upacƒÅras (ways of service). They are usually stated to be sixteen. They are: avahana, asana, padya, arghya, acamaniya, snana, vastra, yajiopavita, anu. lepana or gandha, puspa, dhupa, dipa, naivedya (or upa b√§ra ), namaskƒÅra, pradaksing and visarjana or udv√§sana. In different works, the items differ. Some add bhusana (orna ment) after yaj√µopakita and tƒÅmbƒÅla (or mukhav√°sa ) after pradaksina or naivedya (Vrddha-Harite VI. 31-32 and Puja prakasa, p. 98 ). Therefore some speak of 18 upacƒÅras, 1986 Some omit avahana, add svagata (welcome) atter asana, madhuparka after doamaniya, and some have stotra (hymn of praise) and pranama (bow) as distinot upacƒÅras, while others hold that these latter two are one and that pradak≈üi≈Üa is part of visarjana (vide Pujaprakasa p. 98). If a person cannot afford to offer vastra (garment) and alamkara (ornament), he could

  1. ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§π‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§……. ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶ ‡§ï‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§π‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç …… ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ñ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§®‡•å‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø …… ‡§Ö‡§• …… ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§§‡§ø-‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ…… ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ã ‡§™‡§æ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö ‡•§ …… ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É‡•§‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§®‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§Æ‡§É‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§ü‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ß‡•Ç‡§™‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ …… ‘‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡§æ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•á‡§ï ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ã‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡§Æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã ‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø ‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§™ ‡§≠‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ …… ‡§≤‡§ø. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§®‡§µ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä.‡§è‡§Æ ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑II. 17. (Ch. XIX

perform only ten out of these 16 upacaras viz. from p√•dya to naivedya; if he cannot afford to offer even ten he may offer only five pa≈æcopac√°ra-p≈´ja ) viz. from gandha to naivedya; if he has nothing he may perform with flowers alone all the 16 upac√°ras. When the image is immovably fixed on & pedestal there is no av√°hana and visarjana and so the items become 14 or one may offer in their place only a handful of flowers with mantras.” Those who can repeat the Purugasakta (Rg. X. 90) should repeat one of its verges before offering each of the 16 upacaras (see N≈ôsimhapur≈°≈Ü& 62, 9-13). Those who cannot repeat that hymn and women and s≈´dras should simply say * SivƒÅya nama·∏•’ or ‘Vi≈ünave namah’ ( adoration to Siva or Vi≈ünu). V≈°ddha-H√§rlta (XI. 81 ) specially recommends the worship of the child Krsna to women and of Hari to widows (XI. 208 ). 1788 After each of snana, vastra, yaj√±opav√≠ta and naivedya, doamana is to be offered as part of that upacara “*** (vide N≈ôsimhapurana 62. 14). The names of some of these upac√°ras ocour even in the Asv. gp. ( IV.7.10 and IV. 8.1) in relation to the brƒÅhma·πáas invited at ≈°rƒÅddha such as √°gana, arghya, gandha, malya (flowers), dh√ºpa, dipa and √°cch√§dana (i.e. Vastra ). Farquhar is not right when he says in his ‘Outlines of the Religious literature of India. p. 51 that the sixteen upacƒÅras “are so distinct in character from the sacrificial cult as to betray alien origin.’ When image-worship became general items offered to invited brƒÅhma·πáas were also offered to the image of gods. It was a case of extension and not of borrowing from an alien cult.

A few words have to be said in connection with some of the 16 upacaras.

As regards the water to be employed in deyap√ºjƒÅ and rites for the Manes, the Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. 8. (66. 1) prescribes that it should not have been brought the night before ( but it must be drawn

FATTI U N P. 118.

Oh. XIX)

Devapuja-sisteen upacaras

731

that day). The worshipper should not sit on an Asans made of bamboo or stone, or of unsaorificial wood or on the bare ground, or on a seat made of grass or green leaves, but should sit on a woollen blanket or silken garment or deer-skin (P√§j√§prakƒÅ≈õa, p. 95 ). When offering arghya, in the vessel containing the water to be used for that purpose all or as many as one oan afford out of the following eight articles are to be mixed up, viz. curds, whole grains of rice, ends of kusa grass, milk, d√ºrv√° grass, honey, barley grains and white mustard seeds ( Matsya purƒÅna 267. 2 quoted in the P≈´jƒÅprakasa p. 34). It is further said that arghya is offered to the image of Vi≈ü≈Üu by means of a conch in which water is mixed with sandalwood paste, flowers and whole grains of rice. In the water for √•camana are mixed cardamom, cloves, usira grass and kakkola or as many of them as possible. The snana ( bath) of images is effected with five materials called pa√±cƒÅmsta (five ambrosial things ) viz. milk, ourds, clarified butter, honey and sugar. 1740 The image is to be bathed with these five in the order stated, so that sugar coming last removes all effects of oiliness. After these & bath with pure water follows. In the pa√±cƒÅm·ªôtasn√§na the following Vedic verses are repeated in order ; ‘√§pyƒÅyasve’ (Rg. I. 91. 16), * dadhikrƒÅvpo’ (Rg. IV. 39. 6), ‘guftam mimik≈üe’ ( Rg. II. 3, 11 ), ‘madhu vƒÅtƒÅ’ (Rg. I. 90. 6), ‘svƒÅdu·∏• pavasya’ (Rg. IX. 85.6). It will be noticed that each of these mantras is suggestive of the material with regard to which it is uttered. No bath with water or these things is allowed when only a picture or a clay image is to be worshipped. If one cannot afford these, one may bathe the image with water in whioh the leaves of the basil plant (tulasi) are mixed up, as that plant is deemed to be the favourite of Vi≈ünu. The water used in the bath of the image of a God is regarded as very sacred and it is used for acamana by the worshipper and members of his family and friends and is called tirtha ( it is also sprinkled over one’s head ). 1741 As regards the unguents to be offered ( anulepana or gandha ) numerous rules are laid down

  1. horgofia FETT OTTEVII RYTTET How at fire ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡•à‡§É ‡•• ‡§§‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ quoted in the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ P. 84. ____1741. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§¶‡§æ‡§ß‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡§π‡§æ ‡§§‡§§‡•ã ‡§≤‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§π‡§∞‡§£ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡§ï ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ wetfarm fri for var Hai quoted in Frate. ( ft p. 989).’

5732

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XIX

(vide P≈´jƒÅprakƒÅ≈õa pp. 39-41), The Vi≈ü≈Üu 1748 Dh, 8. (66, 2) days that unguents should be one or more out of sandalwood, pine tree paste, musk, camphor, saffron, nutmeg. If ornaments are offered, then gold and precious stonos should be real and not imitation ones (Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. 8. 66.4). Very detailed rules are laid down about flowers. The P≈´jƒÅprakƒÅƒ£a ( pp. 42-49) waxes eloquent over the merit of offering basil leaves to Vi≈ünu and using the same wood in worship generally and also when no flowers are available. The Vi≈ünu Dh. S.1748 ( 66.5-9 ) prescribes that flowers emitting an overpowering smell or having no spell whatever are not to be used, nor flowers of thorny plants unless the flowers are white and sweetly fragrant ; that even red flowers such as saffron flowers and those that spring in ponds or lakes may be employed. There are grades in the merit derived from

offering certain flowers, e. g. the Sm. C. I, pp. 201-202 and the P≈´jƒÅprak√°sa p. 51 quote many verses of the NarasimhapurƒÅ≈Üa, some of which arrange vanamallikƒÅ, cempaka, asoka, vƒÅbanti, malatƒ±, kunda &o, in an Ascending order among flowers and the j√°ti flower is said to be the best of the flowers in the worship of Vi≈ünu. The same work (p. 56 ) Dames d√ºrvƒÅ and twentyfive flowers as favourites with Vi≈ü≈Üu. Vide Vrddha-Harita VII. 53-59 for the flowers that may be used in Vis≈Üu-p≈´jƒÅ and Viddha Gautama p. 563. The flowers offered on a day are removed the next day by the worshipper wben he is about to offer worship that day. Such flowers are called ' nirmalya’and great virtue is attached to placing such flowers on one’s head by way of homage to the deity worshipped ( vide PƒÅjƒÅprak√°sa, pp. 27 and 90). The Sm, O. ( I. p. 204 ) quotes & pur√§na to the effect ‘He, whose heart contemplates the form of Vi≈üpu, on whose lips there is ever the name of Vi≈ünu, who partakes of the naivedya offered to Vi≈ü≈Üu and who places on his bead the water in which the feet of an image of Vi≈°≈Üu are washed and the nirmƒÅlya of Vi≈ünu, never falls off (from heaven).’ The Madana. parijata (p. 303 ) quotes passages from the Vi≈ünu-dharmottara about the flowers, that are not to be used in worship. In Siva worship the following flowers and leaves are in an agcending grade of worth; Viz, arka flowers, karavirs flowers, bilva leaves, flower of dropa, leaves of apam√§rga, flower of kuda, sami leaves,

  1. aga armatosura tanda a fare i progetto 66. 2.

  2. penting profile on mature your curare us on a pani H F# qarai fognatus 66..

C.XIX]

Devapuja-flowers

193

blue lotus leaves, dhattara flower, saml flower, blue lotus, which is the best (vide Pajaprakasa, p. 210). The Madana parijata, p. 303 quotes from the Devipurana Verses which enumerate the flowers that are to be avoided in Siya worsbip. If no flowers are available, then a fruit may be offered or if no fruit is available then only leaves and lastly only white whole grains of rice or even water may be offered. 174 Lamps are to be fed with ghee or in its absence with sesame oil. 1748 Camphor is to be burnt before the image. There is a ceremony called ≈´rƒÅtrika (waving lights round the image ) performed with Beveral lights or pieces of camphor placed in a broad vessel which is held in both hands and waved round an image and over its head. Vide PƒÅjƒÅprakƒÅ≈õa, pp. 75 and 87. For naivedya no food is to be offered which is declared unfit in the gƒÅstras for eating, nor the milk of a she-goat or she-buffalo though they are allowed for food, nor the meat of the five-nailed animals nor the flesh of the wild boar nor fish. The general rule is stated by the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa as whatever food a man eats the same is the food to be offered to his deities ‘. 1748 The Sm. C. (I. p. 203 ) quotes the PadmapurƒÅ≈Üa to the effect that naivedya should be offered in a vessel of gold, silver, bronze, copper or of olay or in palƒÅsa leaves or on lotus leaf. The naivedya is offered with the formula set out below, 1747 According to the BrahmapurƒÅ≈Üa quoted by AparƒÅrka, pp. 153-154 and PƒÅjƒÅprakasa (p. 82 ) the naivedya offered to Brahma, Visnu, Siva, the Sun, Devi, the Matya, to goblins and evil spirits respectively is to be given to brahma. pas, Satvatas ( Bhagavatas), those whose bodies are smeared with ashes, to Magas, to the Saktas, to women, to the poor.

  1. ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§§ ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§∑‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§≤‡•à‡§É | quoted in the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂ P. 65.

  4. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡•§‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ì ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ì‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ …… ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡•§ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ã‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§á‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§´‡§∞‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§ ‡§π‡§∏‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•‡•à ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ó‡•Ä‡§´‡§≤‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡•§

  5. ‡§™‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§ö ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§™‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§ö‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•Å ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•• ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï P. 153-154 and ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ 2.82. ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ reads ‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡§ó‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç while the ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ. reada ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§™‡•á‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç tor ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡•¶. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§® is ‡§è.

History of Dharmatastra

[ Oh. XIX

One may also partake of the naivedya offered by oneself and the SmrtimuktƒÅphala (Ehnika, p. 390) quotes Rg. L 154.5 in support. After naivedya, tambula is to be offered to the God worshipped. In the ancient grhya and dharma sutras no mention is made of tƒÅmb≈´le or mukhavƒÅsa (materials that will render the breath fragrant). T√°mbula was probably introduced some time before or about the beginning of the Christian era in South India and then spread northwards. Among the smrtis, Samvarta 55 quoted in the Kftyaratnakars p. 560, Laghu-Harita ( Anand. 39), Laghu-ƒÇ≈õvalƒÅyana ( Anand.) 1. 160-61 and 23. 105, Ausanasa (Jiv√§nanda, part I. p. 509 ) refer to the chewing of tƒÅmb√ºla after dinner. In the Raghuvamsa VI. 64 Kalidasa describes betelnut plants surrounded by betel creepers. The Kamasutra I 4.16 1748 states that a person after performing the brushing of the teeth, consulting a looking glass and partaking of tƒÅmb≈´la for rendering his breath fragrant should set about his daily business. Vide also KƒÅmag≈´tra III. 4. 40, IV. 1. 36, V. 2. 21 and 24, VI. 1. 29, VI. 2.8 for other references. In the Bphat-samhitƒÅ of Varahamihira (77, 35-37 ) the virtues of t√§mb√ºla and its ingredients are described. In the Kadambari ( para 85 ) the royal palace is compared to the house of a dealer in betel leaves ( t√§mbulika) in which lavall, cloves, cardamom, kankola are stored. The Par. M. I. part 1. p. 434 quotes four verses from Vasi≈ütha ( not found in the printed Dharmas≈´tra ) about the cutting off of the two ends of tƒÅmb≈´la leaves before eating them. In the Vratakhanda ( of Caturvargacintamani, vol. II. part I, p. 242 ) HemƒÅdri quotes Ratnakosa to the effect that tƒÅmb≈´la means betel leaves, betel nut and ch≈´nam; while * mukhavaga’ means these together with cardamom, camphor, kakkola berries, places of copra and matulunga. The Nity.cara paddhati 1780 (p. 549 ) quotes verses showing that tƒÅmb√ºla comprised nine ingredients viz. be tel nut, betel leaves, chunam, oamphor, cardamom, clove, kankola, copra, the matulunga fruit. In modern times pieces of almond, nutmeg fruit and bark thereof, saffron, cateohu are taken and matulunga is omitted. Thus the thirteen ingredients of t√¢mb√ºla are

Oh. XIX)

Devapuja-Tumbila

735

made up. The Astangasamgrahas1 of V√•gbhata also mentions the several ingredients of tƒÅmb≈´la including the essence of the bark of the Khadira tree (catechu ). In modern times tambala is said to be of 13 gunas, either because it contains thirteen ingredients or because it effects thirteen good results, the last of which are set out in a subhƒÅ≈üita quoted below.

Pradaksing ( going round the image with the right hand always turned towards the image ) and namaskƒÅra constitute only one upacƒÅra ( item of worship) according to many. The namaskara to the image is either a≈ütƒÅnga (with eight limbs ) or pa√±o√§nga ( with five limbs.) The first occurs when & person prostrates himself on the ground in front of the image in such a way that the palms of his hands, his feet, bis knees, his chest and forehead touch the ground and his mind, speech and eye are fixed on the image and the latter occurs when he prostrates himself with his hands, feet and head. 1752 There are other definitions of the a≈ütƒÅnga namaskƒÅra. These several parts of the worship of images have been judicially noticed in Ram brahma Chatterji v. Kedar Nath 36 Calcutta Law Journal 478 at *p. 483 (where the normal type of the continuous worship of an idol is described) and Pramatha Nath Mullick v. Pradyumna Kumar Mullick 52 Cal. 809 at p. 815 (P.O.).

In modern times it is the practice to perform in homage to the sun twelve namaskƒÅras or any multiple of twelve and repeat the following twelve names of the sun in the dative preceded by ‘om’ and followed by nama·∏•': Mitra, Ravi, S√ºrya, BhƒÅnu, Kbaga, Pu≈üan, Hiranyagarbha, Marloi, Aditya, Savitr, Arka and BhƒÅskara. There is another method of these namaskaras oalled TpcƒÅkalpanamaskƒÅras in which after ‘om’ certain mystio syllables and their combinations in twos and

The P≈´≈°√°prakasa (pp. 166-188) mentions 3% aparadhas ( lapsos ) which should be avoided while engaged in worship or while one is about to perform Vi≈ünup≈´ja and the atonements for these. These 32 aparadhas (offences) against proper etiquette for worship are referred to in the Vardhapurana (130.5).

A passage from BaudhƒÅyana about Siva worship has already been quoted and it has been stated that worship of the phallio emblem of Siva appears to have been ourrent in the very ancient civilization brought to light by the finds dis covered at Mohenjo-daro. Sir R. G. Bhandarkar in his ‘Val spavism and Saivism’ has shown how Rudra is described as the supreme deity even in the Rg., how in the Tai. 8. IV.5. 1-11 there are eleven anuvƒÅkas (called Rudras) which contain a sublime eulogy of Rudra (and also in V√°j. 8. 16) and how numerous Saiva sects and dootrines arose in course of time (p. 119 f). Panini teaches the formation of Bhav√°ni, Saryani Rudr√•≈Üi and MrdƒÅni from the four names of Siva (IV. 1. 59). In the sacrifice called Salagava in the gƒºhya s≈´tras Rudra is worshipped as the supreme deity. The ƒÄ≈õv. gr. IV. 9.17 mentions twelve names of Rudra and adds 1754 (IV.9.27-29) that all names in the world, all armies, all exalted things belong to him. Patanjali in his Mahabhigya (vol. II. pp.387-388) on PƒÅ≈Üini V.2.76 speaks of a ‘Siva-bhagavata’( a devotee of Siva). Vedantag√ºtra IL 2. 37 is direoted, according to Samkara, to the refutation of the Pasupata seot of Saivas. In the S√§ntiparva 284. 121-124 the Pasupatas are said to be opposed to the dharmas of var≈Üa and Asrama The K≈´rmapurƒÅ≈Üa (p≈´rv√§rdha, chap. 16) speaks of the

Devap≈´ja-siva worship

731

s√°stras of the Saiva sects, of KƒÅpƒÅlas, Nakulas 1786 (Lakulas?), V√°mas, Bhairavas, Pasupatas as meant for deluding the world. The Var√°bapurƒÅ≈Üa (chap.70-71) is also directed against Pasupatan. The PƒÅ≈õupata brƒÅhma·πáas are stated in the KƒÅdambari to have burrounded the minister SukanƒÅsƒô (para 90). Sive was worship ped in the form of the linga or as an image. It is believed that 14 crores of lingas were established by BƒÅ≈Üa, an Asura devotee of Siva, in various spots and these are called B√§≈Üa-lingas (Nity.. cƒÅrapaddhati, p. 556 ) and the BƒÅ≈Üa-lingas (white stones) found in the Narmada, the Ganges and other holy rivers are only like them. In the KƒÅdambari ( para 130 ) BƒÅ≈Üa speaks of sand lingas on the Acchoda lake and in another place of a linge made of pure mother-o’pearl. The K√ºrmapurƒÅ≈Üa (p≈´rv√§rdha chap. 26 ) describes the origin of Linga and its worship and the VƒÅmana. purƒÅna 46 lauds the several holy places where ancient lingas are established. The famous twelve Jyotir-lingas are; Omkara at Mandb√•ta, Mab√°kƒÅla at Ujjayini(modern Ujjain), Tryambaka (near Nasik), Dbrspe≈õvara at Elora, NƒÅganatha ( towards the east of Ahmednagar), Bhima-Samkara (at the source of the BhimƒÅ river in the Sahyadri ), Kedara-nƒÅtha in Garhwal, Vig. Ve≈õvara at Benares, SomanƒÅtha in Kathiawar, Vaidyanatha new Parali. Mallikarjuna on the Srisaila, and RƒÅme≈õvara in South India. Many of these are situated in central and western India near each other.

The P≈´jƒÅprakƒÅ≈õa (p. 194) quotes Harita prescribing that Mahe≈õvara may be worshipped by means of the mantra of five syllables ( nama·∏• SivƒÅya ) or by the Rudra!758 Gayatri or by

  1. About Lukuli√°u, Pasupata or Kalumukha, vide Vuippuvism and saivism’p. 119 ff. In the V&yupurana 23. 221-224 it is said in & prophetic strain that Siva would assume the form of Nakuli (Lakuli?) and the place where he will appear will be called the holy place of Kaya. rohaga. Vide E. I. vol. II. p. 124, vol. XII. p. 337, vol. XIV p. 265 for the Lakula dootrine, its dodryas and other information. For the Kapalikas, vide Bhandarkar’s Vaippavism and Saivism' pp. 117,127. A grant of Nigavardhana, Dephew of Pulakofi ( 610-639 A, D.), was made provi ding for the worship of KƒÅp√•ledvara and the maintenance of Mahayrating, Yama 29 quotod in Par. M. II. part 1 p. 335 prescribes the pedance of Krcobra for eating at a Kupalika’s house. The Karpuramanjarr ( about 900 A, D.) I. 22-24 contains a caricature of Kaula (i. o. Kapalika ) practices.

[ Ch. XIX

‘om’ or by the mantra ‘Isana·∏• sarva-vidyƒÅn√§m’ (Tai. ƒÄr. X. 47 ), or by the Rudra mantras ( viz. Tai. S. IV. 5. 1-11 ) or by the mantra ‘tryambakam yajƒÅmabe’(Rg. VII. 59. 12). For a devotee of Siva, the wearing of a string of Rudraksa berries is necessary either on the band, the arm, the neck or on the head. 1787 The SmstimuktƒÅphala (abnika p. 393 ) quotes verses from the Smrtiratna and the Ratn√°vali about the merit secured hy bathing the linga with cow’s milk, ourds, clarified butter, honey, sugarcane juice, pancagavya, water in which campbor and aguru are mixed up, and other substances. The 14th day of the dark half of a month has been sacred to Siva from ancient times. Bana in the Kadambari ( para 54 ) refers to the fact that queen VilasavatI went to worship MahakƒÅla at Ujjayini on the 14th.

The worship of DurgƒÅ bas prevailed from ancient times, “68 She is worshipped under various names and aspects. In the Tai, Ar. X. 18 Siva is said to be the husband of Ambika or Umd. In the Kena Upani≈üad (III. 25 ) Um√† Haimavati is mentioned as imparting to Indra the knowledge of the Great Being. The various names of DurgƒÅ are UmƒÅ, P√§rvati, Devi, AmbikƒÅ, Gauri, Candi or CapdikƒÅ, Kali, Kumari, Lalita &o. The Mahabharata (VirƒÅ»õaparva 6 and Bbi≈üma 23 ) contains two hymns addressed to Durga in which she is stated to be Vindhyav√§sinl and fond of blood and wine, and in Vanaparva 39, 4 it is stated that UmƒÅ became 8 kirƒÅti when Siva became a kir√°ta to test the prowess of Arjuna. In the KumƒÅrasambhava K√°lidƒÅs& speaks of PƒÅrvati, UmƒÅ, Aparna and derives the latter two words (I. 26 and V. 28). YƒÅj. I. 290 speaks of AmbikƒÅ as the mother of VinƒÅyaka. DurgƒÅ wax lovoked as a supreme goddess. Cb. XIX )

Devapaja-worship of Durga

1799

that a goat or a buffalo may be sacrificed for her.1789 These bloody rites are still continued in the Kali temple in Bengal and a few other shrines of DurgƒÅ. In Bengal the worship of Durg√• in Asvina has been most popular. 1760 Raghunandana in his DurgƒÅrosna-paddhati gives an elaborate description of the worship of DurgƒÅ in Asvina. Durga is also worshipped as Sakti. The influence of Sakta worship has been great throughout India and will be briefly surveyed later on.

In modern times devapƒÅja differs considerably from the ritual of the ancient works of Vi≈ünu and BaudhƒÅyana ; it also differs from province to province and caste to caste. A brief analysis of the devap≈´jƒÅ practised by brƒÅhma·πáas in Western India is given below: Acamana; prƒÅ≈ÜƒÅyƒÅms; adoration to MahƒÅganapati and certain other deities; twelve names of Ganesa, hyma of praise to Gana≈õ8, Gauri, Vi≈ünu; mention of the place and the time with astronomical details about the day, the nak≈üatrs &o. ; then the sankalpa of performing devap≈ØjƒÅ with sixteen upacaras ; contemplation on Ganapati with Rg. II. 23. 1 ( gapƒÅnƒÅm tv√•); asanavidhi with an invocation to the earth ; nyasa (mystical sanctification of the body ) of the sixteen verses of Rg. X 90 on sixteen parts of the body; inyocation of the deities and the saored rivers in the water jar and offering sandalwood paste, flowers and whole grains of rice to the jar; then invocation of the conch and bell in a similar way; sprinkling of oneself and the materials of worsbip with water accompanied by the mantra (‘apavitrah pavitro vƒÅ &c.'); dhyana (contemplation) of Vi≈ünu, Siva, Ganesa, the sun’s diso, DurgƒÅ holding a bunch of flowers in one’s folded hands; then offering the sixteen upacaras enume. rated above to the accompaniment of the 16 verses of Rg. X. 90 to one’s favourite deity ; final benediction, 1761 When several deities are worshipped, there are two methods in which the upacaras may be offered. One may offer the upacaras from ƒÄv√§bapa to namaskƒÅra to one deity or the principal deity and then the same upacaras to the other deity or deities one after

another. This method is oalled kandƒÅnusamaya. The other method occurs when √§vƒÅbana is done for the several deities in order, then √§gana for all, then p√§dya for all and so on up to namas k√§ra. This is called padƒÅrthƒÅnusamaya. This method is generally preferred. Vide the com. of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa on ƒÄ≈õv. gr. I. 24. 7, the com. on KatyƒÅyana-srauta 1. 5. 9-11 for detailed explanations of these.

From the early centuries of the Christian era the works on Tantra exercised & profound influence on the ritual of devapƒÅjƒÅ and several mystical postures of the hands and fingers such as the mudrƒÅs and the nyƒÅsas began to occupy the minds of the worshippers. 1762 The BhƒÅgavata-purƒÅ≈Üa XI. 27. 7 says that devap≈´jƒÅ is of three kinds viz, Vaidiki, T√°ntriki and misr√£. The first and the third are for the three varnas and Tantrikt for k≈´dras.

CHAPTER XX

VAISVADEVA Vai≈°vadeva.-offering of cooked food to all Gods ).

Daksa ( II. 56 ) says that in the 5th part of the day a house holder has to allow distribution of food according to his ability to the gods, Manes, men and even insects. Vai vadeva is to be offered according to S√§t√§tapa ( quoted by MedhƒÅtithi on Manu V, 7 and by AparƒÅrka p. 142) in the gphya fire if one has preserved it, or in the ordinary fire. If no fire is available one may offer it even in water or on the bare ground. Laghu. VyƒÅga II. 52 says the same.

Somo medieval works like the Smrtyarthag√§ra and the Par, M. (I. part 1, p. 389 ) state that vai≈°vadeva really com prises the three daily sacrifices viz. devayaj√±a, bh≈´tayaj√±a and pitsyaj√±a. The rite is so called because in it sacrifice is offered to all the gods or because food is cooked therein for all the gods. 1763 But in the ancient gphyas≈´tras the three yaj√±as are kept distinct. In the ƒÄ≈õv. gr. III. 1 the five daily sacrifices are enumerated, but only one, the brahmayaj√±a, is thereafter described in detail and we have to understand that Vai≈°vadeva bas already been dealt with under homa in ƒÄ≈õv, gr I. 2. 1-2 and that I. 2. 3-10 is concerned with bb≈´tayaj√±a or baliharana, out of which the 7th s≈´tra contemplates an offering to Visve-devas and s≈´tra 10 an offering of cooked food to pitrs. The SƒÅn. gr. II. 14 speaks of Vai≈°vadeva, wbile Gobhila gr. I. 4. 1-15, KhƒÅdira gr. I. 5. 22-35 speak of balibarapa only. Panini VI. 2. 39 teaches the accent of ‘k≈üullaka-vai≈õvadeva’ (as & compound). Vaik. 1784 VI. 17 expressly says that devayaj√±a is the home to the gods offered with cooked food meant for all the gods. According to Gautaina (V.9) the deities of vai≈°vadevo are Agoi, Dhanvantari, Vi≈õve-devas, PrajƒÅpati and Svi≈ütakrt (Agni). According 1785 to Manu (III. 84-86) the deities are Agni,
