History of Dharmasastra

| Ch. XXII

Manu, Vispu and Vas, it is clear that when the extant works attributed to these authors were composed, they themselves were staunch upholders of ahimsƒÅ, but that there were two classes of people in their days who were not opposed to flesh-eating, one class holding that killing animals only for purposes for which the Veda expressly sanctioned hiins≈´ was not improper and another class that indulged in flesh-eating without restrictions. That in spite of the individual predilections of the author of the Manusmrti, general usage was different even in Manu’s day is indicated by the fact that in III. 227 Manu says that in sraddha the performer should get ready various kinds of food including flesh of tempting varieties. Y√°j. I. 258-260 states how flesh of various animals when served in grƒÅddha to the brahmanas invited tends to gauge satisfaction to the Manes for long periods. Bphas pati quoted by Sarvaj√±a-N√§r√§yapa explained Manu V. 27 as a pari samkhyƒÅ i. e. Manu does not enjoin flesh-eating on the four ocoasions stated, but only permits it and forbids it on other occasions. 1886 Centuries were required before the views pro pounded by Manu became predominant. Gradually large seo tions of the population of India gave up flesh-eating and even those who did not regard it as forbidden to them rarely partook of it or did so in an apologetic way. The spread of Vai≈üpavism tended to wean people from flesh as required by the Bhagavata purapa 1867 (VII. 15. 7-8) which is to the Vai≈üpavas what the Bible is to the Christians. In medieval and modern times all brahmanas avoid flesh (except some br√°bma≈Üas in northern and eastern India that hold that fish may be eaten); BO also do many vaisyas, particularly those who are Vai≈üpavas and even among s√ºdras there are many who do not touch flesh and regard abstention from flesh as meritorious. From ancient times the k≈üatriyas have been meat-eaters. The Mahabharata hag in several places to say & great deal on flesh-eating. In the Vanaparva 50. 4 it is stated that the PƒÅ≈Üdava beroes killed with unpoisoned arrows deer and first offered venison to brƒÅhma·πáas and partook of it themselves. In Sabha 4. 1-2 king Yudhisthira on the opening of Mayasabha feasted ten thousand br√°bmanas with various delicacies including the flesh of wild boars and

Bhojana-flesh-ealing

781

deer. Vanaparva 208. 11-121868 offers the consoling thought (that is conveyed by the Rgveda itself) that animals killed in sacri. fices to the accompaniment of Vedio mantras went to heaven and it narrates the story of king Rantideva in whose sacrifices two thousand animals and cows were killed every day. Anu ≈õƒÅgana 116. 8 contains the view that there is nothing so nourish. ing as meat for those who are wounded or weak or worried or who are given up to too much sexual gratification and those exhausted by long travel. AnugƒÅgana 116. 16-19 allows flesh of animals killed by hunting to k≈üatriyas. There are some passages where the Mahabharata contains the same sentiments as those of Manu e. g. Anu≈°ƒÅgana 115 highly praises abstention from meat and a few verses of this chapter (e. g. 115. 44-45, 48) are very similar to Manu’s (V. 27, 51 ). Sankha quoted by AparƒÅrka p. 1167 allows the flesh of buffaloes, goats, rams, ruru deer, ordinary deer and spotted deer. H√§rita quoted in the Gr. R. P. 375 mentions the flesh of goats, rams, buffaloes, deer of Various kinds (ruru, prsata, nyanku, ≈°k≈üa ), rhinoceros, and large forest boars as permissible, while Devala quoted by the same forbids the flesh of COWB, asses, camels, horges, elephants, lions, tigers, bears, sarabhas, snakes, boa constrictor, rats and mice, cats, mongoose, village hog, dog, jackal, animals of un known species, cheettas, dark-faced apes, monkeys and human beings. Manu V.51 ( = Vi≈ünu Dh. 8. 51. 74) says that he who gives consent to the killing of an animal ( for food ), who cuts off the limbs, who kills the animal, who sells or purchases meat, who cooks it, who serves meat and the ester of meat these are all guilty of killing Yama ( quoted in Ahn. Pr. p. 533 ) says that the eater is the greatest sinner out of these, &s, if there were no eators of meat, no one would kill animals for food.

Gaut. 17. 29 and 34-35, Ap. Dh. S. I. 5. 17. 32-34, Vas. Dh. 8. 14. 48, Vi≈ünu Dh. 8. 51. 29-31, Manu V. 11-14, Yaj. I. 172-175 contain long lists of birds the flesh of which was forbidden and of those the flesh of whioh was allowed. A few of these may be noted. All birds that subsist on raw flesh ( vultures &c.), the c√£taka, parrot, hamsa, all birds that dwell in a village ( auch es pigeons), baka, birds that scratch dungbills for food are forbidden; while wild cocks and peacocks were permitted. On Jaimini V. 3.26-28 Sabara quotes a Vedic text that one who has

History of Dharmasastra

[Ch. XXII

constructed the fire altar (agnicit) should not eat the flesh of birds till the sacrifice he has embarked on is finished.

About fish there is no unanimity. Ap. Da. S. I. 5. 17. 36-37 says among fish the ceta ( long-nosed orocodile ? ) is forbidden, 80 also are fish with snake-like heade, the makara, fish that subsist on dead flesh, fish that have strange forms (such as those that have heads like men, or that look like elephants ).’ Manu on the other hand regards fish-eating as the worst form of flesh-eating and forbids all fish (V. 14-15 ), but then makes an exception (V. 16) in favour of fish called PƒÅ»õhina and Robita if used in rites for gods and Manes and fish called rajiva, lion-faced fish and fish having scales. Vide Vas. Dh. S. 14. 41-42, Gaut. 17. 36, YƒÅj. I. 177-178 also.

About milk several rules are stated in the sm·∫∑tis. Gaut. 17. 22-26, Ap. Dh. 8. 1.5, 17, 22-24, Vas. Dh. S. 14. 34-35, Baud. Dh. S. I. 5, 156-158, Manu V. 8-9, Vi≈ünu Dh. S. 51. 38-41, Yaj. I. 170 lay down that the milk of a cow that is sandhini, 1869 the call of which is dead, that gives birth to twins and that has not passed ten days after delivery, from whose udders milk oozes of itself, is forbidden. The milk of sheep and she-buffaloes also is not to be used until the lapse of ten days after delivery. The milk of ewes, of camels and of all animals with one hoof is altogether forbidden. The Mit. (on Yaj. T. 170) notes that even the ourds and other products of such milk as is forbidden are also forbidden, but Visvar√ªpa thought that only the milk of a cow whose calf is dead, or who is sandhini, or who has not passed ten days after delivery is forbidden and not curds and other produota thereof. The milk of even a cow that feeds’ on impure food should not be used 1870 (Vi≈ügu Dh. 8. 51. 41 and Atri verse 301 ). In the VayupurƒÅ≈Üa even the milk of she buffaloes is forbidden. 1871 Baud. Dh. 8. (L. 5. 159-160) prescribes the ponance called PrƒÅjƒÅpatya for drinking forbidden milk of all animals except the cow and a fast for three days for drink

  1. The word sandbinl' is explained in throe ways as a cow in boat', ‘that gives milk once a day’, ‘a cow that yields milk on account of another calf being brought to it, its own being dead’. Vide Mit. on Yaj. I. 170.

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-rules about milk

783

ing the milk of a cow when forbidden. Apastamba-smrti (in Verse) forbids the milk of a kapila cow to all except to brƒÅhma·πáas and the Bhari≈üyapurƒÅ≈Üa says that even a brahmana is to use only such portion of the milk of such a cow that remains after employing it in rites for gods.1878 The Brahma* pur≈°≈Üa says ‘one should not partake of curds at night even if one is starting on a journey, but in madbuparka it may be used at night. Ill-luck dwells in fried grain by day and in curds and barley by night and in KovidƒÅra and Kapittha ( trees or fruits ) at all times’ ( quoted in Gr. R. p. 370). Manu IV. 75 forbids the eating after sunset of all food in which gesame are mixed.

Several herbs and vegetables have been forbidden from very ancient times. According to ƒÄp. Dh. 8. (1. 5. 17. 25-27) all herbs from which liquors are distilled, kala√±ja (red garlic ), pal√°ndu (onions), parƒÅrska ( dark garlio) and whatever similar vegetables are not used by respectable people, should not be eaten; and a brƒÅbma≈Üa text prescribes that ‘ky√§ku’ (mush rooms) are forbidden. Gaut. 17. 32-33 forbids tender leaves (of trees), kyƒÅku, lasuna and the resins of trees and the red sap flowing from incisions made in the barks of trees. Vas. Dh. 8. 14. 33 forbids the eating of lasuna, palƒÅ≈Üdu, kyƒÅku, gƒü√±ja na (turnip), Sle≈ümƒÅtaka, the resins of trees and red sap (as in Gautama ). Manu V. 5-6 forbids lasuna, palandu, grƒÅjana, musbrooms ( kavaka ) and all herbs that spring from impure soil and manure, red resins and red sap (as in Gautams) and selu ( sle≈üm√§taka ) fruit. YƒÅj. I. 171 and 176 adds sigru and pres oribes the penance of c√¢ndrƒÅyana for eating forbidden herbs and vegetables. The great difficulty is to find out the modern equivalents of some of the herbs and vegetables. According to & verse quoted in G»ô. R. p. 356 from the Smrtima√±jari there are ten varieties of palƒÅ≈Üdu of which gƒºƒÅjana 1873 is one. AparƒÅrka p. 249 quotes passages from the BrahmapurƒÅ≈Üa forbidding various kinds of herbs and vegetables. Vide also Gr. R. pp. 354-356 for quotations from Devala and others about herbs and

(Ch. XXII

vegetables that are forbidden. The Mit. on Y√°j. III. 290 quotes a g≈´tra of Sumantu that lasuna and other vegetables are not forbidden to those who are ill, if they are prescribed by way of medicine. 1884 About asafoetida (hingu ) Haradatta on Gaut. 17, 32 says ‘it is doubtful whether it is a resin or is & sap flowing from incisions, but even respectable people partake of it and that camphor not being red nor & resin nor a sap may be eaten.’ The Sm. O. (op br√§ddha p. 413 ) says that some smrtis forbid the use of hingu in gr√§ddba, while the AdipurƒÅna allows it and therefore there is an option. The Gr. R. p. 354 shows that the round alƒ´bu (gourd ) was forbidden. V»õddha-Harita VII. 113-119 mentions herbs, vegetables and fruits that are forbidden. Vide also the SinftimuktƒÅphala (abnika pp. 434-435 ) for quotations as to the names of several roots, fruits and vegetables that were fobid. den together with their South Indian names.

Ap. Dh. 8. II. 8. 18. 2 forbids the use of dark grains (like mƒÅ≈üa beans) in sr√•ddha. The Mahabh√§≈üya says ‘when it is declared that mƒÅsa beans should not be eaten, they are not to be eaton even when other grains of oorn are mixed up with them’ (vol. I. p. 127) 1875 The Gr. R. p. 359 quotes the BrahmapurƒÅ≈Üa “iT6 forbidding the use of certain cereals generally such as rƒÅjamƒÅ≈üa, sth≈´lamudga (called ‘metbi’ in Marathi), masura &c. Sankha Likhita 1897 quoted in Ahn, Pr. p. 394 allows the employment in offering to gods of all cereals, except kodrava, canaka ( gram ), m√•ga, mag≈´ra, kulattha and uddalaka. Vrddha-HƒÅrsta VII. 110-111 also mentions the corns that are forbidden.

Gaut. 17. 14-16, Ap. Dh. 8.1.5.17.17-19, Vas. Dh. 8. 14. 28-29 and 37-38, Manu V. 10, 24-25, Y√°j. I. 167 prescribe that cooked food which has become sour by being kept for some time or by being mixed with something else should not be eaten nor should stale (over which the day or night has passed ) food be eaten, nor food cooked twice ( with interval) except curds and butter milk and except stale articles like vegetables, cakes, fried grain,

Ch. XXII

Bhojana-forbidden food

785

porridge, pulse cakes, those boiled in oil and rioe boiled in milk or when mixed with honey; and that even stale food flavoured with ghee or ourds or the remnant of food offered to the gods may be eaten. Manu V. 25, Vas. Dh. S. 14. 37-38, Ap. Dh, S, I. 5. 17. 19 and YƒÅj. I. 169 say that articles of wheat and yava flour and products of milk though stale and unmixed with ghee may be eaten by all dvijƒÅtis, provided they have not turned

sour.

The above long lists of forbidden vegetables, meat, milk furnish examples of food that is jƒÅtidu≈üta or svabhƒÅvadu≈ü ta. The rules about not eating stale and sour food illustrate food that is k√ºladu≈üta. Any article of food which is mixed up with forbidden things like palƒÅndu or is in contact with unclean substances or food in which hair or an inseot is found or in which uxoreta or the limb or tail of a mouse is found, food touched by a woman in her monthly course or in which & bird (like the crow ) has thrust its beak or food touched by a dog or smelt by & cow or food from a house in mourning or from a family in impurity due to birth should be avoided ( vide Ap. Dh. $. I. 5. 16. 19-20 and 24-29, Manu IV, 207-209, 212, 217, YƒÅj. I. 167-168 ). If a dog or an apapƒÅtra sees food which & man is eating or if a person when engaged in taking his meal sees a cƒÅn. dƒÅla, & dog, a crow or a cock or 8 woman in her course, he should leave the food and get up. Manu (III.239-240) says that a c√£≈Üdala, a village hog or a village cook or a dog, & menstruating woman and an impotent person should not be allowed to see brƒÅhma·πáas eating, whether in rites for gods or Manes, or at times of gifts. K√§tyƒÅyana says that if & brƒÅhma·πáa hears the voice of a cƒÅ≈ÜdƒÅla, a patita, or a woman in her course he should at once leave eating and if he eats even one morsel after hearing their voice he has to observe a fast for one day. 1878 The rules about not eating food from a house in mourning illustrate food that is nimittadu≈üta (forbidden by reason of an occasion or chance reason ), the other rules about food

Ch. XXII

forbidden because of contact with unclean things or with garlic &c. exemplify samsarga-du≈üta (forbidden because of contact) and the rules about avoiding food seen by a dog &o. are examples of kriya-du≈üta (forbidden on account of certain actions ). The smrti writers were not devoid of practical common sense, Baud. Dh, S. II. 7. 7 says that if in a heap of cooked food, hair, bits of nails or skin or insects or dung of rats is seen, then a lump from that part where these are seen should be taken out and the rest should have water sprinkled over it and holy ashes should be scattered over it and water should be again sprinkled over it and brƒÅhma·πáas should then louldly declare the food to be all right and it may be then used for serving. Vaik. 1879 IX. 15 contains a similar direction. ParƒÅ. sara VI. 71-74 says that cooked food (rice) amounting in quantity to one drona or one √§dhaka, 1880 if licked by a dog or by a orow or smelt by a cow or an ass, should not be thrown away, but should be purified and then used, and that the portion spoilt by touch &c. should be taken away from the whole mass, the rest should be sprinkled over with water in which & golden piece has been dipped and fire should be brought in contact with it (by ignited darbha ) and brƒÅhmanas should recite Vedic texts over it and then it may be served. Vas. Db. 8. 14. 23 and 25‚Äì26, Yaj. I. 189 and 191 contain similar rules. 1881

Food cooked only for oneself and not for offering to gods or guests should not be eaten (Gaut, 17, 19, Manu IV. 213 ). This is called samsk√§ra-du≈üta ( forbidden on account of the absence of purificatory rites ) by the SmrtyarthasƒÅra p. 68. The largest number of injunctions are concerned with parigrahadu≈üta (food which may be good in itself but is forbidden because of its coming from the hands of or being owned by certain persons ), The following is a fairly comprehensive list of such persons compiled from Ap. Dh. 8. I. 6.18. 16-33 and I. 6. 19.1, Gaut. 15.18 and 17. 17-18, Vas. Dh. 8. 14. 2-11, Manu IV. 205-220, Y√°j.

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-whose food forbidden

787

I. 160-165, Veda-Vy√°sa III. 50-54, BrahmapurƒÅ≈Üa quoted by AparƒÅrka pp. 1177‚Äì79 and other works :-one who has not kept the sacred ( srauta and gƒºhya) fires, a miser (who stints even his parents, children, wife through greed), one imprisoned ( or fettered), a thief, an impotent person, & wrestler (or one who subsists by going on the stage ), & vai≈Üa i. e. & worker in bamboo (or na»õa according to Visvar≈´pa ), a singer, an actor, an abhi≈°asta (one charged with having committed & mahƒÅpataka ), a usurer, & courtezen, a sangha or a gana (group or band of roguish brƒÅhma·πáas or others ), one who is initiated for a Vedic sacrifice (till he has not bought soma or has not offered an animal to Agni and some ; vide Ap. Dh. 8. I. 6. 18. 23-26 which quote the Ait. Br.), a physician ( who subsists by the practice of medioine ), a surgeon, a fowler, & hunter (for selling flesh), one suffering from an incurable disease, one who is irascible or cruel, an up chaste woman, a matta (one intoxicated or puffed up by wealth and learning), an enemy, an ugra ( one ferocious in look or words or & man of that caste ), patita ( an outoast), vr√°tya ( vide pp. 376-379 above ), a hypocrite ( or swindler), one who eats the remnants of others' food (or of a s√ºdra ), a woman whose husband is not living and who has no son, & goldsmith, & hen pecked husband, one who serves as a priest to the whole village, & vendor of weapons, a blacksmith, a ni≈üada, a tailor, a svavrtti (one subsisting by keeping dogs, or one who does menial ser vice ), a king, 1988 a king’s purohita, & rajaka ( a washerman or dyer ), an ungrateful person, one who makes his livelihood by killing animals, & distiller or seller of liquors, one who stays in the same house with his wife’s paramour, one who sells the soma plant, a back-biter, a liar, an oil-presser, a bard, a son-in-law (88 long as he has no son or child ),1888 & sonless man (Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 290 quoting Likhita ), one who starts & sacrifice without studying the Veda, & woman sacrificer, a carpenter, one who makes his living by astrology, one whose duty is to ring bells (for reminding the king of the time or awakening bim), a grƒÅma k≈´ta (a village officer, Apararka p. 239), a parivitti, a parivividƒÅna, the husband of a s√ºdra woman or of & remarried widow, the

History of Dharmasastra

[ Ch. XXII

son of a punarbh≈´, & worker in hides, & potter, a spy, one who becomes an ascetio without following the rules laid down for that asrama, a lunatio, one who has sat down at his debtor’s house in dharna. Manu IV. 222 prescribes a fast for three days if a brahmana partakes of the food of these unknowingly, but the kycchra ( Prajapatya ) for knowingly doing so. Baud. Dh. 8. II. 3. 10 prescribes the japa of Rg. IX. 58 (tarat sa mandi ) for eating the food of one from whom it should not have been taken. Manu XI. 253 and Vis≈Üu Dh. S. 56. 6 do the same.

The next question is whose food may be taken. Great fluc tuations have occurred in the usages during the last two thousand years or more in this matter. Gaut. 17. 1 says ‘a brahmana may eat at the houses of all dvij√§tis ( the three higher varpas ) who are well-known to be performing the peculiar duties of their varna or a≈õrama.” Gaut. 2. 41, Baud. Dh. 8. 1. 2. 18-19, Ap. Dh. S. I. 1. 3. 25 allow a brahmacarin to beg for food at the houses of men of all varnas, except those who are apapƒÅtra and abhitasta ( suspected of mah√§p√§takas). Ap. Dh. S. I. 6. 18. 9 first prescribes for a brƒÅhmapa who has returned from his teacher’s house that he should not eat in the houses of the ksatriya and other varnas (as a general rule ), then he gives the opinion of some that he may take food from members of all varnas except s≈´dras, provided they abide by the rules for their varpa. He also notices that even s≈´dra’s food may be eaten if he serves a dvijƒÅti in virtue of his duty to do so. Even Veda. Vy√°ga III. 56 expressly declares that all dvijƒÅlis who know each other’s families may partake of food at each other’s houses. 1884 Ap. Dh. S. I. 6. 19. 2-12 raises the question as to whose food may be eaten and names several sages who differed in their views. Kanva said that one may eat the food of only him who wishes to give (and so requests ), Kautsa thought that one may eat the food of him only who is holy (punya ); VarsyƒÅya·πái said that one may accept from whoever is liberal enough to give; Eka, Kupika, Kanva, Kutse and Pu≈ükarasƒÅdi held that alms (food) offered by a pure man may be eaten; V√§rsyayani said what is offered by any body without asking may be accepted ; according to H√§rita one should not accept food whioh is offered after an express previous announcement ‘I shall give you such and such a kind of food.’ ƒÄpastamba’s own view appears to have been ( I. 6. 19. 9-11) that one should accept the food of him whose conduct is religious and who

  1. Protarar Forrafar

: ITERURT III. 66.

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-whose food may be eaten

1789

desires to offer food, that one should not accept the food even of a righteous man if he shows even the slightest unwillingness to give and that whatever is offered unasked may be accepted. These directions are rather vague.

In modern times a person is more lax in taking food pre pared with oil or ghee or milk. He may take such food from members of certain castes otber than his own. But ordinarily he would not take food cooked in water from any person belong. ing to another caste or even sub-division of the same caste. In towns and cities there is a strong tendenoy to considerably relax these restrictions. We saw above that in the times of Gautama and Apastamba and others a brƒÅhma·πáa was allowed to take food prepared in the houses of k≈üatriyas, vaisyas, and even s≈´dras. Gradually this latitude came to be restricted and most of tho g≈´tras and early gmptis restrict the liberty to take food from s≈´dras by saying that only from the following among ≈õ≈´dras a brƒÅhmana can take cooked food, viz, one who cultivates the brƒÅhmana’s field on the system of paying half of the crops to the latter, & family friend, one’s cowherd, one’s barber, one doing personal service i. 6. & dƒÅsa ( vide Gaut. 17. 6, Manu IV. 253, Vis≈Üu Dh. S. 57. 16, YƒÅj. I. 166, Angiras 120-121, Veda. VyƒÅsa III, 55 and ParƒÅ≈õara XI. 21 ). Manu and YƒÅj. add that any s≈´dra who declares to a brƒÅhma·πáa that the former is going to be dependent on the latter and who declares what his actions have been and how he will serve the brahmana is also bhojyƒÅnna (one whose food may be eaten). The Mit. quotes a s≈´tra wbich includes the potter among these (on YƒÅj. I. 166 ) and Devala also does so, 1885 It may be stated that ParƒÅ≈õara (XI. 22-24) gives peculiar meanings to the words dƒÅga, nƒÅpita, gopƒÅla and ardhika. The general rule forbidding the food of s≈´dras is stated by Vas. Dk. 8. 14. 4, Manu IV. 211 and 223, YƒÅj. I 160. Angiras 121 says that he who takes cooked food from s≈´dras other than the five excepted above has to undergo cƒÅndrƒÅya·πáa penance. Atri ( 172-173 ) prescribes the same penance for’a dvijs eating the food of a washerman, an actor and & worker in bamboos and the penance of parƒÅka for taking the food of or residing amongst antyajas. Vas. Dh. 8.

790

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXII

VI. 26-29, Angiras 69-70, Ap. ( verse) 8.9-11 severely condemn a brahmana partaking of food from s√ºdrag. Angiras 75, Ap. ( verse ) VIII. 8-9 declare that a brƒÅhma·πáe who is an agnihotrin and yet does not desist from s≈´dra food loses five viz. his self, his vedio lore and his three ( sacred fires ). MedhƒÅtithi on Manu V. 84 expressly states that the barber is touchable and bhojyƒÅnna ( whose food may be taken). This shows that up to the 9th century A, D, the rules about taking food from even Certain g≈´dras had not become rigid in all provinces of India. Angiras 77-78. Ap. ( verse ) 8. 11-13 and Yama ( quoted in Gr. R. P. 334 ) declare that a brƒÅhma·πáa may eat at a brƒÅhma·πáa’s at all times, at & k≈üatriya’s only on parvans (on full moon &c. ), at & vaisya’s when the latter is initiated for a sacrifice, at a s≈´dra’s never and the food of the four varnas is respectively like nectar, milk, food and blood. 1888 According to Manu IV. 223 a brƒÅhma·πáa could take from a s≈´dra uncooked food for a night, if he had no other means of subsistence. When exaotly brƒÅhma·πáas were forbidden to take food from k≈üatriyas or vaisyas it is difficult to say. In the Kalivarjya section all that is forbidden is taking food from the five s≈´dras enumerated in Manu IV. 253. Gaut. 17.1 prescribes that fuel, water, fodder, roots, fruits, honey, protection, what is offered unasked, a bed, seat, shelter, conveyance, milk, ourds, roasted grain, safari ( small fish ), priyangu (millet ), & garland, meat of deer, vegetables must not be refused when offered by any one spontaneously. Vas. Dh. S. 14. 12, Manu IV. 50 are to the same effect. Angiras 1887 quoted in Gr. R. p. 337 states that cow’s milk, barley flour, oil, oil-cakes, cakes (of flour) may be taken from a s≈´dra and eaten and whatever else is cooked in milk. B»ôhat-ParƒÅ≈õara VI. says “uncooked meat, ghee, honey and oils extracted from fruits, even if they are kept in a mleccha’s vessel, become pure the moment they are taken out of suoh veggel; similarly milk, curds, and ghee contained in Vessels of √°bhiras are blameless and the vessels are pure as long as these articles are contained in them. 1888 Laghu-S√§tƒÅtapa 128

Wh

__1886. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡§ø ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•à‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á‡§ó‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç

(Jivananda, part 2 p. 210 ).

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-food allowed

791

says that corn lying in the field or on the threshing floor, water drawn from wells and milk while still in the cow enclosures may be taken even from one whose food is forbidden. Even such later writers as Haradatta stated that a brƒÅhmans may eat the food of the five s≈´dras named by Manu IV. 253 in extreme distress only.

Certain articles were not to be eaten at certain stages only. For example, a brahmac√§rin was not to partake of honey, meat, and k≈üƒÅra-lavana ( vide ƒÄp. Db. 8. I. 1. 4. 6, M√§nava gr. I. 1. 12). But in danger of life he could eat even these (vide MedhƒÅtithi on Manu V. 27). Similarly a forest hermit and on ascetic were forbidden many things ( which will be discussed later on). A 5≈üatriya was not to drink soma juice (vide p. 140 above ).

There were rules about the persons who might be engaged to cook and serve food. As brƒÅhma·πáas could in very ancient times eat the food of all varnas including at least some s≈´dras, no difficulty must have been felt. The ƒÄp. Dh. S. (II. 2. 3. 1-6 ) prescribes that ƒÅryas (i. e. the three varnas ) purified (by & bath ) may prepare the food for vai≈°vadeva; they should stop speaking, coughing or spitting with their faces turned towards the food that is being prepared and should touch water on touch. ing their hair, limbs or garment; or s≈´dras supervised by aryas may be the cooks. ƒÄp. Dh. 8, further requires that when g≈´dras are cooks they should shave their hair and beard and pare their nails every day or on the 8th day or parva days and they must always bathe with thoir olothes on. Laghu-Asv. I. 176 says that food should be cooked by one’s wife, daughter-in-law, son, pupil, elderly relative, or one’s ƒÅcƒÅrya or by oneself. AparƒÅrka (p. 500 ) quotes a verse of N√§rƒÅyana that food must be served to a dvijƒÅti by a wife of the same caste ( if he has wives of different oastes ).

Although numerous rules are laid down about the persons at whose house food may or may not be taken, the ideal placed before householders was that they should not as far as possible eat at the houses of others and should only do so if they are invited by a blameless person ( vide Gaut. 17. 8, Manu III. 104, Yaj. I. 112). Manu III. 104 holds out the threat that those who constantly seek to subsist on the food given by others become after death the cattle of those who give them food.

It is necessary to say a few words on drinking liquor ( madyapƒÅna).

792

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

( Ch. XXII

In the Rgveda a distinction is made between soma and sura (liquor ), the former being an intoxicating drink, but reserved for being offered (as a sacred beverage) to gods and to be drunk by the priests, while the latter seems to have been meant as a beverage for common men and not usually offered to gode. In Rg. VII. 86. 6 the sage 1889 Vasi≈ütha implores Varuna to recognize that a man does not commit sin by his own urge or power, but that it is due to destiny or surƒÅ, anger, dice ( gambl ing) or heedlessness. In Rg. VIII. %. 12 the sage exclaims that draughts of some when quaffed by Indra create in his heart such tumult as those who are heavily intoxicated engage in when surƒÅ is drunk. Rg. I. 116,7 mentions among the deeds of Asvins this that they filled & hundred jars of surƒÅ from the hoof of their powerful horse which (hoof) was like kƒÅrotara (a strainer or leather-bag?). Rg. I. 191. 10 refers to the leather-bag (of wine ) in the house of & vintner. In belauding bhojas ( liberal mon) Rg. X. 107. 9 says that they won the inner draught of surƒÅ (from their foes ). In Rg. X. 131. 1890 4 and 5 the Asvins are praised for having drunk surƒÅms (surƒÅ mixed with soma) and helped Indra in his fight with the Asura Namuoi. In the Atharvaveda IV. 34. 6 the reward for the per former of sacrifices is said to be heaven in which there are lakes full of ghee and honey, and wherein liquor flows like water. In Atharva veda 14. 1. 35-36 and 15. 9. 2-3 surƒÅ is referred to. The Vaj. 8. 19.7 distinguished between surƒÅ and soma ' thou art the powerful surƒÅ and this is soina ; don’t destroy me when thou enterest thy place. In the Tai. 1891 8. II. 5. 1 ff, the Sat. Br. I 6. 3 and V. 5. 4 there is a legend of Visvar≈´pa, the son of Tvagtr, which narrates how he had three heads, one of which Was soma-drinking, one wine-drinking and a third for eating

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-drinking liquor

793

food, how Indra cut off the heads of Visvar≈´pa, how Tva≈üƒ±r being furious at the slaughter of his son performed a soms Bacrifice from which he excluded Indra, how Indra, though not invited, consumed all the some that was in the tub, how the drinking of too much soma injured Indra and how the gods healed him by the i≈üti called SautrƒÅma≈Üi (for SutrƒÅmap, ‘the good protector’, Indra). This SautrƒÅƒ±nani sacrifice was per formed for & priest who drank too much soma and therefore either began to vomit or had severe purging. Vide KƒÅtyƒÅyana ≈õr. 19.1.4. It was also performed by him who had an enemy(Sat. Br. XII. 7. 3. 4). In this sacrifice & brƒÅhma·πáa had to be hired for drinking the dregs of surƒÅ offered in it and if one was not found willing to do it the dregs were to be poured on an ant-hill.1882 How sur√£ ( liquor) was prepared is described in the Sat. Br. XII. 7. 3.5 and in KƒÅtyƒÅyana ≈õr. 19. 1. 20-27 ( vide S. B. E. vol. 44, p. 223 n. 2 which summarises the com. on K√§ty√§. yana ). In Jaimini III. 5. 14-15 there is a discussion about the SautrƒÅma≈Üi sacrifice and Sabara quotes the passage of the Tai. Br. I. 8. 6 about hiring a brƒÅhma·πáa for drinking the dregs of the surƒÅ offered in the sacrifice. The Sat. Br. contrasts some and of surƒÅ by saying ‘soma is truth, prosperity, light and surƒÅ is untruth, misery, darkness’ (V.1.5. 28 ). The Sat. Br. V. 5. 4. 21 expresses dread 1893 of mixing up the libations of some and of surƒÅ together. The Kathaka Samhita XII. 12 contains the follow ing interesting remark. “Therefore an elderly person or & youngster, the daughter-in-law and father-in-law drink liquor and remain babbling together; foolishness (or thoughtlessness ) is indeed sin; therefore a brƒÅhma·πáa does not drink surƒÅ with the thought otherwise ( if I drink it) I may be affected by sin’; therefore this is for ksatriya ; one should say to a br√•hmana that surƒÅ, if drunk by & k≈üatriya, does not harm the latter.” 1884 This passage makes it Olear that at the time of the Kathaka Samhita public opinion had come to this stage that brƒÅhma·πáas had generally given up drinking surƒÅ. ( Ch. XXII

Tai. Br. quoted above establishes that it had become difficult to find a br√°bmana willing to drink even the remnants of surƒÅ left after being offered in a sacred Vedio rite like the SautrƒÅmani. The above passage from the Kathaka is quoted by the Tantra. v√•rtika on Jaimini I. 3. 7 (p. 210 ) and explained by it as referring to sidhu (rum ) and liquor prepared from honey. SamkarƒÅcƒÅrya in his bhƒÅ≈üya on the VedƒÅnta≈ü√ºtra III. 4. 31 quotes1895 this passage expressly from the Kathaka Samhita. In the Ait. Br. (37. 4) it is stated that when a king has undergone & solemn coronation ceremony the purohita places in his hand a vessel of sur√¢. A≈õvapati, king of Kekaya, proudly declares in the Chandogya Up. V. 11.5 to the learned brƒÅhma·πáas that came to him for the lore about Vai≈°vƒÅnara ‘in my country there is no thief, no miser, no madyapa ( drinker of intoxicants ), none who has not kept the sacred fires, none who is not learned, no man of loose character; whence can there be a woman of loose character in my country?’ In Ch√•ndogya V, 10.9 one who drinks sur√£ is enumerated among the five grave sinners.

It is somewhat strange that in some of tbe gƒôbya s≈´tras it is stated that in the rites on Anva≈ütakƒÅ day when pindas are offered to the male ancestors, pindas are offered to the mother, paternal grandmother and paternal great-grandmother and also liquor is offered. For example, the ƒÄ≈õv, gr. II. 5. 5 says that to the wives ( of the ancestors ) are offered surƒÅ and the scum of boiled rice in addition'( to the pindas ). 1896 The PƒÅr. g·ªâ. (III. 3) states also to the female ancestors be makes pipda offerings and pours for them liquor and water oblations into pits.' The Kathaka gs. (65. 7-8) also prescribes that in the Anva≈ütaka surƒÅ was to be sprinkled with a spoon about the pindas for women ancestors and the pi≈Üdas were to be eaten by servents or by ni≈üadas or may be thrown in fire or water or brƒÅhma·πáas may eat them. It is difficult to account for this. If & conjeo. ture may be hazarded, it is possible that women drank ( perhaps secretly ) liquor even when their husbands had given up the practice owing to the force of public opinion or that in those days (before the grhya s√ºtras ) intercaste marriages being allowed, the women ancestors might have been ksatriya or

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-drinking liquor

795

vaisya women and so were not unfamiliar with drinking. Manu XI. 95 forbids drinking to brƒÅhma·πáas and Kull≈´ka notes that there were commentators who held that the prohibition did not apply to brƒÅhma·πáa women. Whatever the reasons for the above directions in the gƒºhya s≈´tras may be, they run counter to the prevailing sentiments, not only of the Kathaka Sam, and the BrƒÅhma·πáa texts, but also to the unanimous prescriptions of the dharmas≈´tras and smrtis.

Gaut. II. 25,1897 Ap. Dh. S. I. 5. 17. 21, Manu XI. 94 forbid all kinds of intoxicants to brƒÅhma·πáas at all stages of life. Ap. Dh. 8. I. 7. 21. 8, Vas. Dh. $. I. 20, Vi≈ünu Dh. S. 35. 1., Manu XI. 54, YƒÅj. III. 227 hold that drinking surƒÅ or madya is one of the grave sins ( mahƒÅpƒÅtakas ). In spite of this, the Baud. Dh. $. I. %. 4 notes that among the five peculiar practices of the brƒÅhmanas in the north was that of drinking rum and it condemns all the five practices. The verses of Manu (XI. 93-94 ) 1898 are frequently quoted in digests and commentaries *sura is the filthy refuse of food and sin indeed is called mala (filth); therefore, a brƒÅhma·πáa, a rƒÅjanya, and a vsisya should not drink sur√¢, which is of three kinds, viz. prepared from molasses, from flour (or ground grains ) and from flowers of the Madh≈´ka tree; brahma≈Üas should not drink any one of these three.' The interpretations put on these verses by Visvar≈´pa on YƒÅj. (III. 222 ), the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 253, Apar√§rka p. 1069 and others establish that the word ' surƒÅ' primarily applies to paistƒ´ (liquor prepared from flour ) as Vedic usage in the Sautr√§napi sacrifice and elsewhere shows, that paisti is forbidden to all brƒÅbma≈Üas, k≈üatriyas and vai·∫•yas, that it is the drinking of paisti alone that constitutes a mahƒÅpƒÅtaka, that all intoxicants are forbidden to brƒÅhma·πáas but liquors other than pai≈üti such as those prepared from molasses or madh≈´ka flowers are not forbidden to ksatriyas and vai≈°yes. In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata ( Udyogaparva 59. 5) both Vasudeva and Arjuna are described as intoxicated by drinking tbe liquor prepared from honey and

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXII

the Tantrav√§rtika tries 1899 to establish that there was nothing wrong in this as they were ksatriyas and as Manu XI.93-94 and Gaut. II. 25 are to be construed asstated above viz. all intoxicants are forbidden to brƒÅhma·πáas and oply pai≈üti to ksatriyas and vaisyas, Intoxicants are not forbidden to g≈´dras, though Vrddha-Harita (IX.277-278) declares that some desire that good s≈´dras should abstain from surƒÅ also and that Manu says that even a s√ºdra becomes patita by falsehood, by partak ing of meat and intoxicants and by stealing another’s wealth or wife. Another rule was that brahmac√°rins, of whatever Varpa, had to abstain entirely from every kind of intoxicant (Ap. Dh. S. I. 1. 2. 23, Manu II. 177, Yaj. I. 33 ). Visvarupa on Yaj.I.33 refers to a passage from the Caraka-sakha which states that when √Åvetaketu suffered from a skin disease ( kil√°ga ), the Asving told him to take madhu ( honey or wine) and meat as medicine, and when he asked bow being a brahmacƒÅrin he could do so, they replied that a person must first gave himself (from disease and death) in all waystoo as a man can say I sball perform meritorious acts ‘only if he lives. Apar√°rka quotes the BrahmapurƒÅpa and says that in the Kali age human sacrifice, Afvamedhs sacrifice and intoxicating drinks were forbidden to the three varnas and to brahmanas in all yugas (ages). But this is opposed to bistory and tradition. 1901 The MahabhƒÅrata narrates ( Adiparva 76-77) the story of Sukra, his daughter Devayani and pupil Kaca and states that Sukra forbade for the first time brahma≈Üas from drinking intoxicants and decla red that, if any brahmana drank sura thenceforward, he would be guilty of the grave sin of brahmana-murder.1902 The

‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•å ‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡§∞‡§£‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡•§‡•§ ____1900. ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ö‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø-‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•§ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§≠‡•à‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§Æ‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§É‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•á‡§∑ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ on ‡§™‡§æ. __1901. ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§® ‡§¨‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§§ ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡§∑‡•á‡§∑ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ …… ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡•å ‡§Æ‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§≤‡•å ‡§¨‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï p. 63.

Ch. XXII)

Bhojana-drinking liquor

797

Mausalap√§rva (1. 29-30) states that BalarƒÅma prohibited the drinking of sura from the day the musala ( iron pestle) for the destruction of the Yadavas was produced and directed that any breach of his order would be punished with impalement. The S√§ntiparva ( 110. 22 ) declares that those men who always avoid honey and meat and intoxicants from their birth surmount all difficulties. Santiparva (34. 20) presoribes that, if a man drank liquor when in danger of life or through ignoranoe, he was to undergo upanayana again. Aco. to Vi≈ünu Dh. 8. 22. 83-851903 intoxicants (madya) forbidden to brƒÅhma·πáas are of ten kinds viz. those prepared from madhuka flowers, from sugarcane juice, from tanka fruit (i. e. kapittha), from koli (i. a. badara or jujube fruit), from dates, from jack-fruit, from grape juice, from honey, from maireya ( extracted from the blossoms of a plant ) and from cocoa-nut sap. Vi≈ünu ad ds that these ten kinds are not forbidden to ksatriyas and vaibyas. Pulastya quoted by the Mit. on YƒÅj. III. 253 and by AparƒÅrka p. 1075 states that surƒÅ ( distilled from rice flour) is different from the eleven kinds of madyas that he enumerates (practically the same as in Vi≈ünu). It may be stated that this sentiment against drinking is still very strong among brƒÅhma·πáas and drinking is still looked down upon by all castes, though, owing to contact with the West, some people (even including a few brƒÅhma·πáas ) have come to regard it as a fashionable indulgence.

Manu IX. 80 and YƒÅj. I. 73 say that a wife who drinks liquor is to be abandoned (even if she be a s≈´dra woman married to a brƒÅhma·πáe ). The Mit. on Yaj. I. 73 quotes a text (of ParƒÅ≈õara X. 26 and Vas. Dh. 8. 21. 15 ) that half of the body of him whose wife drinks surƒÅ is guilty of grave sin'904 (on Yaj III. 256 it is asoribed to Manu ). Vas. Dh. 8. ( 21.11 ) says that & br√§bmapa wife who drinks surƒÅ is not allowed by the gods to reach the world of her husband (after death ) and that she

History of Dharmasastra

( Ch. XXII

wanders in this world as a leech in water or as an oyster. 1805 YƒÅj. III. 256 says the same and adds that such a wife becomes in her subsequent lives a bitch, a vulture or a pig in this world itself,

Visvar≈´pa (on Yaj. I. 140 ) quotes a text that a vendor of liquors is to have a flagstaff at his shop to indicate that it is a liquor shop, that his shop was to be in the midst of the village and that he was not to sell sura to the antyajas except in times of distress ( 1. e, in diseases &o.).1908

Megasthenes ( p. 69 ) and Strabo (XV. 1. 53 ) note that Indians did not drink wine except at sacrifices ( in the 4th century B. C.). Gautama 23.1. Manu XI. 90-91, YƒÅj. III. 253 prescribe that if a person knowingly and frequently drinks sur. i. e. pai≈ütƒ±, he can be purified only by death due to the pouring in his mouth of boiling surƒÅ or water or ghee or cow’s urine or milk. YƒÅj. III. 254 prescribes another prayasoitta (expiation ) also. Vas. Dh. . 20. 19, Manu XI, 146 and YƒÅj. III. 255 prescribe that if any one of the three varnas drinks surƒÅ through ignorance he becomes pure by undergoing the penance of K»ôcobra and by having his upangyang performed again. AparƒÅrka (p. 1070 ) quotes & smsti of KumƒÅrs that a child up to five years has to perform no penance for drinking any intoxioant, that after five but before upanayapa the child’s parents or other relative or friend has to undergo it viz. three krochras. 1907

Manu (VII. 47-52) enumerates in the case of kings ten vices springing from love of pleasure and eight vioes produced by wrath and then states that among vices due to love of pleasure drinking, dice, women and hunting are the worst and that drinking is the most pernicious of all the vices of kings. Kautilya VIII. 3 agrees with this. Gaut. XII. 38 and Y√°j. II. 47 declare that though sons and grandsons are bound to repay their ancestors’ debt as a pious duty, they are not bound to pay

Ch. XXII )

Bhojana

799

debts inourred for liquors, gambling &c. Among the articles that a brƒÅhma·πáa is forbidden to sell even when he is forced to take to trade as a means of livelihood is liquor (Manu X. 89 and YƒÅj. III. 37).

To return to the subject of bhojana. After finishing one’s midday meal, a person was to chew t√¢mbula or mukhavasa ( des cribed above p. 734) and it appears that in ancient times persons smoked also certain preparations made with fragrant berbs and medicaments (and not tobacco which was then unknown). For example, BƒÅ≈Üa describes in the KƒÅdambari ( para 15 ) that king S√£draka after bis mid-day meal took in the smoke of fragrant drugs and then chewed tƒÅmb≈´la. 1908 In the Caraka-sanhita, s≈´tra sthƒÅna chap.5, there is a description how & reed was to be smeared with pastes of sandalwood, nutmeg, cardamom and several other drugs and spices, how it was to be eigbt angulas long and as thick as one’s thumb, how it was to be dried and the reed removed and then the dried portion was to be smoked. Vide Indian Antiquary vol. 40 pp. 37-40 for detailed information.

The Visnupurana III. 11. 94 remarks that after taking the mid-day meal one may do acts that would not cause exertion to the body. Dak≈üa ( II. 68-69 ) says that after109 taking dinner one should sit at ease and allow the food to be digested and should read and listen to itihƒÅsa and purƒÅnas in the 6th and 7th parts of the day, and in the 8th part of the day the bouseholder should look into his private worldly affairs and then perform the evening adoration (eandhyƒÅ) outside the house. That the higher and middle classes of society attended in the afternoon the recitation of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (the itih√§sa par excellence) and the pur√§≈Üas in the 7th century follows from BƒÅna’s state ment in the Kadambari (para 54) that even queen VilƒÅgavati on hearing from the MahƒÅbhƒÅrate that the sonless do not reach heaven (which was recited in the temple of Mab√°kƒÅla at Ujjayini) became so extremely dejected and the fact that BƒÅna

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

[ Ch. XXII

is said in the Har≈üacarita (III) to have listened after the midday meal to the recitation of the VayupurƒÅ≈Üa by the reader Sudrsti. Yaj. ( I. 113-114) directs that the rest of the day (till evening) should be spent in the company of ƒ£istas (learned and respecta ble people) and of dear relatives and then having performed the evening prayer and offered oblations into the three sacred fires (if he has kept the three Vedic fires) or into gƒºhya fire, the householder sbould feed guests if they come at night, then he should take his evening meal surrounded by (bis children) and servants, should not eat too much in the evening and then go to sleep. Daksa ( II. 70-71 ) says that after evening he should perform homa, then take his meal, do other household work, then repeat some part of his Veda and sleep for two watches (six hours) and he should devote some time in the first and last watches of the night to reciting the Veda already learnt.

Numerous rules are laid down in the smrtis and digests about sleeping, viz. as to the position of the head, what kind of bed to use, where to sleep and what texts to recite and so on Vide Gaut. II. 13 and IX. 60, Manu IV, 57, 175-176, YƒÅj. I. 136, Vi≈ünupurƒÅ≈Üa III. 11. 107-109 for some of these rules. Among the earliest works to give elaborate rules is the Vi≈ünu Dh. S. chap. 70, which is set out here. ‘One should not sleep when one’s feet are wet with water, nor should one have his head towards the north and west or lower (than the other parts of the body ), nor should one sleep naked por below a beam along its length nor in an uncovered place nor on a bed-stead of & pal√°sa tree nor on one made of five kinds 1911 of wood nor on one made of trees split by an elephant nor on one made of wood burnt by lightning, nor on a broken bed-stead nor on one which is scorched, nor on a bed of trees watered with jars, nor in cemeteries nor in an unoccupied house, nor in a temple, nor in the midst of rash (or mischievous) persons, nor in the midst of women, nor above grain, nor in a stable of cows nor on the bed-stead of elderly persons nor over a fire or over an idol, nor before washing his hands or lips after meals, nor should one sleep by day nor in the twilight nor on ashes, nor on an unclean spot, nor on a wet spot nor on the top of a mountain.’ Vide

  1. The FTTE. (377. p. 457 ) says ‘90 qrato age TUTY AT’. Tbo . . p. 397 remarks ago 7608-C o r

a ‡§µ ‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ #: fail. Oh. XXII)

Sleep

801

SmrtvarthagƒÅra p. 70, Gr. R. pp. 397-399. Smrtimuktaphala (ahnika pp. 456-458), Abnika-prakasa pp. 556-558 for further details. Some of them may be noted. One should bow to one’s favourite deity and keep a bamboo staff near one’s bed8ys the Sm·ªôtyarthasƒÅra. The Sm·ªôtiratna says that one should not sleep on the same bed with a person suffering from an eye dis ease or with one who is an epileptic or with one suffering from foyer, leprosy, tuberculosis, asthma and hiccough. The Ratn√°vali (quoted in Sm. M. abnika p. 457) requires that one should place & jar full of water at the head of the bed-stead, recite Vedio mantras for one’s protection and mantras against poison and also the hymn to Night (Rg. X. 127), remember the five ancient personages well-known as sound sleepers, ‘918 viz. Agasti, M√§dbava, Mucakunda, Kapila and Astrka, salute Vi≈ünu and then go to sleep. Harita (prose) quoted in ƒÄbnikaprakƒÅ≈õa p. 557 oontains similar rules. V»õddha-H√§rita (VIII. 309-310) says that an ascetic, a brahmac√•rl, a forest hermit and a widow should not sleep on a cot but on the ground covered over with a deer skin or a blanket or with ku≈°as.

In connection with the subject of going to bed at night, a good deal is stated in the smrtis and digests about sexual inter course between husband and wife. Some of these rules ( viz. about the proper days for intercourse) have already been stated above (pp. 204-205). Gaut. V.1-2 and IX. 28-29, Ap. Dh.S. II.1.1, 16‚Äì23 lay down that a householder is to approach his wife on the proper days or he may do so at any time except on forbidden days or when the wife desires it; he is not to bave intercourse during day-time or when the wife is ill, nor when she is in her courses nor should he embrace her during that period, Ap. Dh, S. II. 1. 1. 19, Vas.‘1% Db. S. XII. 24 and Yaj. I. 81 refer to the boon conferred on women by Indra scoording to a legend narrated in the Tal. 8. II. 5. 1. When Indra killed Vi≈°var≈´pa, son of Tvastf, he incurred the sin of brƒÅhma·πáa murder; all beings loudly condenaned him as ‘brahmahan’, and he went about the universo in search of sharers in his sin, of which one third was

  1. Uri nga golat PTTPOTH Faure a dreniran ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§™‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ö ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡•§ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§•: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§∑‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã AETTEI I Tuoi farefirent sitat gairfa: Il fafa. . D. 101

History of Dharmasastra

[ Oh, XXII

taken by the earth (which seoured the boon that when a pit is dug it becomes filled up in a year), one-third by trees (that got the boon that even when pruned they would grow again and the exudation from trees is the part of brahmahalyƒÅ that comes out of trees and the red resins exuded are therefore not to be eaten) and one third by women, who got the boon that they would conceive only during their period (of sixteen days) after the recurring occurrence of menses and that they might indulge in intercourse till the time of delivery and in the case of whom the murder is manifested every month. 1914 Vi≈ünu Dh. S. chap. 69 puts all rules together, some of which are: A householder must avoid sexual intercourse after having been invited at a grƒÅddha or having partaken of dinner at it or after having given a & gr√§ddba dinner or after performing the initiatory ceremony of soma sacrifice; he must not have intercourse in a temple, in a cemetery, in an empty house or at the root of a tree, in the day time 18 or at twilight, or with a woman older than himself or with a pregnant woman or with one who has a limb too much or is deficient in a limb. Vide Vis≈ÜupurƒÅ≈Üa III. 11. 110-123 for similar rules on the same topic. Most of the rules are eugenic or based on hygiene, though a few may be held to be only religious or superstitious. Gaut. IX. 26, Ap. Dh. S. II. 1. 1. 21-23 and II. 1. %. 1, Manu IV. 4 and V, 144 say that after intercourse the husband and wife should take a bath or at least wash, sip water and sprinkle water over the body and should sleep on separate beds. Other writers stated different views, 1916

Rajasvala-dharmƒÅ·∏•. From the times of the Tal. 8. rules have been laid down about the duties of a rajasvalƒÅ (& woman in her monthly illness) and about how her husband and other people are to act

Ch. XXII)

Rules about Rajasvala

803

towards her. In the Tai, S. II. 5. 1. it is stated 1917 ‘One should not address a woman who has unolean clothes (i. e. who is in her course) nor should one sit with her, one should not eat her food for she keeps emitting the colour of brƒÅhma·πáa murder; they say woman’s food is unguent, therefore one should not accept unguent from her; but anything else at will may be accepted’. The Tai. Br. III. 7. 1 states ‘Indeed half of this sacrifice is destroyed in the case of him whose wife becomes un. touchable on the day on which the observances for & sacrifice commence (i. e. on the day previous to the performance); but the sacrificer should segregate her (in a different place or house) and offer the sacrifice; by so doing he worships with a sacrifice that is entire (though the wife is absent).“1918 The adhikarana in Jaimini (III. 4. 18-19) is based on these texts; Sabara’s bhƒÅ≈üya quotes the passage of the Tai. S. and of the Tai. Br. and the conclusion established is that these rules, though occurring in the context of the new moon and full moon sacrifices, are not restricted to those sacrifices, but are to be observed by per sons generally (i. e. they are puru≈üƒÅrtha and not kratvartha). The Tai. S. II. 5.1 contains thirteen directions about a rajasvalƒÅ and deolares what evil results follow from breaches of them. They are: there is to be no intercourse with her, nor in a forest (after she bathes), nor when she is unwilling (after bath ), she should not bathe during the three days, should not bathe with oil in those days, should not arrange her hair with a comb, should not apply collyrium to her eyes, should not brush her teeth, should not pare her nails, should not spin yarn, should not make ropes, should not drink water with a vessel made of palƒÅsa leaves or & vessel that is baked in fire (or is broken). The results of the breaches are respectively that the son ( born of her) becomes suspected or charged with grave sins, a thief, shy and not bold, destined to die in water, has a skin disease,

Babara on Jaimini III. 4.19 says that the words ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ñ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Öh really enjoin the probibition of approaching her for intercourse and the Tantravartika (p. 952) offers the interesting information that among the Latas “abhya√±jana’ is a synonym for sexual intercourse’ aur ft Flataracak ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§Æ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXII

has a bald head and is feeble, is squint-eyed, has dark teeth, has bad nails, is impotent, is unrestrained (or commits suicide by hanging), becomes a lunatio, or a dwarf. The Tai. S. further direots that she should observe these rules for three nigbta, should drink water with her hands joined together or with a plate that is not baked in fire. The B·πõ, Up. VI. 4. 13 notes that a married woman in her courses should drink water from & vessel of bronze and should not wash her olothes, a s√ºdra male or female should not touch her; on the lapse of three nights she should bathe and she should be made to unhusk rice. Many of the g≈´tras refer to the rules contained in the Tai, S. about the rajasvala (vide Ap. gp. 8. 12,1919 Hir. gs. I. 24. 7, Bhar. gƒº. I. 20, Baud. gr. I. 7. 22-36, Baud. Dh. S. 1. 5. 139 ). Vas. Dh. S. V. 7-9 con tains the story of Indra and the boon given to women and also the rules about rajasvalƒÅ (adding that she should sleep on the ground, should not sleep by day, should not eat flesh, should not look at the planets, should not laugh). When Vas. Dh. 8. V. 8. and Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. 8. 51. 16 forbid the eating of the food of & rajasvali, what is meant is (according to the Gr. R. and other digests) that the food cooked for her or owned by her should not be eaten. Laghu-Harita 38 prescribes that a rajasvalƒÅ may eat food from her own band used as a plate; V·πõddba-H√§rita (XI. 210-11) says the same and adds that if she be a widow, then she should not take food for three days and that one whose husband is living should have only one meal a day. Rajasvala women were also not to touch one another. Vi≈ü≈Üu Dh. S. (22. 73-74) prescribes that if & rajasvala touches another rajasvalƒÅ of lower var & she should observe a fast from that time till the fourth day when she takes the purificatory bath; while if she touches another rajasvala woman of the same varpa or higher varna, she has to bathe and then take her food. More elaborate rules are laid down by Angiras 48 ( who proscribes pa√±cagavya), Atri 279-283, Ap. (verse) VIL. 20-22, B»ôhad-Yana III. 64-68, Par√°sara VII. 11-15. If & rajasvala is touched by a cƒÅ≈Üd√°la or by any of the antyajas, or by a dog or grow, she has to be without food till she bathes on the 4th day (Angiras 47, Atri 277-279, Apastamba VII. 5-8). If a woman is suffer ing from fever and becomes a rajasvala she is not to be bathed

  1. 9 THT: F √ºat nutraforata for mer opf MYTHHT THAT I WT4. V. . 8. 12. The wholo of Vas. Db. 8. V. 7-9 is quoted in T. I. PP. 406-407 and Vas. Dh. 8.V.1 is quoted by faite on a. III 20 and to p. 106.

Oh. XXII)

Rules about Raj asvala

805

on the 4th day to purify her; her purification is to be effected by another healthy woman, who touches her and then herself bathes with her clothes on and this is done te n or twelve times and each time there is sipping of water; then the woman who is ill has her clothes removed and new ones put on and then gifts are made according to ability and she becomes pure (Uganas quoted in Mit. on Y√°j. III. 20). Similar verses occur in Angiras 22-23. The same procedure is followed where & male who is ill is touched by a rajasvalƒÅ or for some other cause he has to undergo the purification of a bath, viz. a healthy male touches him geven or ten times and bathes after each touob, at the end of whioh the sickly person is to be declared to be free from the impurity (Angiras 21, ParƒÅ≈õard VII, 19-20 quoted in Mit. on Yaj. III. 20). If a rajasvalƒÅ dies, then the corpse should be bathed with the five products of the cow (pancagavya), she should be covered with another garment and then should be cremated (& Verse quoted by the Mit, on YƒÅj. III. 20), while Angiras (42) said that the corpse should be bathed after three days and then it should be oromated. The Mit on YƒÅj. III. 20 notes that, if & woman who usually has monthly periods, men struates within seventeen days, then she has no impurity; if on the 18th, she becomes clean in one day, if on the 19th in two days and thereafter in three days. Vide Angiras 43, Apastamba (verse) VII. 2, ParƒÅgara VII. 16-17.

So far we have desoribed the daily duties of common men, particularly of brƒÅhmanas. Manu VII. 145-147, 151-154, 216-226, Yaj. I. 327-333 and Kaut. I. 19 dilate upon the daily duties of the king. Kaut divides day and night into eight parts each and states that in the first part of the day the king should take measures for his protection and attend to income and expenditure, in the second he should look into the causes (or disputes ) of the people of the cities and villages, in the third he should bathe, study or recite the Veda and take his meals, in the fourth he should receive revenue in gold and appoint (or examine) superintendents; in the fifth he should correspond with the council of ministers, and receive the secret news brought by his spies; in the sixth he may engage in what ever amusements or sports he likes or in deliberation (on state matters); in the seventh he should review elephants, horses, chariots and soldiers; in the eighth he should consider with the help of his commander-in-chief plans of campaigns. When the day ends he should observe the evening prayer; in the first part

806

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

[Ch. XXII

bathe 8 secret

should

of the night, he should see secret emissaries, in the second part of the night he may bathe, revise his studies and take supper; in the third he should lie down after the burst of trumpets and sleep in the fourth and fifth; in the 6th he should be awakened by the sound of trumpets, he should bring to his mind the dictates of s√§stra and the mode of carrying them out; in the seventh he should deliberate and send out secret omissaries; in the eighth he should receive, being accompanied by his sacrifi. cial priests, acƒÅrya and purohita, benedictions and should see his physioian, chief cook and astrologer and having circumambu. lated a cow with her calf and a bull he should go to court. Or the king may divide the parts of day time and night time according to his capacity. Other sm·ªôtik√§ras differed here and there. KatyƒÅyana prescribed 1920 that the king should devote the three parts of the day time (divided into eight) after the first part to judicial work and if he cannot personally do it, he should appoint & judge. YƒÅj. (I. 327-333) mostly follows (though concisely ) the routine sketched by Kaut. The Manusmrti also hardly adds anything of importance to what we find in Kaut. It is remarkable that in the DasakumƒÅra-oarita (ucchrƒÅsa VIII) the author closely following the words of Kautilya as to the engagements of the king during the eight parts of daytime and of night also puts in the mouth of the voluptuous jester VibƒÅrabhadra & parody of Kautilya’s solemn dicta. 1921

As to the ahnika of vaisyas and s≈´dras no special rules are laid down in the smrtis. They had to adjust the duties set out for brƒÅhma·πáas to their own case according to their circumstances. A vaisya belonged to the twice-born classes and he could do if he chose almost every thing that a brƒÅhmana could (except officiating as a priest or teaching as a profession or receiving gifts ). Vide pp. 154-164 for the disabilities and the few privileges of the s≈´dra,

  1. Vide note 1610 above. 1921. e.g. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ö ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø

Hrafta VIII.

CHAPTER XXIII

UPƒÄKARMA OR UPƒÄKARANA AND

UTSARJANA OR UTSARGA.

ning (upakran Asv. g!. III. 3:in the year. Ap.

UpƒÅkarma or UpƒÅkarana means ‘opening, starting or begin. ning’ (upakrama as the Mit. on Y√°j. I, 142 says) and Utsarjana or Utsarga (in A≈õv. gƒº, III. 5. 13) means ‘the cessation of Vedio studies for a certain period in the year.’ Ap. gr. VIII. 1 and Ap. Dh S. I. 3. 11. % employ the word ‘samƒÅpana’ for utsarjana. In former times these two rites were performed on different dates and in different months, but with the decline of vedio studies in medieval times they came to be performed one after another on the same day. In several s√§tras the first of these two is spoken of as adhyayop√§karspa (as in ƒÄ≈õv. gr. III. 5. 1.) or adhyiyopƒÅkarma (in P√°r. gs. II. 10, Vas. Dh. S. 13. 1). In this case adhyƒÅya means study of the Veda’ or it may mean Veda itself because it is studied (pre-eminently). Therefore the rite which signalises the opening of the session for Vedic study in the year is itself called up√•karma.1997 In Gaut. 16. I the rite of upƒÅkarmu is called v√¢r»ôika either because it took place in varsƒÅ (the rainy season) or because it took place once a year (from varsa, a year). The ƒÄ≈õv. gr. III. 5. 19 also states that this rite is oalled vƒÅr≈üika.

The time for upakarma is variously stated in the s√§tras, The ƒÄ≈õv. gr. III. 5. 2-3 states when the herbs appear, when the moon is in conjunction with the constellation of Sravana, in the month of Sr√•va≈Üa or on the 5th (tithi) of Sr√§vang when the moon is in the Hasta nak≈üatra. “1913 The

History of Dharmasastra

(Ch, XXIII

P√•r. gr. II. 10 says ‘when the herbs appear, when the moon is in conjunction with Sravana on the full moon day in the month of Sr√§vana or on the fifth of the month of Sr√°vans when the moon is in Hasta.’ Gaut. 16. 1 and Vas. Dh. 8. 13. 1 require that it should be performed on the full moon day of Srivana or Bhadrapada. The KhƒÅdira gf. (III. 2. 14-15) and Gobhila III. 3. 1 and 13 ordain that Upakarma should be performed on the full moon day of Bhadrapada or under the constellation of Hasta in that month or according to some on the full moon day of SrƒÅvana. The Baud. gr. III. 1. % prescribes that Upakarma may be done on the full moon day of ≈ör√§vana or A≈üadha. The Hir. gr. (II. 18. 2, S. B. E. vol. 30 p. 241) says ‘during the fortnight (at the end of which) the full moon of Sr√§vana ocours, when the herbs have sprouted forth, the ceremony for the open ing of the annual Veda study ( should be performed ) under the Hasta oonstellation or on the full moon day’. The Ap. Dh. S. I. 3.9.1 speaks only of the full moon day of Sr√•vans as the time for the performance of the Upakarma rite. Manu. IV. 95 prescribes the full moon of Sravana or Bhadrapada as the time for up√•karma. Yaj. I. 142 provides three times viz. on the full moon day of Sriva≈Üa or on a day (in Sr√•vapa).when the moon is in conjunction with the Sravana nak≈üatra or on the 5th tithi of ≈ör√•va≈Üa if the moon is in conjunction with Hasta. The K≈´rmapurƒÅ≈Üa (Uttar√§rdha 14. 60-61 ) holds that Upakarma should be performed on the full moon day of either SrƒÅvana, ƒÄ≈üƒÅdha or Bradrapada. In this rather bewildering variety of opinions oommentators like the Mit. prescribed that one should follow one’s gphyasutra.‘¬∞* This means ( as stated by Medhatithi on Manu IV.95 ) that the full moon of Bhadrapada being mentioned by Gobhila gr. and KhƒÅdira g≈Ç. Chandogas (students of the S√§maveda ) should perform upakarma on that day; but as Ap. Dh. 8. speaks only of the full moon of SrƒÅvana, the followers of the Krsna Yajurveda should perform upakarma only that day. When there is no rain and so no herbs appear in Sr√•vapa or when that day is inauspicious owing to an eclipse or the like, Upakarma may be performed on the full moon day of Bhadrapada by those whose grhys a≈≠tra allows

students of these by Gobhila hat the full moc

Oh. XXIII )

U pakarma or upakarana

809

the option of two months or on the fifth of the bright half of ≈örƒÅvana. But if both days of the full moon in the two months are inauspicious, then Up√§karma should be performed on the full moon of SrƒÅvana. As the Baud. gr. refers to the full moon of A≈üƒÅdha, the followers of the Black Yajurveda may perform up√§karma on ƒÄsƒÅdha full moon, if the full moon of SrƒÅvana is not available. But the students of the Rgveda cannot do so, since no sutra of the Rgveda speaks of AsƒÅdha 88 an optional month. Rgvedins have to prefer Sravana bak≈üatra (so that they may perform upakarma on the 14th or 15th of the bright half of Sr√§vana ); the followers of the Yajurveda (Sukla ) must perform it on the full moon day of ≈ör√°vana when the moon is in ≈öravana nak≈üatra, but if the moon is not so, then they have to prefer the full moon day. The students of the Taittiriya gƒÅkh√• also have to follow this last course. The followers of the SƒÅmaveda should prefer Hasta. Vide Sam. Pr. pp. 497-498, Sm. M. pp. 32-33, Nirn, pp. 114-120. Some interpreted Yaj. I. 142 in such a way as to yield four times for upƒÅkarma, viz. the full moon of SrƒÅvana, the day in SrƒÅvana on which the moon is in conjunction with Sravana nak≈üatra ( this may sometimes be the 14th tithi of the bright half ), or on the 15th of the bright half of ≈örƒÅvana or on that day in SrƒÅvana when the moon is in Hasta. Why so much importance was attached to the month of SrƒÅvana and to the constellation of Sravans as the season for starting Veda study is obscure. It is possible that that month was originally chosen as owing to showers of rain it is pleasantly cool, there is more leisure and staying inside the house in that month for brƒÅhma·πáas than in other months of the year and then Nature is at its best. The month of Sr√°va≈Üa being fixed upon, the best day therein would be the full moon (Soma in another sense being the king of br√°bma≈Üas ). If any other day in Sr√§vana was to be chosen then the day on which the moon was in Hasta would be the best, which would ordinarily be the 5th of the bright half (of SrƒÅvana). As the Paur≈ÜamƒÅs√≠ of that month was called SrƒÅvani owing to the moon’s conjunction with the Sravana naksatra ( which conjunc

tion usually takes place on that day) the Sravana nak≈üatra came to be associated with the starting of the annual session of Vedio studies. But that the Sravana naksatra by itself bad no direct connection with upƒÅkarma is clear from the fact that several s≈´tras do not mention it at all. The Gobbila and KhƒÅdira gr. do not accept the full moon day of SrƒÅvana ( but of Bhadrapada and the Hasta naksatra ) as the proper time for upakarma.

810

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra (Ch. XXIII

Oldenberg in his note on san, gr. IV. 5. % when the herbs appear, under the nak≈üatra Hasta or Sravana’( S. B. E. vol. 29, P. 112 ) remarks ‘the naksatra Sravana is evidently considered 88 particularly fit for this occasion because of its name contain ing an allusion to ≈õruti’. But this conjecture has no plausibi. lity. Hardly any ancient writer makes the suggestion that Sravana and Sruti are brought together on account of the root ‘≈õru’. The presiding deity of Hasta is Savitr. Owing to the supreme importance given to the GƒÅyatri verse (of which Savity is the deity ) and to the fact that Veda study begins with the recitation of the Gayatri, the nak≈üatra Hasta would be closely connected with the starting of Veda study. As a matter of fact the San. gr. IV. 5.2 mentions Hasta first and then ≈öravana; the Hir. gg. does not name the Sravana naksatra at all, but names Hasta in this connection; while the ƒÄ≈õv. gr., P√°r. gr. and several others mention both Sravana and Hasta.

. are brought together as the suggestion that

‘≈õru’. The n

UpƒÅkarma is to be done in the morning. If for part of the day, the moon is in conjunction with UttarƒÅ≈üadhƒÅ and then with Sravana that day is not to be chosen for upƒÅkarma, but the next day is to be chosen on which the moon is in conjunction with Sravana and Dhani≈üthƒÅ. Later writers introduced further complications about the zodiacal sign (rƒÅ≈õi) in which the Sun would be at the time. Garga required that upƒÅkarma must be performed during the days when the Sun was in the sign of Leo by the followers of the SƒÅmaveda and by those who are to the north of the Narmada river. There is no upƒÅkarma in the intercalary month of SrƒÅvana and Bhadrapada except for the followers of the SƒÅmaveda who must perform it in the inter calary month. When upƒÅkarma is to be done for the first time after a boy’s upanayana, the planets Jupiter and Venus must not be in the position of asta ( i. e. invisibility owing to their being too near the sun).

Upakarma is to be done by brahmacƒÅrins, by householders and also by vƒÅnaprasthas ( forest hermits). The teacher does it in the company of his pupils whether they be brahmac√°rins or not and performs the homa in his own gƒºhya fire, as the P√§r. gr. II, 10 says. Karka the com. of P√§r. gr. states that if the ƒÅcƒÅrya has no pupils then he has no adhik√§ra ( right or eligibi. lity ) to perform the upakarma in the gƒºhya fire, while Harihara says that the practice of performing upakarma in the ordinary

Ch. XXIII

Upakarma or upƒÅkara√±a

811

domestic fire in the company of a Veda student is based on no authority, but is a mere usage. 1935

The procedure of upƒÅkarma is set out as followg1988 in the A≈õv. gr. (III. 5. 4-12): ‘having sacrificed the two ≈´jyabhƒÅgas 1927 (portions of clarified butter), he should offer oblations of ajya to the following deities, viz. I. 1, 1),1948 and ‘the Ku≈üumbhaka bas said it’ (Rg. I. 191. 16), ‘O bird, when crying announce welfare to us’ (Rg. II. 43.3), *Sung by Jamadagni’(Rg. III. 62. 18), ‘In thy abode the whole world rests’ (Rg. IV.58, 11), ‘you ( Maruts ) that deserve sacri fice, come to our sacrifice’ (Rg. V. 87.9), ‘whosoever whether ours or a stranger ( Rg. VI. 75, 19), ‘look towards us, look in various directions’ (Rg. VII. 101.25 ), ‘Come here, O Agni, the friend of the Maruta’ ( Rg. VIII, 103. 14), ‘O king, the oblation that is cooked for thee’ (Rg. The ƒÄp. gƒº. (VIII. 1-2) is very brief and states that at the opening and conoluding rites of Vedic study that R≈üi who is indicated as the R»ôi of the KƒÅ≈Üda ( section of the Tai. S.) to be studied is the deity to whom the rite belongs and in the second place Sadasaspati is the deity. Sudar≈õapƒÅcƒÅrya explains 1933 these two s≈´tras at great length. Briefly what he means is : the commencement (up√§karma ) of the study of the whole Veda (Black Yajurveda) is to be done on the full moon day of ≈örƒÅvana, tarpana is to be done for nine R≈üis and pine oblations of ≈´jya are to be offered to these nine, the ninth being offered with the verse ‘sadagaspatim’ (Rg. I. 18. 6 = ƒÄp. M. P. I. 9,8). But when a KƒÅnda is to be begun that is another up√§karma and a homs is to be performed in respect of it also.

Gradually many accretions were made to the simple upa karma rite given in the ƒÄ≈õv. gr. and other gƒºhya s≈´tras. In modern times upakarma is & most elaborate matter. That of Rgvedins may be briefly described here ; After acamana, pr≈´pƒÅyƒÅma and reference to time and place, a sankalpa is made

The method of offering thoso oblations is first to inention the sago, the deity and metre of the verse and then to state tho purpose of its omployment in the rite, then to repeat the whole verse proooded by om and followed by svƒÅhi and then to put tho oblation on to firo, e.g. sferat fut a rengti 791 teret for ‡§™‡•ã‡§ó‡§É‡•§ ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§≠‡§®‡§∑‡§¶‡•á V RU I

Ch. XXIII

Upakarma or upakarana

815

and make others repeat om’, vy√§hrtis and GƒÅyatri thrice, then brahmayaj√±a and then saying upƒÅk≈ôtƒÅ vai vedƒÅ·∏•' (the study of the Vedas has been begun), then the acƒÅrya finishes the rest of the rite such as prƒÅyasoitta, then all resolve to feed brahma≈Üas and give dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ according to ability. The ƒÅcƒÅrya takes leave of the fire, bows to Vi≈ü≈Üu and sips water twice.

The gƒºhyas≈´trag prescribe a holiday (anadhyƒÅya ) after the performance of upƒÅkarma, though the duration varieg. Par. gs. II. 10 prescribes that he should not study the Veda for three days and nights and should not clip his nails or shave for that period and points out that some said that he should not clip nails or hair till the date of utsarjana ( i. e. for 5 months and a half). SƒÅn, gf. IV. 5. 17 (=Manu IV. 119) presoribes an anadhyƒÅya ( holiday ) for three nights on upƒÅkarma and utsarga. Gobhila gr. (III. 3. 9 and 11 ) says that there is no study on the upƒÅkarma day performed on Hasta nak≈üatra and that according to some teachers for three days before it and after it. The Bh√§r. gr. III. 8 enjoins that after upakarma there should be a holiday of three days or one day and for one month thereafter one should not study the Veda in the evening (i. e, the first watch after sunset).

Utsarjana:- About the time of utsarjana also there was divergence of view. The Baud. gr. (1.5.163 ) prescribes that it may be performed on the full moon day of Pau≈üe or Magha. ƒÄ≈õv.gr.(III.5.14) requires Veda study after upakarma for six months and so if the up√§karma was performed on tbe new moon of SrƒÅvana the utgarjana according to it would be on the full moon of M√§gha ( vide III. 5. 20 also ). The P√§r. gr. II. 11 states that after having studied the Veda for five months and a half or for six months and a half they (teacher and pupils ) should per form utsarga (1. e. the rite of closing the course of Vedic study). These periods are only approximate, since PƒÅr. gs. II. 12 further on says that utsarjana should be performed in the month of Paupa when the moon is in the Rohi≈Üi nak≈üatra ( i. e. about the eleventh of the bright half ) or in middle A≈ütakƒÅ (1. e. 8th of the dark half of Pausa ). The Gobhila gr. III. 3. 14 says that utsarga is performed on the full moon of Taisa ( i. e. Pausa ), while the Khadira gr. III. 2. 24 says that having studied the Veda for four months and a half they close the session on the full moon day of Pau≈üa, The S√§n. gr. IV. 6. 1 holds that utsar jana should be performed on the first day of the bright half of Magha ; Yaj. I. 143 follows P√§r. gr. II. 12 by saying that

TT 5.14) requires vous performed ontbeno full moon

half they clor. 6. 16 holds the theatre

816

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

[ Ch. XXIII

utsarga takes place in Pau≈üa on the Rohini naksatra or on the 8th of the dark half, while Manu ( IV, 95-96 ) says that after studying Veda for four months and a half from up√•karma, utsarga should take place when the moon is in the Pu≈üya naksatra thereafter or on the first day of the bright half of MƒÅgha. The MƒÅnava gr. I. 4.7 says that Veda study is stopped 41 or 5 or 5} months after upakarma. These several periods ( 4 months, or 51 months or 6 months ) and the various dates of utsarga in Pau≈üa or MƒÅgha were due to the fact that upƒÅkarma may take place on the full moon day of SrƒÅvana or Bhadrapada (or even Asadha) or on the 5th of the bright half of Sr√§vana or on Hasta in Bhadrapada or SrƒÅyapa.

The A≈õv. gr. III. 5. 13 extends the procedure of upƒÅkarma to utsarga and adds (III. 5. 20-22) that offerings of boiled rice are made to the same deities instead of clarified butter, then they take a bath and perform tarpans of thoge very deities and of ƒÅcƒÅryas, √Æ≈üis and pit?s (as in brahmayajƒÅa ). NƒÅrƒÅyana states that in utsarjana there is no eating (of barley late with ourds ) as there is in upƒÅkarma nor mƒÅrjana. Par. gr. II. 12 gives the procedure of utsarjana as follows: “They ( teacher and pupils ) should go to the brink of water ( a river &c.) and offer oblations of water ( i. e. tarpana ) to the gods, to the metres, to the Vedas, ƒ´sis, the ancient teachers, the Gandha. Ivas, the other teachers, the year with its divisions, the Pitrs, ƒÅcƒÅryas, their ( deceased) relatives. After having rapidly recited the S√§vitri four times, they should utter loudly' we have stopped (Vedio study ).' There is anadhyƒÅya in utsarjana for the same period as on upakarma and they should then continue the repeti. tion (of the Veda ) as before”. The Gobhila gr. III. 3. 15 says about utsarjana ‘they go out of the village turning their faces to the east or north, they should approach water that is deeper than their waist, should bathe therein and should offer tarpana to the vedas, ƒº≈üis and √£oƒÅryas.’ A holiday was observed on the day of utsarjana for a day and half (pak≈üi≈Üi) or three days after it (Manu IV. 97, Y√°j. I. 144 ).
