( Ch. XXX

me from bad sacrifice (or & ourse); may Savity save me from him who speaks evil of me. May I vanquish him who, whether far or near, is my enemy!’ (Tai. 8. 1. 6. 2. 4). Jai. VI. 4. 3 lays down that if after portions are out for Svi≈ütakit as directed they are destroyed accidentally, there is no fresh outting for Svistak≈ôt again.

The adhvaryu comes back to the north of the vedi from the spot where he offered to Svi≈ütakst, fills the juh≈´ with water and pours it round the paridhis (or their places) beginning from the middle one and proceeding from left to right with ‘I offer this offering into Vai≈°vƒÅnara, it is a spring with a hundred or a thousand streams. May he support in this that is being filled, my father, grandfather and great-grandfather’ (Tai. A, VI. 6 ) and then touobes water. The sacrifioer makes the tyaga with ‘this is for (my) father &c.’ and then touches water. The adhvaryu lays down the two sruos in their proper places. Then he tears the surface (or top) of the purodƒÅsa meant for Agni from west to east, inserts his thumb and the anƒÅmika (ring finger) and takes out from inside the cake a portion which is as much as a barley grain or the pippala 8381 berry with ‘let this be cut off, somewhat bigger than a barley grain or than the wound made by an arrow. May we not injure this boly and well-offered havis of the sacrifice’ (Tal. Br. III. 7.5). He takes off a portion from the other purod√°sa also in the same way but without piercing the top. These portions are called prasitrs. The brabma priest looks at the prasitra when it is being taken out with ‘I look at thee with the eye of Mitra’ (A√∏v, I. 13. 1). The adhvaryu sprinkles clarified butter on the vessel called pra≈°itrabarana (that in which prasitra is carried ), keeps the pra≈°itra in it and sprinkles ajya over it ( does abhighƒÅra≈Üa ), takes it to the east of the ahavaniya by the space between the brahmƒÅ and yajam√§na on one hand and the dhavaniya on the other and then lays it down to the west

The adhvaryu then sprinkles ajya in the idƒÅpƒÅtra, he cuts off the first portion of ida from the southern half of the purodƒÅsa meant for Agni with ‘from the southern half I out off (ida) seen by Manu, from whose foot ghee oozes, that is moved by Mitra and Varuna, that has a face in one direction only (in the south), without mixing it with others’ 1382 (Tai. Br. III. 7. 5). From the eastern half of the same purodƒÅsa he outs off a thin but long slice which is the portion of the yajamƒÅna (according to Baud. I. 18 it is three or four angulas long ) and which is anointed (or smeared) with ajya and placed near the dhruv√° (or to the east of the dhruva ) in some vessel on the barhis. Then he outs off a part from the portion of the cake that is between its southern and eastern parts. In the same way (i. e. repeating the Verse ‘seen by Manu’ &c.) he cuts off & portion as id√° from the northern purodƒÅ≈õa and other things offered (such as. the boiled milk and ourds ). He then sprinkles ajya over the out portions and removes them towards the east on the vedi. He crosses to the south in front of the botƒô, site bebind the hots with his face to the east and anoints the front two joints of the fore-finger of the hotr with djya from the sruva, first the front joint and then the one next to it. The hotr wipes with the palm of the hand turned towards his chest the uppermost joint of the finger on the upper lip and the next joint on his lower lip with ‘I partake of thee that art sacrificed by the lord of speech for food, for prƒÅna’ and ‘I partake of thee that are offered by the lord of the mind for strength, for apana’ respectively ( A≈°v. I. 7, 1-%; compare Sat. Br. I. 8. 1.14-15). He touches water. The sdhvaryu turns from right to left, comes back to the place whence he went, sits down to the east of the hots with his face

  1. The word ‘ida’ is the appellation of a devate and secondarily applies to sacrificial materials and also to a rito. ‘Tara TATTI werefter I com. on Sat. II. 3, p. 207. Ap. III, 1. 1 employs ida and prasitra in the sense of rites. Tho i·ªùapatra is made of asvattba wood, bas a bowl four engulas wide and is as long as the foot of tho sacrificor and has a rod four abgulas long. Accordiog to ƒÄp. III. 1. 7 and Baud. Plenty of rice is cooked on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire. This is called anvƒÅhƒÅrya. The adhvaryu sprinkles ajya over 1390 it (i. e. performs abbighƒÅrapa ) and takes it from the dak≈üi≈Üa fire to the north of it. He issues & direction to the yajamƒÅna ‘offer (the boiled rice ) to the priests that sit to the south’ and when the sacrificer says ‘come to the south’ the priests do as requested ( i. e. come to the south). The yajamƒÅns issues a direction to the four priests ‘this boiled rice is yours, take it according to your shares’. The rice is divided into four parts and the priests accept their respective portions with ‘I accept thee at the impulse of God Savitr ……… with the hands of P√º≈üan; may king Varuna take you. Who gave to whom? Desire ( Kama) bas given to K√§mna …… O K√§ma, this is thy fee. May Angsrasa with upturned palm accept it’ (the whole formula occurs in Ap. XIV. 11.2).2391 The priests come back to the north (and then brahmƒÅ comes to his usual seat). The adhvaryu keeps aside the remnants of the several offerings (such as the agni≈üomlya oako or sƒÅnnayya ) and of the boiled rice outside the vedi to its north.

He throws into the Abavaniya the two blades that are now kindled at the fire and had been kept aside (vide p. 1040 above). The adhvaryu says to the brahmƒÅ priest ‘O brahmanl we shall start or commence (Tai. 8. II. 6. 9. 1). History of Dharmasastra

[ Oh. XXX

each case with & prayer noted below.1885 After keeping the Jub≈© in some spot on the vedi other than where the prastara is, the adhvaryu, baviog mixed the prastars with the two vidh·ªãtis ( vide above p. 1045 ) with ‘may heaven and earth be of the same mind; may Mitra and Varu≈Üa help you with rain’ he leaves the vidhrtis on the barbis and smears the prastara ( with the remnants of ajya ) in the three ledles ( sruc), the points in jub√ª with ‘lioking the one that is smeared’ (Tai. The adhvaryu takes the prastara ( and also the sƒÅkha i. e. twig used at the time of milking cows when s√•nnayya is to be offered ), introduces the prastara (together with the twig) at the corner in the north where the middle and northern paridhis meet and says ' a3trƒÅvaya.’ When the dgnidbra responds with

Darsap√ºrnamƒÅsa-SuktavƒÅka

1073

wbich is given below.1896 The contents of the s√ªktavaka may be briefly indicated. He begins ‘O heaven and earth, this bliesful event has taken place; we have so flourished as to pronounce the good words (viz. ‘fire has aocepted this havis &o.') and our adoration (to the gods); o fire, you should deol√∏re good words, so that we may feel elevated; thou art the declarer of good words.’ Thon numerous words follow that state the various attributes of heaven and earth. Then it is declared that Agni and other deities ( named) have accepted the offering and made it flourish. Then the sacrificer is named and it is said that he hopes for various blessings such as long life, worthy sons. The whole is concluded with ‘we men belong to Agni. May we have (the fruits of ) eacrifice and wealth.

May both heaven and earth save us from sin (or evil). May the most desirable thing come here. Here is adoration to the gods.’ After the b≈´ktavƒÅka the adhvaryu throws upon the ahavaniya the prastara (and the sakha, in case of sannayya) with ‘alay waters and plants be strengthened; you are the

[ Ch. XXX

drops of Maruts ; go to heaven and send thence rain to us’ (Tai. 8. I. 1. 13. 1).” Jaimini makes it clear (VI. 4. 43-47 ) tbat sakbƒÅ is not a subordinate complement of the prastara but the real meaning of the text’he throws the prastara with the bakba’ is to indicate the time when the sakha is to be thrown into fire. Jaimini (IV. 2. 10-13 ) states that the throwing of the gakba into fire is pratipattikarma ( i.e. that is the final disposal of the sƒÅkha ). When throwing the prastara he does not bend his hand but holds it rather straight and hanging downwards and the tips of the prastars are not put beyond the fire nor are they turned upwards, nor are the tips allowed to be first acorohed. He raises it up, brings it slowly down and rolls it on the hearth of the ahavaniya (making the upper portion come down and vice versa). The adhvaryu, when the hotf says ‘this sacrificer seeks ( hopes for ) blessings’ directs the agnidhra to consign the prastara to fire. The √•gnidbra tbrice raises with bis joined hands the prastara into the &bavaniya fire. The sacrificer makes the ty√§ga to the several deities mentioned in the s≈´ktavƒÅka (agnaya idam, somƒÅyedam &o.) and adds (Tai. S. I. 6. 4. 1)‘may I win victory following the victory of Agni’ (then of Soma and so on for the other deities ). 1400 When the bots mentions the name of the sacrificer the latter recites “these blessings have come here’ (Tai, 8. 1. 6. 4.% and Ap. IV. 12. 5). The adhvaryu directe the agnidhra to throw into fire on the prastara the blade of kuga taken from the prastara and kept aside ( as described above p. 107) and tbe √§gnidbra 3401 does so with ‘Good speed to the tan≈´s, svaha’. The yajamƒÅna mutters ‘this for the Tan√ºs’ and proceeds ‘This pillar spread down from beaven and was raised over the earth. With it that has a thousand shoots we worry our enemy etc. (Tai. Br. III. 7. 6 and Ap. IV. 12. 8). The adhvaryu points out thrice with his forefinger the blade thrown into, fire with this, this’ and touches his nose and eyes with * Agnil thou art the protector of life, protect my life, thou art the protector of eyes’ (Tai. 8. I. 1. 13.2). Then the adhvaryu touobes the earth inside the vedi with thou art stable'( idid).

(Ch. XXX

oblation of djys with40’may the wife unite with her husband… sv√•ba' (Tai. Br, Il. 7. 5 quoted on p. 556 n. 1291 ). The sacrificer’s wife touches the adhvaryu ( with a blade of darbha) when he makes the last offering. The yajamƒÅna makes the ty√§ga ‘this is for the undecaying Great Soul, the light in Heaven.’

The adhvaryu then smears the two front points of the hotr’s finger as before, first the hind joint and then the front joint. He breathes over it and touches water. The adh varyu drops into the palm of the right hand of the hotf four drops of Ajya as ida “10 and six in that of the √§gnidhra. The hotƒô inaudibly invokes both ( viz, his own ida and √•gnidhra’s, the hand of the latter being held underneath the former’s ) in the same words as before (vide Appendix under note 2384). When the words ‘this yajamƒÅna has been summoned’ are uttered, the wife mutters ‘being summoned may I surpass in the possession “11 of cattle,’ and the adhvaryu also performs japa as above. When the ida is being invoked the adhvaryu, the √§gnidhra and the wife (with & darbha blade ) touch the hots. The yajamƒÅna invokes ajya ida with ‘may idƒÅ cover us with gbrta &o.’ ( Ap. IV. 13. 4). Br. III. 7.6). He silently performs m√§rjana after partaking of idƒÅ. The patnisamyƒÅjas end with the invocation of idƒÅ or they may be inished after reciting SamyuvƒÅka (Sat. II. 5, p. 225; A≈°v. Then he mutters & long prayer to the Sun ‘O Light of Mitra rising to-day &c.’ (Tai, Br. III. 7.6 and Tal. S. 1. 6. 6.1, quoted in Ap. IV. 15.1 and I. 16. 1). He contemplates the destruction of his enemy with the words. Here do I exclude from a share my enemy the evil.doer &o.' He revolves round himself from left to right with ‘I turn the turning of Indra’( Tai, 8. I. 6. 6. 2) and goes round the abavaniya with ‘Let me bave suspioious riches and may evil riches remain away from me’ (Ap. IV. 15.4). He bends over the dhavaniya with ‘thou art light’ (Tai. 8. I. 1.10.3), pays homage to it with May I be united with my children and may my children be united with me &c.' (Tai, S. I. 6. 6. 2, Ap. IV, 15. 4). He puts the fire into flames ‘O fire, being kindled, shine for me &o.’ (Tai. S. I. 6. 6. 2, Ap. IV. 16. 5). He prays to the abavaniya with ‘The sacrifice is endowed with riches, may I be endowed with riches &o.’ (Tai. 8. 1. 6.6.2, Ap. IV. 15. 5.). I. 6. 6. 3). He sits between the two fires inside the vedi with ‘to thee (unborn or born son as the case may be) who art light &c.’ (Ap. IV. 16.6). S. III. 5. 4. 1-% indicated in Ap. IV. 14. 10).

There are differences in the procedure of darse≈üti as com pared with that of the p≈´r≈ÜamƒÅse≈üti which have been noted in the above at the respective places. There are several modi. fications of the darsap≈´r≈Üam√§sa such as the DƒÅk·π£ƒÅya·πáa yaj√±a, the Vaim»õdba, S√§kamprastblya, which are omitted here for want of space. Jaimini (II. 3. 5-11 ) establishes that the DƒÅk. ≈üaya≈Üa, Sakamprasthiya and Samkrama yaj√±as are modifica tions of darsap≈´rnamƒÅsa.

Pin√ßapitryaj√±a It is so called because balls of rice are offered to the pitrg 2438 in this rite. According to Jaimini IV. 4. 19-21 Pindapitryajia

2427.$ 997 #HIGH √Ä … … Tuftat √Ä para ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ ‡§ú‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡•É‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ Partyra suger I af R ogueusi waja i str. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXX

is an independent rite and not a mere subordinate part of the darga sacrifioe. On the other hand several writers held that it was & subordinate part (anga ) of dar≈õa e. g. KƒÅt. IV. 1, 30 appears to be of that opinion and the paddhati on it notes that all bhƒÅ≈üyak√§ras like Karka stick to that opinion. 8428 The pindapitryaj√±a is briefly described below. For details, vide Sat. Br. II. 4. 2, Tai, Br, I. 3, 10, II. 6. 16, A≈õv. II. 6-7, ƒÄp. I. 7-10, Kat. IV. 1. 1-30, Sat. II. 7, Baud, III. 10-11. It is performed on amƒÅv√§sy√§ day when the moon cannot be seen and its distance from the sun is the least, in the last third part of the day or when only the rays of the sun are visible on the tops of trees. 8430 The caru (boiled rice ) is cooked on the dak≈üi≈Ü√•gni and the oblation is offered in the same. In this and other ways a contrast is brought out between rites for gods and for Manes. He kindles a blade on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire and carries it to

the south-east of that fire with the mantra' ye r√ªpƒÅ≈Üi &c.' (Vaj. 8. II. 30 ).4431 All actions are to be done facing the south-east unless otherwise specified. The darbha grass (to be employed in this rite) is severed at one stroke and is brought with or without its roots ( Ap. I. 7.3-4). Strewing round the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅgni darbha grass (paristarana) with their ende turned to the south in the case of those that are placed to the north or south he spreads darbhas to the north. He places to the north-east or to the north-west of the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅgni singly the yaj√±apƒÅtras required in this rite on darbha grass viz. carusthalƒ±, s√ºrpa, sphya, mortar and pestle, sruve, dhruvƒÅ, antelope-skin, fuel-sticks cut off at one stroke, mek≈üana, kamandalu, and whatever else may be Decessary. The adhvaryu going to the south of the sakata (the wooden frame on which the paddy is stored and which is to the West of the fire ) fills the carusthall (vessel for cooking rice ) that is placed on the s≈´rpa with paddy to the brimn and removes the grains ( that rise above the brim) on to the s≈´rpa (which overflowing grains are returned to the sakata ). The mortar is then placed on the black antelope-skin and the wife with her face to the south-east beats with the pestle the paddy grains

Oh, XXX)

Pindapitryaj√±a

1087

taken out in the carusthall and removes the husks by means of the winnowing basket. Without trying to separate the husked grains from the unhusked ones the grains are washed once and cooked on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire ( in such a way that the grains of rice are not entirely soft). He should draw with the sphya a line between the garbapatya and dak≈üi≈Üa fires or to the south east of the latter with the words ‘the asuras and evil-spirits that occupy the vedi are scattered away. (Vaj. S. II. 29 quoted in Sat. II. 7. p. 249 and Ap. I. 7. 13). He should then sprinkle that line ( as the vedi for this rite) with water, spread round it the darbha grass (out off with one stroke), take clarified butter in the dhruvƒÅ spoon, place it to the south of the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅgni, sprinkle on the mess of cooked rice clarified butter from the dhruvƒÅ. He places to the south of the dak≈üi≈Ü√•gni, collyrium, unguents, & mat and a pillow. Wearing the sacred thread in the prƒÅolnƒÅvita form ( acoord ing to ƒÄp. I. 8. 3 and Sat. II. 7. p. 248 the adhvaryu wears it in the upavita form) he offers on the fire the idhma (i. e. fifteen fuel-stioks), takes a portion of the boiled rice with the mek≈üa≈Üa, pours clarified butter over it, outs off two portions of the rice on it, again sprinkles clarified butter over 2438 the portions and the rice from which they are taken, offers into the dak≈üi≈Üa fire one ƒÅhuti ( oblation) with the words ‘SomƒÅya pitsmate svadh√• namah’, then again sprinkles clari fied butter on the portion out off and offers it with the words ‘Agnaye kavyavƒÅbanƒÅy& svadbƒÅ nama·∏•’. He 2488 then throws the mek≈üana on to the fire. Then on the line made with the spbya he sprinkles water tbrioe 2434 with the mantras “SundbantƒÅm pitara·∏•, sundhantƒÅm pitamabƒÅ·∏•, sundhantƒÅm prapitƒÅ mahƒÅ·∏• (may the fathers, grand-fathers and great-grand-fathers wash themselves puro ). He offers three balls of rice on that line one after another with the hand turned sideways ( i. e. the pinda is let off on the line from the part of the palm between the thumb

1088

History of Dharmasastra

(Ch. XXX

and the index finger ) with appropriate mantras, the first to the father with the words ‘this is for you father, 8435 N. N. and those who come after you’, to the grand-father with the words ‘this is for you grand-father &o.’, to the great-grandfather with similar words. The pinda ( ball of rice) for the great-grand father is the biggest of the three, that for the grand-father being larger than that for the father. There was a difference of view among the teacbers as to the procedure when any of the three ancestors was living, G√§pagƒÅri holding that pi≈Üdas were offered only to the deceased ancestors and he who was living was oply honoured, while Taulvali said that pindas were to be offered to three ancestors whether living or dead and Gautama stating that if any ancestor out of the first three above the sacrificer was alive, three pindas were to be offered and an ancestor beyond the great-grand-father may then be included. A√∏v.(II. 6. 20-23) refutes all these views by saying that no pinda can be offered to any ancestor beyond the great-grand-father and none to those who are alive nor to any ancestor between whom and & preceding ancestor & living ancestor intervenes, but that the pindas meant for ancestors that are alive may be tbrown into fire (with spƒÅbƒÅ at the end and not svadha ). According to Ap. I. 9.8 and Sat. p. 252 if the householder’s father be living he should not offer pindas but should stop after he performs the homa, If he has 2438 two fathers or grand fathers or great-grand-fathers (owing to adoption or niyoga) he should take two names with reference to the pinda offered to that ancestor. When the pindas are placed on the line referred to above he invokes the pi≈Üdas with a formula. Here you may regale yourselves, O pitfs and may you partake according to your shares' (VƒÅj.S.11.31).8439 Then he turns round and faces the nortb, sits down holding his breath till he feels exhausted, then again turns round and faces the pi≈Üdas and utters the invocation

Pindapittyaj√±a

‘the pitys have regaled themselves and have partaken according to their shares’ ( V√°j. 8. II. 31). He smells the boiled rioe. Then he again offers water ( ninayana) with the words Sun dhantƒÅm &o.', ( vide above p. 1087 ) on the line made with the sphya, he puts on the three pindas one after another the unguents and collyrium respectively with the words ‘asau abhyank≈üya’ (you by name so and so father &o, apply the unguents ) and ‘asau ank≈üva’ (you go and so father, &o. put the collyrium in the eye). He should then place 88 garment on each of the pi≈Üdas the hem of a garment ( da≈õƒÅ ) or woolen tuft or a hair from his own body (the part above navel) if he is beyond fifty years of age with the words ‘O pitss, this is the garment for you, may you not come in contact with any other ( garment ) than this’ ( A≈°v. II. 7, 6). Then he should wait upon the pit≈ôs with salutation and mutter the mantra ‘saluta tion to you, Pitrs, for ( securing ) food, salutation to you, Pitrs, for strength’ &o. 1438 and also the three verses ‘manonvƒÅ. huvƒÅmabe’ (Rs. X. 57, 3-5 ).8488 He should then make the pit≈ôs start forward on a stream of water ( i. e. by pouring water on the pipdas) with the mantra O well-disposed pitys! May you depart away by the ancient and awe-inspiring paths, after bestowing on us wealth and welfare. May you send down to us prosperity including all manly sons' (vide Tai. S. History of DharmƒÅtƒÅstra

(Ch. XXX

O pitsg1 may you deposit an embryo that will be a young boy wearing a lotus wreath, so that he may be unhurt' ( compare Vaj. S. II. 33). The other two pindag may be thrown into water or fire or a person who has recently lost all appetite for food may eat the two or one who is harassed by some incurable disease ( such as leprosy or tuberculosis ) may eat them, the result being that he is either cured or dies. Kat. IV. 1. 20 adds that the adhvaryu collects the pindas in a pot and the house-holder bends down and takes the smell thereof. ** Then the darbha blades taken out with one stroke are thrown into the fire, the utensils are sprinkled with water and then taken up in twos and laid aside.

A householder who had not consecrated the three vedio fires also had to perform the pi≈Üda-pitr-yaj√±a on amƒÅvƒÅsya, but he offered it in the grhya fire. Vide A≈õv, Sr. II. 7, 18, Sam. K. P. 838ff, Sam. Pr. 908 ff. Gaut. V. 5 prescribes that a house. holder should at least daily offer water to the pitrs and do more (i. e. offering food &c.) according to his ability and inclination. Manu II. 176 prescribes daily pitr-tarpa≈Üa (satiating the pitre with water ), for which see pp. 668-69.

CHAPTER XXXI

CƒÄTURMƒÄSYAS (seasonal sacrifices ) 2442

TD 1

According to A≈°v. II. 14. 1 the term Istyayana comprehends the C√°turmƒÅsyas, TurƒÅyana, DƒÅk≈üayana and other i≈ütis. The cƒÅturmƒÅsyas are three (or four according to some ), viz. Vai ve deva, Varu≈ÜapraghƒÅsa, SƒÅkamedha ( and Sundsirlya ). Each of these is called & parvan ( part or joint ) of the c√£turmƒÅsyas. They are called cƒÅturm√§syas because each of them takes place after four months. 2448 They are performed respectively on the Full Moon days of Phalguna (or Caitra ), of A≈üƒÅdba, KƒÅrtika and on the 5th full moon from the day on which the SƒÅkamedha is performed (i.e. on PhƒÅlguns) or two or three days before it (com, on ƒÄ≈õv. II. 20.2). They indicate the advent of three seasons viz. vaganta ( spring ), var≈ü& (rains) and hemanta *** (autumn). If the Vai≈°vadevaparva is performed on Caitra Full Moon, then the Varu≈ÜapraghƒÅsas and SƒÅkamedhas will be performed on Sr√§vapa and M√§rga≈õfr≈üa Full Moon days respeo. tively. The Tai. Br. 1. 6.8 states the reward secured by the performance of the c√°turmƒÅsyas. 2445

According to ƒÄsv. on the day previous to the Full Moon of Phalguna when beginning the c√£turmƒÅsyas he performs an i≈üti for ( Agni) Vai≈°vƒÅnara and Parjanya. According to K√•t. V, 1.2 there is an option viz, he may perform this i≈üti or the AnvƒÅrambhaniyƒÅ i≈üti. Then on the Full Moon day he performs the Vai≈°vadeva i≈üti in the morning and then performs the

p√§rnamƒÅsa i≈üti. According to the com. on Kat.V.1. the Vai≈°vadeva i≈üti is performed in the morning of the first day after Full Moon and then follows the purpamƒÅsa i≈üti of Ph√•lguna. The sacrificer has to keep certain observances on all the parvans of the c√£tur m√°syas viz. he has to sbavehis head and face, to sleep on the ground (not on a cot), to avoid honey, meat, salt, sexual intercourse and decorations of the body. There is an option as to shaving the moustaches and beard viz. he should shave only on the first and last parvans or may do so on all four. There are five offerings common to all cƒÅturm√§syas, viz., & purod√°sa (cake) on eight potsherds for Agni, boiled rice (caru) for Soma, a puroda≈°a on 1% or 8 potsherds (12 according to Txi. S. I. 8. 2) for Savitf (upƒÅm≈°u, inaudibly), a caru for Sarasvati, a oaru of finely ground rice for Pa≈üan. The reward secured by the performance of the c√§turm.sya847 is beaven. The caturmƒÅsyas may be performed throughout life or for one year only.

  2. When milk is drawn in the morning and heated and then the sour milk of tho precoding evening is added on to it, the mixture divides itsolf into two portions, the solid one being called MAHT and the liquid above it is called ‡§™‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®. the All-Gods (Visve Devah ) and a cake on a single potsherd to Dy√§v√§ppthivi ( Heaven and Earth ).

Kat. (V. 1. 21-24) requires that this Vaidvadeva-parvan should be performed in a spot which inolines towards the east,4449 that the sacrificer and his wife each put on two fresh and unworn garments ( one lower and the other upper) which they have to wear again at the Varupapragh√§caparvan, K√°t. (V. 1. 25-26 ) following ≈†at. Br. (II. 5. 1) says that barbis ( sacred grass to be strewn on sacrifioial ground ) is tied up in three bunches separately with a rope of grass and then all three bunches are tied together with a bigger rope and therein ( i. e. inside this last rope ) is thrust a bunch of flowering ku≈°a grads, which is to be used as prastara. After putting the yajƒÅap√°tras:450 on the sacrificial ground, fire is produced by churning from the aranis. Being directed by the adhvaryu the hotƒô priest repeats at the time of churning fire the verses Rg. I. 24. 3, I. 22. 13, VI. 16. 13-15 ( except the last pƒÅda of VI. 16. 15 ) and stops till he receives another direction (sampraiga ) from the adhvaryu. If fire is not produced at once the hotr should go on repeating the hymn, Rg. X, 118, till fire is struck from the aranis. “451 On hearing from the adhvaryu that fire is produced and that he should repeat a formula for that event, the botr repeats the last pada of Rg. VI. 16. 15 at which he had stopped (after the syllable om added at the end of that Verse of Rg. X. 118 at which he hears about the production of fire). Then be should repeat Rg. I. 74. 3 and stop after repeating half of Rg. VI. 16. 40, then recite Rg. VI. 16. 41-42, 1. 12. 6, VIII. 43, 14, the verse ‘tamarjayanta sukratum’ and then repeat Rg. X. 90. 16 as the paridhƒÅniyƒÅ ( the finishing Verse ). 45% There are nine prayƒÅjas and nine anuyƒÅjas in the Vai√©vadeva-parvan, while in the Darsapur≈ÜamƒÅse there are only

Catur mƒÅsyas- Vai≈°vadeva

1095

Jai.(IV.1. 22-24 ) concludes that ƒÅmiksa is the principal purpose of mixing curds in boiled milk and not vƒÅjina and in VIII. 2. 1-9 that in offering vƒÅjing the procedure of i≈ü√ßi is to be followed and not of SomayƒÅga though sruti in one passage states ‘somo vai vƒÅjinam’. Vide also Jai. II. 2. 23.

Varu≈ÜapraghƒÅsa.3456 The word Varupapragbaba is masculine and is always employed in the plural. The Sat. Br. (II. 5. 2. 1) gives a fanciful etymology viz. that yavas (barley grains ) belong to Varupa and as these are eaten (from ghas to eat) in this rite it is so called. This rite is performed in the rainy season four months after Vai vedeva on the Full Moon day of A≈üadha or of SrƒÅvana. The sacrificer should go out of bis house to a spot where plenty of shrubs grow. Two altars ( vedi) have to be prepared to the east of the abavapiya inclined towards the east, one south of the other. The northern vedi is in charge of the adhvaryu and the southern one in charge of his assistant, the pratiprasthƒÅtr ( Ap. VIII. 5.5.). The latter follows the adh varyu in doing the same actions on the southern vedi that are done by the adhvaryu on the northern vedi except carrying the water forward, girding the wife, producing fires and a few others specified in K√°t. V. 4. 33; all the orders (samprai≈üas, like agnaye samidhyamƒÅnƒÅya anubr√ºhi’) are to be uttered once and everything that concerns the uttering of words is to be done by the adhvaryu only (Ap. VIII. 5. 17 )8459. But Jai. XII. 1. 18 says that the mantras for taking ajya, for prok≈üa√±a and the like are to be reoited by the two separately. The procedure is like that of Vai≈°vadovaparvan except where special directions are given. The two vedis are separated from each other by a space ( at the corners ) two, three or four angulas or a span or even wider (Ap. VIII, 5. 10). There is a single utkara. The pratiprasthƒÅtmoves between the two vedis. On the previous day he makes ready pots full of karambha i. e. husked grains of barley slightly fried on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire, ground and mixed

  1. Vide Tai. S. I. 8. 3, VXj. S. III. 44-47, Tai. Br. I. 64, Sat. Br. II. 8. 2, Adv. II. 17, Baud V. 6-9, Kat. V.3-5, ƒÄp. VIII. 6-9.

  2. Jaimini XI. 2. 36-43 deals with the question that pratipra athats door on the southern vedi whatever adhyaryo doos on the nothorn. Jai. further (XI. 2. 44-48 ) states that though there are two vedis and the prati prasthats follows tho adhvaryu in doing all that he door, thero is not a double set of priests.1096

History of Dharmasastra (Oh. XXXI with curds ( K√§t. V. 3. 2). According to Ap. (VIII, 6. 3) it is the wife that makes these karambhap√§tras. These pƒÅtras exoved by one the number of the children (sons, unmarried daughters, grandsons and unmarried grand-daughters) of the house-holder ( K√•t. V. 3. 3-5, ƒÄp. VIII. 5. 41, who inoludes daughters-in-law) or they are at least three ( if the house-holder is childless or bas only a son or two). The figures of a ram and ewe are also made of the remaining part of the ground and fried barley used for the karambhapƒÅtras, the male being made by the adhvaryu and the female by the pratiprasthƒÅts and each figure having the characteristic signs of sex. The figures of the ram and owe are covered by the adhvaryu and pratiprasth√§tr respectively with a bunch of the wool of some animal other than the odakƒÅ (wild goat ) or with the ground tips of ku≈°a (in the absence of wool). Besides the five offerings common to all oaturm√•syas ( these being offered in the Varu≈Üa praghƒÅsas with all attributes and subsidiaries as in Vaisva deva, according to Jai. VII. 1. 17-21 ), in this rite offerings are made to four more, viz. Indra and Agai, the Maruts, Varu≈Üa and Ka 1. o. Prajapati (A≈°v. II. 17. 14) and the offerings are a cake on twelve potaherds (for IndrƒÅgni), payasyƒÅ or amik≈üa (for Maruts and Varu√±a) and a cake on one potsherd for Ka silently. All offerings are made from yava or only the karambhapƒÅtras are so made and the figures of the ram and the ewe also are made from yava and the rest from rice grains ( ƒÄp. VIII. 5. 36-37). The anuvƒÅkya and yƒÅjyƒÅ verses of each of these four special offerings to IndrƒÅgni, Maruts, Varu≈Üa and Ka are respectively&#88 Rg. VII. 94. 18, VI. 60.1; I. 86. 1, V. 58. 5; I. 25. 19, I. 24.11; IV.31.1, X. 121.1 (Asv. II. 17. 15). Straight to the east of the ƒÅhavaniya about three prakramas from it the northern vedi is prepared and several rules are laid down in K√§t. (V. 3. 13 f) and its com. about its extent. The northern vedi is six or seven aratnis in length from west to east, its western side is four aratnis and its eastern side is three aratnis or the vedi may be even much larger than this. On this vedi a fireplace is constructed with the earth dug up from the sacrificial pit called cƒÅtvala which is measured with & yoke-pin 32 angulas in length and made to the east of the utkara and after leaving a space between it and the utkara for

On the uttaravedi water is sprinkled with a mantra and gravel is also spread with ‘a lioness art thou’ (VƒÅj. S. V.10). That night the uttaravedi is covered with darbhas. In the morning the adbvaryu and pratiprasth√°ty carry forward fire on to the two vedis from the g√•rbapatya (according to Ap. VIII. 5. 22) or from the ƒÅhavaniya (according to K√§t. gaorificer’s wife sitting near the g√•rbapatya and asks her to declare what lover or lovers (j√§ra )8459 she has. If she names any, he (the pratiprasth√§tr ) declares that Varu√±a will seize him or them. If she con ceals the truth, the result would be that ber dear rela tives would suffer. The rite is conoluded by the priests and the saorificer and his wife going for a bath (avabhrtha) in a river9463 or the like taking with them the remainder of payasy√• for Varuna and the scrap ings from the pan that are treated like the refuse (rjiga of Soma). They then put on new clothes and make a gift of the clothes so far worn (that they had already worn at the Vai≈°vadeva-parvan) to one of the (five ) priests or to another (worthy ) person at their pleasure. (Ch. XXXI

Somayaga and that the material offered therein is the sorapings from the pan and not the purodasa ( VII. 3. 16).

S√§kamedha ***3

This third parvan of the c√£turmƒÅsy as is described at great length in Baud., Ap. and Kat. Only a few salient features are brought out below. ‘Sakamedha’ is used in the plural, since there are many rites therein and many and various offerings (com, on Kat. V, 6. 1). It literally means ‘kindling along with or at the same time as’ (s√•kam edha ). The name is probably given because the first offering in it is a cake on eight potsherds offered to Agni Anikavat with the rise ing sun.**** It is performed four months after the Varups praghasas on the Full Moon day of KƒÅrtika or M√§rgatir≈üa ( according as the Vai≈°vadeva-parvan was performed on the full moon of Phalguna or Caitra ). The whole of this parvan requires two days. On the day previous to the full moon there are three i≈ütis offered at the three savanas ( morning, midday and evening) to the three deities respectively, viz. to Agni Anikavat a cake on eight potsherds in the morning, to Santa pana Maruta caru (oblation of cooked rice) at midday, to Grhamedhin Maruts in the evening a caru boiled in the milk of all the cows belonging to the sacrificer (Ap. VIII. 9. 8). As regards tbis last caru it is stated (Ap. VIII. 10.8 and VIII. 11. 8-10, Kat. V. 6. 29-30) that if plenty of rice is cooked the priests and the sons and grandsons of the sacrificer (who have had the upanayana performed ) eat the food to satiety and go to sleep that night in the same hall without indulging in any talk about poverty or bunger. Jaimini ( V. 1. 19-22 ) refers to the text’agnaye anikavate pratar-a≈ütakapƒÅla·∏• &o.’ and states 88 the conclusion that all the tbree rites are performed on one day and no part of the three is to be performed the next day. On that night the milch cows are let loose to mix up among their calves ( whloh oan then drink the milk of their mothers with out let or hindrance ).. He, however, binds down that calf which is required for milking the cow that has lost its own oalf (and whioh is to be milked the next morning for the offerings

  2. ‡§≠‡§Ø ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§Ω‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡•á‡§°‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§´ turum ft. V. 9; Ap. VIII. 9.2 sad . #. 1. 8. 4.8 have the worde word … . mum.

CaturmƒÅsyas-SƒÅkamedha

to the Manes ). That night and in the next morning agaihotra is performed with rios gruel (and not with milk). On the next day (the principal day of Sakamedba) the sacrificer either before or after the daily agnibotra performs a homa with a darui taking & portion of the boiled rice sticking to the bottom of the sthall (pot) that had been cooked for the offering to Grbamedhin Maruts the previous evening. He fills the darvi3486 (ladle ) with a mantra (Vaj. S. III. 49, Tai. S. I. 8. 4. 1). Then the adhvaryu directs the yajamƒÅna to fetch a bull and make it bellow. When the bull bellows, he offers the rice in the darvi into fire with a mantra (Vaj. S. III. 50, Tai. S. I. 8. 4. 1). If the bull does not bellow, then the oblation is offered after the brahm√• priest directs offer’A≈°v. ( II. 18. 11-12) states that the home may be offered ( if the bull does not bellow) at the thunder of a cloud or some make the √§gnidhra roar calling him * brabmaputra’ (‘the son of the brahm√§ priest’, whose assistant he is). The bull is given ag fee to the adhvaryu. Then an isti is offered to Kridin Maruts with & cake cooked on seven potsherds and a caru to Aditi. This is followed by a mahƒÅhavis ( a great offering), which consists of eight offerings to eight deities. They are five offerings common to all cƒÅturmdeyas, the 6th offering is a cake on twelve potsherds to Indra and Agni, the 7th is caru to Mahendra (or according to A≈°v. II. 18. 18 to Indra, or V√Ωtrahan Indra or Mahendra ), the 8th is & cake on one potsherd to Vibvakarman 2466 ( inaudibly ). According to Ap. he offers the 8th offering of a cake after taking the naines of the four months Sabas, Sahasya, Tapas and Tapasya ( 1 e. M√°rga sir≈üa to Phalguna). A bull is the fee of this MahƒÅhavis (or a COW acoording to Ap.).

After the mahahavis comes the pitƒºyajƒÅa which is called mahapitryaj√±a. To the south of the dak≈üi≈Üa ire a now vedi having four corners in the four principal directions 2407 is prepared and has the same length and breadth as the height

round the vedi from right to left. He offers water for washing the feet to the three ancestors (of the saorificer) in the north west, south-west and south-east corners of the vedi respectively. He mixes portions of the cake, the fried barley and the mantha and prepares three balls therefrom and offers them facing the south on the three corners referred to above for the three ances tors with the appropriate mantras ( etat te tata 2469 ye ca tvƒÅm anu, etat te pitamaba &c.). Aocording to Ap. (VIII. 16. 7) he prepares three more pi≈Üdas for the three ancestors beyond the paterpal great-grand-father and invokes them on the pi≈Üdas in the reverse order i. e. the sixth anoestor on the first (out of these other three pi≈Üdas ), the fifth on the 2nd pinda and the fourth on the 3rd. He then wipes off the remnants of the pindas (pindalepa ) stioking to the hand on the north-eastern corner of the yedi with ‘atra pitaro’ ( V√°j. S. II. 31 first half ). The priests and the sacrificer with faces to the north leave that place, wear the sacred thread in the upavita form and wait upon the ƒÅhavaniya with V√°j. S. III. 51-52 ( = Tai. S. I. 8. 5. 1-2 ), and on the g√§rhapatya with VƒÅj. S. III. 53-55 ( =Tai, S. I. 8. 5. 2-3). Then entering the vedi the sacrificer, wearing the sacred thread in the prƒÅcinƒÅvita form, mutters the mantra amimadanta' (Vaj. 8. II. 31 latter half). They sprinkle the vedi from left to right and do all the rest as in pindapitryaj√±a, The sacrificer then folds his hands with namo vah' ( Vaj. S. II. 32 ) or makes six namaskƒÅras (salutations ) and invokes the blessing

give us house' (Vaj. S. II. 32). This rite ends with Samyu ( A≈°v. II. 19. 2, K√§t. V. 9, 32) i. e. ‘taochamyorƒÅ …… sam catuspade’ (Tai. Br. III. 5. 11 ) and there is no patnisamy√§ja homa in dak≈üi≈Üa fire and so on. The remaining portion of the material for offerings is thrown into the fire or into water or may be eaten by the priests.

The last rite in the SƒÅkamedhas is the Traiyambaka homa. Vide Tai. 8. I. 8. 6, Sat Br. II. 6. %. 1-17, A≈°v. II. 19, 37-40, Ap. VIII. 17-19, Baud. V. 16-17, K√°t. V. 10. This home is offered to Rudra. Some of its peculiarities may be noted. In this the adhvaryu takes out material to prepare cakes cooked on one potsherd exceeding by one the children (the sons and grandsons together with their wives and unmarried daughters ) of the sacrificer or at least four ( if he is childless or has no more than a few children). Besides the five offerings common to all cƒÅturm√°syas, the special offerings in this i≈üti are a cake on twelve potsberds to Sundsfrau (V&yu and Aditya, according to com. on K√§t. V. 11.5 and to Indra Sunasira, according to Ap. VIII. 20.5 and com.), an oblation of fresh warm milk ( not heated) direct from the cow to V√§yu, a cake on one potsherd to S√ºrya. There is no uttaravedi in this rite, and no fire is produced by attrition. There are five prayƒÅjas, three anuyƒÅjas and one sam istayajus, but according to Ap. VIII. 20. 6 there are nine prayƒÅjas and anuyajas. The dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ for the rite is a plough with six bulls or two big bulls and for the cake to S√ºrya a white horse or a white bull (Kat. V. 11. 12-14), while aocording to Tai, S. I. 8.7 it is a plough to whioh twelve oxen are yoked and scoording to Ap. (VIII. 20. 9-10) a plough with twelve or six oxen.

Sundsirau’ occurs in the Rgveda IV, 57.5 and 8. In Rg. IV. 57.4 and 8 the word ‘gunam’ ocours several times. The meaning is doubtful. According to Yaska’s Nirukta IX. 40 ≈öuna and Sira mean V√§yu and Aditya respectively; while the ≈öat. Br. II. 6. 3. 2 appears to hold that suna means prosperity and sira means ' essence or gap' (sƒÅra ) and this i≈üti is so oalled because the sacrificer thereby secures both prosperity and sap.

ƒÄgrayana (offering of first fruits ) 1475 This is an i≈üti, without performing which an ƒÅhitƒÅgni was not to make use of freshly harvested rice, barley and millet. It was either performed on a New Moon day or Full Moon day, but the procedure was the same as that of the i≈üti on New Moon. The time of the √•grayana isti with rice is sarad (autumn) when one had ample rains. *476 As barley crops became ready in vasanta (spring), the √§grayana for yavas was to be per formed in spring. A≈°v, allowed an option that when the i≈üti was once performed in the autumn one may not perform it in spring for the barley crop. The i≈üti for millet crop ( syƒÅmƒÅka) was performed in the rainy season and therein a caru was offered to Soma. The i≈üti was so called because therein the first fruits ( agra ) were first employed or eaten ( ayana ). 3477 According to Ap. (VI. 29. 6) there are 17 kindling versos ( sƒÅmidbeni ), whioh number is obtained by inserting two additional verses called dh√£yy√• after the 8th or 9th s√§midheni of the darka-p√ºr≈Üa-masa i≈üti. II. 9. 13, it is either AindrƒÅgna or Agnendra ), *& oaru cooked in milk or water for All Gods (Vi√üve Devah ) silently, a cake on one potsherd to Heaven and Earth and caru to Soma ( if the first fruits are millets ). Kat. IV, 6. 7 allows en option that the caru for All Gods may be of old rice. For him who performs only daily agnihotra or who does not

CHAPTER XXXII

PASUBANDHA OR NIR≈™DHAPASUBANDH A 2481

(immolation of an animal in sacrifice ).

The animal sacrifice is an independent sacrifice and it is also performed in soma sacrifices as a constituent part (anga ). The independent animal sacrifice is oalled nir≈´dhapasubandha ( offering of an eviscerated animal) and the subordinate ones are called saumika ( A≈°v. III. 8. 3-4). The nirudhapa≈°u is really & modification of an animal sacrifice in somayage (called agni≈üomiya pa≈°u ) 28 Jai. VIII. 1. 13 declares, but in many g≈´tras the full procedure of both is set out in the nirudha. pa≈°u section ( vide K√§t. VI. 10.32 and com. on Kat. VI. 1. 31 ). The nirudhapasubandha itself becomes the prak»ôti (arche type or model) of all other animal sacrifices, except savaniya pa≈°u and anubandhyapasu. The independent animal sacrifice is to be performed every six months or every year by the ƒÅhitƒÅgni throughout his life.348% If done once a year it was to be performed in the rainy season (i. e. in SrƒÅvana or Bhadrapada) on New moon or Full moon day or if done six monthly then at the beginning of the southward and northward passages of the Sun ( dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅyana and uttarayana ). Then it may have to be performed on any day and not necessarily on am√• v√§sy√§ or paurpam.si. According to Asv. (IIL. 1. 2-6) optionally an isti before and after the independent pagubandha rite may be per formed and if performed it is offered either to Agni or to Agai. Vi≈ünu or to Agni and Agni-Vi≈ünu. In this sacrifice there is a sixth priest called Maitr√•varuna ( or Pra≈õƒÅsts) in addition to the five required in the c√§turm√§syas. An udumbara staff is given to the sacrifioer when he is initiated for a sporifice like Agni≈ütoma, In the pa≈°ubandha when the Maitr√§varu≈Üa enters the sacrifioial ground after the priests are chosen the adhvaryu

  2. Manu IV. 26 alao rooommonds an animal sacrifice at the beginning of the ayanas. Ap. VII. 8. 2-3 and Baud, IV. 1 sot out the yajiapatras and other materials roquirod in pasubandha.

History of Dharmat√§stra

[Ch. XXXII

(or yajamƒÅna in some gakhas ) 2488 hands over that staff ( which in length would reach the mouth of the sacrificer) to the maitr√•varupa with a mantra and the maitr√§varu≈Üa accepts it with a corresponding mantra. The maitr√•varupa standa slightly bent to the south of the seat of the hote resting his staff on the vedi and utters directions to the bots to repent y√§jy√•s. Till he utters the first prai≈üa he is not to touch himself or any one else with the staff. The maitr√•varups is to utter in & standing posture while holding the staff tbe praigas and the apuv√°kyas wherever a prai≈üa is employed and do & few otber acts standing; but the rest of his duties in some sacrifices he does sitting. Jaimini (IV. 2. 16-18) has a discussion ( arising out of Tai. S. VI. 1. 4. 2 “krite some maitrƒÅvaru≈Ü&ya dandam prayaochati') on the question whether the handing over of the staff to maitr√§varu≈Üa is & pratipattikarma or an arthakarma (the oonclusion is that it is the latter). The adhvaryu makes an offering of clarified butter in the ahavaniya, which is called y√ºpƒÅhuti, with the sruva or with a sruc in which four lodlings of ajya have been poured, with the mantra’uru vi≈Üpo' (Vaj. 8. V. 41, Tai. 8. I. 3.4.1). The adhvaryu, taking the rest of the djya and the sruva, goes to a place where trees grow, accompanied by a carpenter (tak≈üan) holding an axe (Ap. VII. 1.13 and K√§t. VI. 1.5). The sacrificial post (y√ºpa) 484 is to be made of the palada, khadira, bilva or rauhitaka tree according as one desires Various rewards (Ap. VII.1.16), but in Soma sacrifices the y√ºpa must be of khadira, if possible. Jai. (VI. 3.28-30) states that, if by accident the sacrificial post made of one kind of tree is destroyed during the continuanoe of the rite, another y√ºpa of the same treo or of a tree very similar to it is to be substituted The tree to be out must be full of leaves, must not have its top dried up, must be straight and growing on a level spot, and its branches must be turned upwards and it should be bent in some direction other than the south. Adhvaryu, brahma, the saorificer and carpenter touch the tree after selecting it with the mantra' atyany√°n' (Vaj. S. V. 4%, Tai. 8, I. 3, 5). The adhvaryu touches the trunk of the tree all round ( where it is to be out ) with the sruva anointed with ajya with the mantra

  1. Antard frifa na EH oorlattaat ooreet fast Tror TETT Tratuite SATT ATTAtla i 9 . III, 1. 16; comparo K$t. VI. 4. 4, Ap. VII. 14. 3.

  2. Vide Sat. Br. III. 6.4 to III 7. 1 for an oxtensivo trontmont of avorything rogurding the yups, and also Ait. Br. 6.1-.

Ch. XXXII)

Patubandha-making a y√ºpa

1111

*May god Savitr anoint thee with madhu' (Tai. 8. I. 3. 5 ) or with Vi≈üpave tva' (Vaj. 8. V, 42). He keeps obliquely & darbha blade on the trunk with the words ‘ogadhe tr√°yagvalnam’ (Tai. S. I. 3. 5 or V√°j. 8. V. 42) and strikes the tree with the are with the mantra ‘O axe! do not injure it’ ( svadhite mainam himsih,' VƒÅj. S. V. 42 and Tai. 8. I. 3.5). The first chip of the tree that is cut off, he keeps in a well-known place and the tree is out at such a low height from the ground that the stump left in the ground would not strike against the axle of a cart going that way. The tree should be so cut that it should not fall to the south ; it should fall to the east or north or north-east ( Ap. VII. 2. 7); when it is falling he repeats the mantra ‘do not scratch the heaven with your top &o.’ (Vaj. S. V. 43 or Tai. 8. I. 3.5). He offers ajya with the juh≈´ on the stump of the tree with the mantra ‘O tree, grow again with a hundred shoots’ (Vaj. S. V. 43, Tai, S, I. 3. 5 ) and having touched one’s body with ‘may wo grow into a thousand branches’ (ibid.) he outs off from tbe bottom upwards the twigs and knots of the felled. tree. There were several views about the length of the y√ºpe (Ap. VII. 2. 11-17, K√§t. VI. 1. 24-26). According to some the yƒÅpa may be of any length from one aratni to 33 gratnis, but Kat. gives the usual length at 3 or 4 aratnia and Ap. (VII. 2. 17) also quotes the Sat. Br.(XI. 7. 4. 1) that the y√ºpa in nirudha pagubandha is three or four aratnis in length, while in Soma sacrifices the other measures may apply. KƒÅt. (VI. 1.31) states that in somayƒÅga the y√ºpa may be from five to fifteen aratnis in length except 7, 10 or 14 aratnis and in the VƒÅjapeya sacrifice the y√ºpa is 17 aratnis in length and in the A≈°vamedha it is 21 aratnis. According to Ap. it must be in length at least as much as the height of the yajamƒÅna or as much as the yajamƒÅna with hands upraised. The girth of the y√ºpa is not fired. That part of the y√ºpa which is to be planted in the pit is called upara, which is not to be chiselled and which is about a 5th of the whole log but the rest of it is to be chigelled from the bottom towards the top 80 as to make the y√ºpa have eight angles and it should be somewhat tapering towards the top. One oorner or angle ( out of the eight ) should be more prominent than the rest and should face the fire. Out of the top portion of the 486 tree that remains after making the y≈´pa the carpenter prepares & wooden head-piece, eight-cornered and of the length of the hand from the wrist to the tips of the fingers and contracted in

  1. HOT

TUTT&TT ATYHETTEI

TT. VI. 1. 28.

History of Dharmatostra

(. XXXII

the middle like a mortar. This piece is oalled ca≈üala and is made hollow so as to fit in exactly on to the top of the y√ºpa like a turban and the peg-like top of the y√ºpa on which the ca≈üala is fixed should protrude two or three angulas beyond the ca≈üƒÅla ( Kat. VI, 1. 30 ).

The nirudhapasubandha oocupies two days, though it may be performed in one day. On the first of the two days called upavasatha ‘86 preliminary matters such as preparing the vedi, bringing the ydpa are performed.

The vedi (a single one ) in the nir≈´dhapasubandha is prepared like the one in Varuna-pragbƒÅsas to the east of the usual √°bavaniya fire-place (and not to the west as in darka p≈´r≈ÜamƒÅsa). The dimensions of the vedi are variously given, According to Ap. VII. 3. 7-9 the vedi is three or four aratnis on its western side, six aratnis in length from west to east and three aratnig on the eastern side and it is less in breadth ‘towards the east or it is as wide as the axle on the west, of the length of the shafts of & cart and to the east as wide as that portion of a yoke which is between the outer holes thereof. On this vedi an uttaravedi ( a high altar ) is measured with the samyƒÅ 3487 (yoke-pin) on the eastern one-third of the vedi. From the northern corner of the eastern side ( the shoulder ) of the vedi, a pit called c√§tvƒÅla is measured one samy√§ square about one prakrama to its north; it is dug with & spade taken with the mantra ‘devasya ivƒÅ …… adade’ (Vaj. S. VI. I) and it is silently dug as deep as the knee or three vitastis ( 36 angu las ). The Tal. Br. I. 5. 10 gives the latter measure. The o√°tv√°la is in front of the utkar& and a passage is left between the utkara and the catvala which is contiguous to the north side of the mab√°vodi (vide Sat. Br. III. 5. 1. 24-30). The earth dug up is heaped on the uttaravedi thrice 2488 with the mantra

Ch. XXXII)

Patubandha-uttaravedi

1113

*a lioness art thou’ (Tai. 8. I. 2. 12. %) and a fourth time silently and then is spread over the uttaravedi with ‘uru pra thasva …… prathatƒÅm’ (Tai. 8. I. 2. 12. 2); he breaks up the olods with the samyƒÅ, invokes the earth dug up, sprinkles it, spreads gravel on the earth so dug up and spread, pours down the remainder of the water contained in the prok≈üanl vessel to the north of the uttaravedi by means of a channel made with one stroke of the sphya and cements together the borders of the utta ravedi ( with water and earth). On the uttaravedi he makes & square hole ( called uttaranƒÅbhi) a span in measure or measuring as much as a bull’s or horse’s hoof, invokes it and sprinkles it with water and the rest of the water is drained off to the south (as water was drained off to the north above). Then he covers the uttaravedi with twigs of udumbara or plaksa tree and waits, if the pa≈°ubandha is so performed as to extend over two days. In the morning next day he pours clarified butter in a stream on the uttaravedi from the south-east corner to the north-west corner and from the south-west to the north-east carrying a golden piece in such a way that the butter will fall on the gold. Then he places three (pine ) paridhis ( enclosing stioks ) which are of kƒÅrsmarya wood ( according to ƒÄp. VII. 7.7) round the nƒÅbhi in the west, south and north and puts down on the uttaravedi certain materials viz. bdellium, fragrant and appetising grass, bunch of white wool from between the horns of a ram ( petua ). Having kindled idhma ( a bunch of samidbs ) at the dhavaniya fire, he carries forward the kind led sticks (in & veggel) *489 which is supported on a vessel containing gravel ( to prevent the soorching of the hands ) to the uttaravedi and places them down on the n√§bhi over the bdellium and other things. This becomes the abavaniya for all actions in the pasubandha and the original Abavaniya becomes the g√°rhapatya.9490

He takes a spade with a mantra (e. g. Vaj. S. VI. 1), draws to the east of the new ahavaniya an outline of the hole to be dug for inserting the y≈´pa. He digs a pit so deep that when the y√ºpa is erected therein its upara (the lower unchisel led portion) will not be exposed to view and he throws out to the east of the pit the earth dug out. (Oh. XXXII

and surrounding with a girdle ( parivy√§≈Üa or parivyayana ) are performed on the y√ºpa only once and are not repeated at each time an animal is sacrificed. The girdle is an anga of the y√ºpa and not of the pa≈°u, as otherwise as many girdles will be required for the y≈´pa as the number of victims to be sacrificed in a gƒÅga (vide Jal. IV. 4. 22-24). The svaru is connected As an anga with the victim (for anointing the victim with it) and not with the y√ºpa (Jai. IV. 4. 25-28 ). Vide Jai. IV. 2. 1-6 also.

The animal to be sacrificed is bathed with goented water, is led between the cƒÅtvala and utkara and brought in front of the y≈´pe to the east with the animal’s face to the west. The animal is a he-goat ( cb√§ga ) which must not have a broken horn and must not be devoid of an ear or eye or tooth or tail, must not be lame nor have only seven hoofs (instead of eight, as each of the feet has two hoofs). If the animal is defective in any one of these ways an expiatory offering of djya has to be made to Vi≈ü≈Üu or Agni-Vi≈üpu or Sarasvati or B·ªáhaspati (Ap. VII. 12.3). Then follows Pa≈°≈´pƒÅkarana495 which may be done in two days. He takes a darbha blade other than from those spread on the vedi with ‘up√•vir-asi’ (Vaj. S. VI. 7) and touches the animal ( that stands faoing the west) therewith with the verse ‘near the gods’ (upa devƒÅn, V√°j. 8. VI.7). Anotber way (according to Ap. VII. 1%. 5-8) is: he takes two blades of kusa reciting ' i≈üe trƒÅ' (Tai. $. I. 1. 1.1) and takes a branch of plaksa tree that has many leaves and twigs, that is not dry at the end and is not hollow and touches the victim with the blades and the branch and repeate the two mantras ‘upo devƒÅn-daivir-videb and prajapater-jayamƒÅna’ (Tai. S. I. 3. 7. 1 and III. 1.1.4) and the words ‘I assign thee, who are dear to Indra and Agni.“3486 Then he produces fire by churning from the aranis and offers homa in accordanoe with the procedure of the Vaisvadeva-parva (vide above pp. 1093.-94). Ap. (VII. 12. 11) says that upakarapa may be done after the production of fire. He makes a loop of the

VIII, 4). The 2nd meaning of Aprr is ‘& verse (yojya) that gratifics a deity’. In this senso the word is used in the Ait. Br. VI. 4

Patubandha-Apris

1119

escribed to the founder of his gotra if he is from among these ten sages. The words of Asv. I. 5. 21-22 oreate some difficulty. A√∏v. there presoribes that when uttering the yajya at the time of offering the 2nd praydja, the formula should contain an address to Tan≈´nap√§t for all except for persons of Vasi≈ütba, Sunaka, Atri, Vadbrya≈°va and Rajanya gotras. These latter should utter a formula addressed to NarƒÅ≈°amsa. Here if * rajanya’ refers to Visv√§mitra, then the difficulty is that in the Aprl hymn (III. 4) ascribed to him, the 2nd deity is Tan≈´napat and not Nar√°bamsa ; but it is possible tbat the word ‘rdjanya’ stands for a k≈üatriya sacrificer in general and does not refer to Visv√§mitra gotra at all. After ten prayƒÅjas are offered, the adhvaryu says to the slaughterer of the victim' bring your two-edged knife.' The adhvaryu takes the svaru (chip of wood) and anoints the svaru and one edge of the knife with the clari fied butter from the bill-like (or spout-like ) part of the juh√º ladle ( according to ƒÄp. VII. 14. 10 the svaru is anointed thrice) and holding the svaru below the knife touches with both the head of the victim (forehead, according to Kat. VI.5.12 ) with a mantra (VƒÅj. S. VI. 11, Tai. S. I. 3.8.1). After placing back the svaru whence it was taken the adhvaryu gives the knife back to the slaughterer (Samitr) with the words ‘let this edge be marked by you’(Sat. Br. III. 8.1.5). The animal when killed is out up by the slaughterer with the un-anointed edge and the flesh when roasted is cut up with the edge that is anointed. The adhvaryu directs the maitrƒÅvaru≈Üa to recite a mantra for indicating that fire ( a fire-brand) is being carried round the victim and the maitr√•varu≈Üa recites ‘agnirhota no’ (Rg. IV. 15. 1) or the verses Rg. IV. 15.1-3 (according to ƒÄ≈õv. III. 2.9). To the north of the c√¢tvala pit, he digs up a spot for establishing the

Samitra fire.900 The Agnidhra, lighting & fire-brand at the Ahavaniya, carries it thrice round the victim, the y√ºpa, the Ahavaniya fire, the place where the dƒÅmitra fire is to be kindled, the otvƒÅla pit and the clarified 2001 butter, from left to right with the mantra pari vƒÅjapatih kavih' (Rg. IV. 15. 3, Tai. 8. IV. 1, 2.5). In modern times the priest perambulates all these together and not separately. The √•gnidbra throws the firebrand on to the Ahavaniya fire and again goes round the above objects thrice from right to left. According to Ap. VII. 15. 4-6, the adhvaryu makes one, two, three or four offer ings of ajya, with mantras called apƒÅvya, when fire is carried round the victim, when it is set free from the y√ºpe and led on (Tai. S. III. 1. 4. 1-2). The agnidhra, again taking up the same fire-brand, starts to go with his face to the north and the victim is led after the agnidhra by the samitr ( who takes away the cord of girdle from the victim’s head and ties it round its neck). The pratiprastb√°tr ( an assistant of adhvaryu ) touches the animal (that is being led northward ) from behind with two utensils ( spits) made of k√§rsmarya wood ( used for roasting vapa, omentum ), the adhvaryu touches the pratipra sth√§te and the sacrificer touches the adhvaryu.250X A pit ia got dug (by a servant) for covering in it the undigested food and the fooes of the victim when killed. They (the priests and yajamins ) should not pass beyond the place for the samitra fire. History of DharmasƒÅstra

(On. XXXII

terers calling upon them to bring the animal to the holy doors of the sacrificial place, wishing that the parents, relatives and friends of the victim will consent to its death and expres sing the hope that its several organs and limbs, such as the eyes and ears, will be merged in divinities like the sun and giving directions as to how its parts are to be cut and disposed of. On reciting this solemn formula the hot;, while still occupying his seat, turns to the right (i. e. he comes to face the west) and has the sacrificial place behind his back and the maitr√•varupa does the same. The adhvaryu throws one of the two blades taken up by him to the west of the samitra fire, the victim is held over that blade with its head to the west (or to the east, according to KƒÅt. VI. 5. 17) and feet to the north. Then its mouth is firmly held so as to stop its breathing and choke it to death or it is strangled to death without allowing it to give out a ory, by using & halter round its throat. The adhvaryu says ‘kill it without 980s allowing it to utter a ory’ and then he along with the pratiprasth√§tr, √§gnidhra and the sacrificer come back to the ahavaniya which they face, turn from left to right and remain with their backs to the animal that is being killed (i. e. they, do not see the actual slaying of the animal). According to Ap. VII. 16. 7 tbe sacrificer repeats at this time several verses such as Tai. S. III. 3. 1. 2, Tai. Br. III, 7.7, the purport of which is that the viotim may go to heaven, the sacrificer himself also may go to heaven after securing welfare in this world. When the samitr declares that the viotim is killed the adhvaryu says ‘let, it lie down for a moment.’ If the pa≈°u bleats while being strangled the adhvaryu then offers

ajya in fire (as an expiation). The sacrificer and adhvaryu with vapa≈õrapanis (spits ) approach the dead victim with the words ‘O slaughterers, may you approach’(Tai. 8. III. 1, 4.3). History of DharmatƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXII

Haorificer treadg3508 upon the blood-stained blade with the left foot ( and then touches water with his hand ). The adh varyu then pulls out from the belly of the viotim the omentum, envelopes the two spits 2510 ( vapa≈°rapanis ) with it, pierces the thin end of the vapa with one spit, severs it from the belly on all sides and sprinkles it with water holding the spits over the patvƒÅla pit. Then the pratiprasthƒÅtr heats the omentum on the samitra fire. The adhvaryu, pratipras. thats and Agnidhra come from the otv√•la to the aha vaniya. The Agnidhra throws the samitra fire (viz. the firebrand and not the fire produced by attrition) into the Dhavaniya and the adhvaryu also throws into it the portion of the blade hold in his left hand ( as stated at p. 1123 above). Ap. ( VII. 19. 3) adds that the samitr holds tigbtly by the closed fingers of his hands the two portions of the skin of the victim’s belly till the omentum is offered into fire. The pratiprasthƒÅtƒô, standing to the north of the ƒÅhavaniya fire, heats the omentum on that fire, then carries it by the space between the y√ºpa and @havaniya, goes round to the south side, and roasts the omentum on the dhavaniya. The adhvaryu takes clarified butter in the sruva ladle and pours ajya on the omentum that is being held for roasting on the ƒÅbavaniya by the pratiprasth√§tr with a mantra. When drops ( stokas) of fat begin to drip from the omentum, the adhvaryu directs the maitrƒÅ varu≈Üa to recite for the drops. The maitr√§varu≈Üa recites Rg. I. 75. 1. and Rg. III. 21. 1-5.8511 When the omentum is well roasted, the pratiprasthƒÅtƒô says to the adhvaryu ‘it is roasted, proceed. The omentum is placed on the south corner of the western side ( ≈õropi ) of the vedi on a branch of plak≈Üa tree stretched on the barhis ( kusa grass on the vedi). p. 1117 above ). Jal. (XII. 1. 1-8) prescribes that the proce dure (viz. pray√∞jas ) performed at the time of offering vapa is not to be repeated when the pasupuroda≈õa is offered. The adhvaryu separates the various organs ( such as the heart, the tongue) from the corpse without cutting into parts each organ (according to the com. on Ap. VII. 22.5 and 7 it is the samitr who outs up the several limbs). There is some divergence as to the limbs of the victim that are out off and are used as avadƒÅnas and since animal sacrifices became rare or were altogether stopped in medieval times, the commentators do not explain all the words used in the ancient texts in the same way (vide ƒÄp. VII. 22. 6, KƒÅt. VI. 7. 6-12 and Baud. IV. 8). Accord ing to ƒÄp. VII. 22. 6,8510 the limbs out off are: the heart, the tongue, ohost, the liver, the kidneys ( v≈°kyau, v≈ôkkau in K√°t. ), left forefoot, the two flanks ( p√•r√∏ve), the right haunch, a third part ( i. e. the middle one) of the entrails these are meant for the dovat√°s and are to be offered with the juh≈± ladle ; the right fore-foot, the left baunch, the thinnest third of the entrails–these are for svi≈ütak·ªát; the kloman (the right lung ? )8517, plihan ( the spleen), puritat ( pericardium ? ), adhy√ºdhni (& tubular vessel above the udder ), vani≈üthu (large entrails ?), medas (fat), jƒÅghanƒ±$18 (the tail). The whole of the entrails are taken off at once and divided only at the time of cutting and putting into the juba ladle.

7.11 adds that kloman and the next three may be out off or not. The medas ( fat on the abdomen) is, according to Kat., thrown on the guda (entrails) if the victim be thin. The tail is to be employed as an offering in the PatnisamyƒÅja, according to Kat. and the largest part of the intestines ( 3rd of the whole ) was to be employed as offering in upayaj homa. The undigested grass (inside the belly of the victim ) is put in & pit dug up to the west of the gƒÅmitra fire and to the north of the utkara and on it the blood of the victim is poured with the words ‘thou art the portion of evil spirits’ (Vaj. S. VI. 16 ). The victim’s heart is held pierced on a pike (d≈´la) made of varana wood one aratni long and is roasted on the samitra fire and all other parts of the victim except the heart are cooked in an ukhƒÅ (pot for boiling or cooking). According to com. on Ap. VII. 22. 9 this cooking is done by the samits. Jai. XII. 1. 12 prescribes that the cooking is done on the sal√°mukblys fire and not on simitra fire. The adhvaryu performs the operation of sprinkling butter on the juh≈´ and upabhrt, outs two portions from the middle and front parts of the cooked material into the juh≈Ø, pours butter over it and offers it into fire for Indra and Agni, then cuts one portion ( for Svi≈ütakst) into the upabbft, makes two pourings of butter over it and makes an offering to Agni Svi≈ütakst.2519 Jai. (XII. 1. 10-11 ) concludes that the offering of the pahupurodƒÅsa is made with the ladles. used in dar≈õap≈´r≈ÜamƒÅsa and not with the soma vessels ( viz, the oups and camasas). Then a portion is cut off out of the remainder of the material from which purodƒÅsa was offered and placed in & vessel called prasitrabarana ( which portion of the sacrificial food is eaten by the brahmƒÅ priest ) and some portion is cut off as the id√£, which is invoked with mantras and eaten by all the priests. He then thrice asks the samity whether tho havis (the heart roasted on a pike) is ready cooked and the latter simply replies “it is cooked', Kat, VI. 8. 1 presoribes that the samitr should in his reply utter only the word ‘sptam’ and should not add any word like ‘revered sir’ (bhagavah) or ‘hi’.   1. The wholo animal is the sacrificial material (just as rice grains are the material from which caru is prepared for offering ) and havis is constituted by the heart and other organs of the animal. Vide com, on Kat. VI. 8. 6 and Jai. X. 7. 1-2. The several organs and parts are taken out of the ukha and spread over a large bamboo vessel (varda-patrr ), the last part being placed in the north. Tho adhvarya porforms on each of the oloven limbs (called jaubava ) pranadana (vivifioation) while no pripadana is done for the portions to be offered to Sviptakft. According to ƒÄp. VII. 24. 5 only ono portion is out from the limbs meant for Svia≈£akpt. Several rules are laid down in ƒÄp. VII. 24. 6‚Äì19 about the cutting of some parts. Out of the three parts of the ontrails, one of medium thickness is out in two and placed among the daivata portions, the thinnest part being for sviptak≈üt; the medas is out in thros parts, two being put in the two srucs and the third in tbeido patra. The modas is mixed in tbe broth of the victim’s limbs. The ida is made from tho first six out of the limbs (heart &c.) and the vanisthu is the 7th. The ida is incroased by the addition of the limbs that bave no bones viz. kloman, spleen and puritat.

the sacrifioer is caturavattin or panc≈´vattin, all four or five por tions are cut off from the tail and there is no under layer (upastarana) and upper layer (abhigh√©rapa) of ajya in this case. Acoording to K√•t. VI. 9. 20 portions of the tail are offered to all devatƒÅs of patnisamyƒÅja. Vide Jai. XII. 4. 10-16 and III. 3. 20-23 on this. Ida is cut from the hairless portion of the tail for hot; and from the hairy portion for the agnidhra and the rest of the tail is handed over to the sacrificer’s wife who passes it on to the adhvaryu or some brahmana, The samitr had so far partaken of nothing, but he is now given the shoulder of the victim, but if he be not a brƒÅhma·πáa he gives it to a brahmana. They offer three sami≈ütayajus, e538 throw the barhis into fire, approach & pond ( or reservoir of water ) taking with them the spit (s√ºla ) on which the heart was roasted. Ap. VII. 27. 15 says that they carry&827 the s√ºla in such a way as not to touch it. The adhvaryu enters in the midst of the water and conceals the spit into the bottom underneath with its tip downwards with the mantra ‘thou art sorrow; give him gorrow who hateth us and whom we hate’ (Tai. S. I. 3.11. 1-2 and also with V√°j, S. VI. 22 according to K√•t. VI. 10. 3), at the same time thinking of his enemy (without taking his name ). If he does not enter water, then he may pour some water to the east of the y√ºpa and should conceal the spit at the place where the dry space and wet space meet. A≈°v. (III. 6. 25-26 ) prescribes that all the priests, the sacrificer and the wife do not touch the s√ºla after it is thrust into the earth, do not look at it, and return, each taking one after another three fuel-sticks with a mantra for each and put them on fire with & mantra for each stick one after another, after doing homage to the ahavaniya with Rg. I. 23. 23. Then they all perform m√§rjana near the concealed sƒÅla or the cƒÅtvala with ‘sumi. triy√° na √•pa osadhayah’ (Tai, S. I. 4. 45. 2 ) or according to Kat. VI. 10.5 they touch water with ‘dhƒÅmno … … sumitriya na Apah’ (Vaj. 8. VI. 22). Then they pray Varu≈Üa to free them from sin in the words ‘dhƒÅmno dhƒÅmno rƒÅjan’ (Tai, S. I. 3. 11, %), and ‘ud-uttamam’ (Tai. 8. I. 5. 11,3 ). They lay samidhs on the ahavaniya as in Varupapragh√•sa. The animal sacrifice ends with the garnsthƒÅjapa as in darsap≈´rpamƒÅsa,

History of Dharmatosira

i Ch: XIII

sacrifices are found in the texto prescribed for the attainment of such objects as prosperity, villages, eloquence &o. Tai. 8. (II. 1.1-10) refers to several such sacrifices. For example, Tai. S. II. 1. 1. 1 says ‘one who is desirous of prosperity should offer a white pasu to V√§yu; one who is desirous of a village should sacrifice an animal to Vayu Nigutvat; one who having command over speech or words is not able to speak eloquently should offer an ewe to Sarasvati’ (II. 1. 2.6). The Tai. Br. ( II. 8. 1-9 ) contains the anuv√§ky√§s and yƒÅjyƒÅs of the vapa, purodasa and havis offerings of many animal sacrifices. Ap. (XIX. 16-17) deals with kamya animal sacrifices. A≈°v. III. 7 gives the anuvaky√•s and yƒÅjyƒÅs of a group sacrifice (Aika da≈°ina) of eleven animals 2538 to Agni, Sarasvati, Soma, P≈´≈üan, Bphaspati, Vi ve Devas, Indra, Maruta, Indra-Agni, Savit, and Varu≈Üa ; while ƒÄ√°v. III, 8. 1 sets out the anuvƒÅkys and y√§jyƒÅs of eighteen animal sacrifices in addition,

Those follow the procedure of the nirudhapa≈õubandha Bacrifice and are all passed over here.

  1. The Aikadagina animal sacrifice is a special form of the animal sacrifice, for wbich Ap. XIV. 5-7 may be consulted. It follows the procedure of savaziya pabu (Jai. VIII. 1. 14). In this thero may be thirteen y≈´pas for cloven pagus or only one y√ºpa for all pa≈°us. Bleven y√ºpas are the ordinary onos, the 12th is called upasaya, the whole of which is chiselled, but is not implanted in a pit like the othors; it lies near the yupa to the south; the 13th is oalled patnƒ´vate and it is not highor then the gavel when imbedded in the ground. The y√ºpas are so arranged as to rise on the south sido i. e. the southern-most is the tallast of all. The padu tied to the p√§tnirate is meant for Traptr, bat it is lot off and ajya is offered. Jai, (II. 3. 19 ) concludes that when the Vedio toxt says “after carrying fire round the patnlvata victim, it is let off', only a special matter is laid down concerning the p√§tnfvata victim. Ho further says (in IX. 4. 56-60 ) that the djya offered is not * substitute for tho viotim, but is a separate rite in which the deity is the demo, Vide Kat. VIII. 8. 27 ff. If there bo moro yupas than one, thon the situoktras from anjana to parivyapA (surrounding with a girdlo) are all to be done on one, then on anothor and so on. Vido Jai. V. 2. 7-9.

Br 1.

CHAPTER XXXIII

AGNI≈ûTOMA2529

Sacrifices are often divided for convenience into ieti, pasu and soma. Acoording to Gaut. VIII, 21 and Lat. Sr. V. 4. 24 there are seven forms of some sacrifices, viz. Agni≈ütoma, Atyagnistoma, Ukthya, Sodasin, VƒÅjapeya, Atiratra and Aptor yƒÅma. The Agni≈ütoma is the model (prakrti) of all soma sacrifices. The Agnistoma is a one day (alkƒÅbika or ekƒÅba ) sacrifice and it is an integral part of the Jyoti≈ütoma so much so that the two are often identified. Soma sacrifices are classi fied into those that are finished in one day (and so called ok√°ba ), those that are celebrated for more than one day up to twelve (and so called ahina ), those that extend over more than twelve days ( and are called Sattra ). The dvƒÅda≈õaha is both & sattra and an absna.8530 The Jyotistoma ocoupies generally five days and the chief rites performed on these days are: (1) choosing of priests, madhuparka, dik≈üaniye»ôti, consecration of the sacrificer (dik≈üƒÅ ); (2nd day) PrƒÅyapiya i≈üti ( i. e, opening i≈üti ), purchase of soma, atitheyesti ( i≈ü√ßi offering hospitality to Boma ), Pravargya 2581 Upasad ( homage twice a day in the morning and evening); (3rd day) Pravargya and Upabad twice again ; (4th day) Pravargya and Upasad, Agniprapayana, Agnisomapranayana, havirdhƒÅna-pranayana, animal sacrifice; (5th day called sutya or savaniya) pressing of soma, offering it and drinking it in the morning, mid-day and evening, the udayaniga (concluding i≈üti), avabh»ôtha (final purificatory bath). In the following pages only a skeleton outline of

History of Dharmal√§stra

(Ch. IXXIII

Agni≈ütoma is presented, derived from the principal ≈öreuta s√§tras, Jai. in VI. 2. 31 declares that the performance of Jyoti≈ütoma is obligatory on all members of the three higher varpas, just as upanayana is, since the word brahmana in Tai. 8. VI. 3. 10.5 (a brahmana when born comes charged with three debts ) is only illustrative. Agni≈ütoms is so called because in it Agni is praised or because the last chant ( stotra ) is addressed to Agni.8878 It is to be performed in vasanta ( spring ) every year and on the New Moon or Full Moon day (Ap. X. 2. %, 5 and 8, Kat. VII. 1. 4 and Sat. VII. 1 p. 562 ). The general view ex pressed in Jai. IV. 3. 37 was that one should perform & soma sacrifice after baving performed darsap≈´r≈ÜamƒÅsa, cƒÅturmƒÅgyas and pa≈°u sacrifice, but some held that it could be performed even before darka-p√ºrnamƒÅsa, but after agnyadhana (A√∏v. IV. 1. 1-% and Sat. VII. 1. p. 556 ). Jai. (V, 4.5-9) also states this As the view of some. Jaimini, however, declares that all modi fioations of the Agnigtoma must be performed after one has begun to perform darsap≈´rpamƒÅsa ( V. 4. 26 ). The intending sacrificer sends a person called somapravƒÅka ( inviter to officiate at a soma sacrifice) to invite brƒÅhma·πáas who are thorough masters of the Veda, neither too young nor too old, with clear and loud voices and not deficient in any limb (Tapdya Br. 1 1.1, Dr√°hy√¢yapa ≈ör. I. 1. 10, Ap. X. 1. 1). He invites the principal four or all the 16 (or 17, including sadasya') priests ( stvrij ), who make inquiries whether some other person has refused the office and whether the fee will be excellent. Those portions of the choosing mantras are uttered inaudibly wherein the priests are invoked as if they were divinities and the portion asau mƒÅnu≈üa·∏• or tvam mƒÅnu ≈üah is uttered loudly, 4518 When the priests come madhuparku is offered to them. The sacrificer goes to the king ( of the country ) to ask for a sacrifi. cial ground ( devayajana ), even if he has one already, with the formula’god Varu≈Üa, give me devayajana , 25%* This is a mere

Agniƒôtoma-Devayajana

1135

form, but even the king has to make a similar request (in his case ) to the hots and other priests. The requirements of a proper devayajana have already been given above (p. 988n). In the western portion of the devayajana from which all roots are uprooted, & pavilion 1535 (vimita, & four-cornered mandapa ) is erected, the central ridge and the covering bamboos of whicb run from west to east, which has doors ( two oubits wide ) in all directions and which slightly inclines towards the east, or a rectangular house (≈°ala ) may be built, twenty aratnis long and ten aratnis wide ( Kat. VII. 1. 19-25, ƒÄp. X. 5. 1-5, Baud. VI. 1). A shed for cooking the vrata food is erected to the south of the pavilion and another to the west for the patni ( wife of the sacrificer). The sacrificer while in his house implants his g√•rbapatya and abavaniya fires on the ara·∫°is with a mantra “ayam te yonih’( VƒÅj. 8. III. 14., Tai. S. I. 5.2), comes to the devayajapa, enters ( along with the priests and bis wife ) the mandapa by the eastern door with the granis in his hand, and touches the central post of the pavilion. The things that are required ( sambhƒÅra·∏• ) 8586 are also brought to the pavilion. In the pavilion a vedi is prepared and fires are establisbed after being produced by attrition. Offerings of ajya with the sam bharayajus formulas (Tai. A. III. 8), with the sapta-hot, formulas (Tai. A. III. 5) are made and also & y√ºpabuti is offered. Outside the pavilion to its north the sacrificer gets the hair on the head, arm-pits and on the face out by a barber in a tont covered with mata, pares the nails of his hands first of the right band first from the small finger) and then of the feet. Jal. ( III. 8. 3-11 ) establishes that it is the sacrificer (and not the adhvaryu ) who pares his nails, cuts his hair, brushes his teeth, subsists on milk. Sat. VII. 1. p. 587 states that the nails of the left hand are pared first and then of the right hand. He brushes his teeth with an udumbara twig, then he bathes in & reservoir of water or in 8 kunda after putting a golden piece in it with mantras, performs doamana and drinks water as a consecration,
