History of Dharmasastra

(Ch. XXXIII

All these from paring nails (oalled apsu-dik≈üi ) 18 except the cutting of hair are also undergone by the wife at the instance of the pratiprasth√§tƒô priest (but without mantras ). The adhvaryu hands over a fine silken fresh garment to the gaori fioer which the latter wears. In the afternoon in the pr√°gvamsa he partakes of food (rice ) #588 mixed with ghee and sprinkled over with ourds and honey or whatever iso liked by him. The wife also does the game. He takes up butter (navanita ) with two bunches of darbha grass and smears himself thrice with them beginning from the face. He applies collyrium with a darbha blade twice to the right eye and once to the left or thrice to both. The adhvaryu performs the purification (pavana) of the sacrificer outside the pr√§gvarsa to its north by three bunches of geven darbhas esch rubbed twice over his body above the navel and once below the navel with mantras and the sacrificer algo mutters mantras. The wife also does all this (smearing the body with butter, applying a√±jana and purifica tion) without mantras at the instance of the pratiprasth√§tr. The sacrificer enters the pavilion by the eastern door and the wife by the western and ocoupy their respective seats. Then follows diksapiya i≈üti 8539 whioh is so called because it effects & samsk√§ra in the man intending to sacrifice and because after it is performed he is entitled to be called ‘dik≈üita’. The conolu alon in Jai. V. 3. 29-31 is that a man becomes a dik≈üita at the end of the dik≈üapiya i≈üti and has thenoeforward to observe the rules laid down for √• dik≈üita and that one does not become a dik≈üita by being given the staff or the girdle &o. At first six abutis called dik≈üƒÅhutis are offered, four with djya taken from the dhruva into the sruva, 5th with the bruo and the sixth is oalled p√°rpabuti and is offered with sruo (in which twelve ladl ings with aruva have been made ). Thege six abutis are called * audgraha≈Üa ‘( Ap. X. 8.7 and com. on Sat. VII. 1. p. 591 ) or ‘audgrabhana’( Kat. VII. 3. 16 ). In the dik≈üapiya i≈üti a cake

prepared on eloven potsherds is offered to. Agni-Vi≈ünu ( or boiled rice with olarified butter). Some offered another offering of boiled ribe to Aditi. Several matters that occur in the model i≈üti (such as observing & vrata, the girding up of the wife, outting off & portion for yojamƒÅna, phalikaranahoma, cooking anv√§hƒÅrya rice as fee for the priesta, sami≈ütayajus) are omitted in this i≈üti (Baud. VI. 3 mentions ten matters that are omitted, Ap. X. 4. 12, Sat. VII. 1. p. 575). According to Jai. VIII. 1. 3-10 the several actions done in the model i≈üti are not to be extended to somayƒÅga unless the vedio texts expressly say 80, and Jai. X. 1.4 establishes that there is no ƒÅrambhaniya i≈üti in dik≈üanlyd and other i≈ütis of somayƒÅga, The dik≈üanly, onds with the patnisamyƒÅjas and the eating of the 2nd idƒÅ (Sat. VII. 1. p. 578). Certain rules are laid down about the pitch of the voice in the several rites. According to Ap. X. 4. 9 everything is said inaudibly till the agnisomlya rite. According to KƒÅt. (VII. 2. 31-32) the voice reaches the highest pitch in the dik≈üaniya i≈üti, the mantras in the prƒÅyaniya and atithyƒÅ i≈ütis are in a lower tone than in the dik≈üanlyi and the upasad mantras are repeated inaudibly. The dik≈üƒÅ (consecration) of the sacrificer and his wife proceeds as follows.a540 To the south of the dhavaniya two black antelope hides (or one if two are not available) with the neck portion to the east are spread on the altar with the hairy part outside. He (the priest ) site to the west of the antelope skin bending his right knee; the saori ficer touches the white and black spots (or the line that joins them, Kat. VII. 3. 23), then creeps upon the hide with bis right knee bent and sits down on the western side of the hide. The sacrificer ties round his waist above the garment worn by him a girdle of three strands made of hemp and mu√±ja grass, covers his right shoulder with a fresh garment and folds round his head a piece of cloth, he is given the horn of a black ante lope about & span in length with three or five folds (from left to right), which he ties to the hem of his garment (or in the corner of his upper garment). He touches his forehead above the right brow with the horn, draws a line with it from west to east outside the vedi, and if he wants at any time to soratch

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Oh. XXXIII

his body he does so with that horn. Jai. (XI. 4. 48-49 ) declares that the mantra is to be repeated only once even if the yajamƒÅna feels the desire to scratch several parts of his body at the same time. The adhvaryu gives & staff of udum bara ( or of some other sacrificial tree) which is as high as the sacrificer’s mouth (or ohin), which he raises up and keeps on his right shoulder. While the adhvaryu is doing these things for the yajamƒÅna, the pratiprasthƒÅtr does the same things for the wife (without mantras ) except that she has the yoktra girt round her upper garment, that her head is covered by a jala (& net or fillet) of wool and she has a piece of some sacri fioial tree one span long for scratching her body. The sacri ficer and adhvaryu repeat long passages wherein the word dik≈ü√¢ occurs frequently (Ap. X. 10, 6 and X. 11, 1), and the adhvaryu makos him repeat the sambhƒÅra-yajus mantras (Tai. ƒÄ, III.8). The sacrificer then contracts the fingers of both hands one after another with mantras (first the small fingers of both hands, then the ring-fingers of both hands and so on) and ultimately he olinches his fists. He observes silence. Some priest ( like the pratiprasthƒÅts) other than the adhvaryu inaudi. bly declares ( to the gods ) thrice and loudly proolaims to the world thrice ‘this brƒÅhma·πáa has undergone the consecration, son of so and so, grandson of so and so, great-grandson of so and go, the son of such and such a woman, grandson of such and such a woman and great-grandson of such and such a woman’. Even when the sacrificer was a k≈üatriya or vaisya, the announcement was still to be ‘this brƒÅbma≈Üa 3541 &c.,’ since after dik≈üƒÅ & person was supposed to be reborn and to be a child of holy prayer and to have become pure enough for receiving spiritual influences. The Sat. Br. III. 3. 3. 12 states “he who is consecrated becomes an embryo’. Dik≈üƒÅ takes place in the afternoon (Ap. X. 12. 1) and the sacrificer observes silence till the appearance of stars in the evening. The adhvaryu directs the milking of two cows to supply milk for

Ch. XXXIII)

Agnistona-observances of dik≈üita

1139

the sacrificer and his wife who are to subsist on the milk of the two cows during the period of the sacrifice. This vrata (obser Vance) of subsisting on milk is deolared by Jai. ( IV. 3. 8-9) to be kratvartha (an obligatory rule) and not puru≈üƒÅrtha (recommendatory ). Vide also Jai. VI. 8. 28. Some allowed rice or barley to be cooked in that milk. The two cows were milked in two separate vessels, one of which (meant for the sacrificer) was heated on the g√§rhepatya and the other (for the wife ) was heated on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire. A k≈üatriya or vaibya sacrificer could take gruel or amik≈üƒÅ respectively or all persons could subsist on milk or on rice cooked in milk or on fruits ( if enough milk was not available) or if he had a desire for ourds, he could use ourds or use fried barley grains or he could take ghee. He was to take his food at midday or midnight long after ordinary men have taken their meals and he took his food from a pot which was not earthenware and the wife from a copper pot. Persons who were not dik≈üitas were not to see him when taking his milk or other vrata diet. The wife was also to take her milk or other diet in her own place. Vide Ap. X. 16 and K√§t. VII. 4. 19-34 for details. The dik≈üita and his wife ( to some extent) have to observe certain rules ( till the final bath ) and people also had to observe some rules with reference to him. He has to keep awake on the night of the dik≈üƒÅ (Jai. XII. 1. 17), on the night when soma is purchased and on the night before the pressing day. He is not *543 to speak with women or s≈´dras nor should a g≈´dra follow him. If he is obliged to speak to a s≈´dra he should do so by employing a messenger belonging to the three higher varnas. He may speak to or bless another, but he was not to bow to another, even if the latter was his ƒÅcƒÅrya or father-in law or a king. No one was to touch him or to address the dik≈üita by his name ( but use only such terms of address as ‘bhoh’, dik≈üita' &c.). The sacrificer was not to keep aside the antelope horn till the fees were distributed. He could laugh covering his face with his hand and should not show his teeth. He was not ordinarily to answer calls of nature by day, but if he has to do so, he must do so in & shaded spot. He has to observe complete colibacy. While he is consecrated for the sacrifice, he does not go out by the

  1. Ap. X, 12-15, Baud. VI. 6 give long lists of the observances for a dƒ´ksita out of which a few are set out above.

1140

History of DharmajƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

western door, nor does he perform the daily agnihotra, nor Vai≈°vadeva nor offering of bali nor perform the dar≈õap≈´rpamƒÅsa i≈üti (Jai. XII. 1. 19-23 ), but he may employ another to do all these. He must speak the truth and address people in a pure and conciliatory style adding the word ‘canasita’ when address ing a brƒÅhma·πáa and the word ‘vicak≈üa≈Üa ‘wben addressing & ksatriya or vaisya (vide Ait. Br. I. 6). He must always be in the pavilion at sunrise and sunget; he sleeps on the ground to the south of the ƒÅhavaniya with his head to the east and sleeps on his right side and does not turn his back to the fire. He always sits on antelope hide and never leaves it and his staff (except when answering calls of nature). No one is to eat the food given by a dik≈üita till the agni≈üomlya victim or its omentum is offered. It is recommended by all the s≈´tras that dik≈üƒÅ (consecration) should not be finished in one day, but it should extend over 12 days or a month or a year or till from being fat he becomes lean ( vide ƒÄp. X. 14. 8, X. 15. 4, A≈°v, IV. 2. 13‚Äì15 ). Every day (while the diskƒÅ lasts ) the sacrificer observes silence from the afternoon till the appearance of stars and in the morning from before sunrise till the sun goes up. The dik≈üita is allowed to go himself or to send agents called ( sanihƒÅra ) 2543 to colleat money and materials necessary for the sacrifice. He has to observe many rules on his journey ( vide Ap. X. 19, 6-16 ).

After the day (or da ys of dik≈üa), the next day the first rite is the prƒÅyapiyƒÅ 2544 (opening) isti. In this i≈üti caru (rice ) cooked in milk is offered to Aditi (Jai. IX. 4. 32-40) and four offerings of ƒÅjya to four more deities viz. PathyƒÅ Svasti, Agni, Soma and Savity in the four directions ( viz, east, south, west and north ) respectively. Caru is offered to Aditi in the centre. Agni Svi≈õtakst is the sixth deity. According to Asv. IV. 3.3 po ajyabhƒÅgas are offered in this i≈üti, but according to KƒÅt. VII. 5. 15 they are offered. The priests that officiate in this i≈üti should as far as possible officiate in the Udayaniga (concluding ) i≈üti. The rites of this i≈üti end with the first Samyu, 6545 but there is no patni.samyƒÅja and no gami≈ütayajus.

  1. ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∑‡§æ Fara HAPERT HET 1974. X. 18. 4-5, vide yt. VII. 5. 3-4.

Ch. XXXIII)

Agniƒôtoma-PrƒÅyaniyƒÅ i≈üti

¬∑ 1141

The puronuv√§ky√• vorges in this i≈üti become the yƒÅjyd verses in the udayaniya i≈üti and vice versa ( vide A≈õv. IV.3.2 for them). He keeps aside in a well-known place in the prƒÅguarnsa the cooking pot (from which the leavings of rios sticking to the bottom are not removed according to some ), the mek≈üane and the barhis (except the prastara ) for use in the udayaniya. Jai. (XI. 2. 66-68 ) refers to this use of ni≈ükisa in the udaya niya i≈üti.

Then comes the purchase of soma (referred to in the BrƒÅhma·πáas and S≈´tras as rƒÅjan ‘). Soma is purchased from a brƒÅhmana of the Kutsa gotra or from a s≈´dra (Ap. X. 20. 12 allows it to be purchased from any brƒÅbmana ). 3546 Jai. III. 7. 31 states that the vendor of soma is someone other than the priests. The seller of soma is asked to free it from the weeds that may be mixed up with it; the adhvaryu turns his back towards soma when this ( weeding ) is being done and neither the adhvaryu nor his assistants nor the sacrificer nor the latter’s sons should do the weeding out nor does anyone of these see it being done (Sat. VII. 1, p. 609). The some plant is placed on the southern part of the red hide of a bull by the pratiprasthƒÅtr spread on the place where uparavas (four sound ing holes) will be made later on and the seller of some sits on the northern part of the hide. A water jar is placed in front of soma. The doors of the sacrificial hall are shut, the adhvaryu pours into the jub≈´ four times ƒÅjya from the dhruvƒÅ ladle used in the prayapiya (or five times for those who are pa√±ca vattins), ties & piece of gold by a blade out of the darbhas spread on the altar, puts down into the juh≈´ the blade with the gold and makes an offering into the alavaniya of that ajya ( this offering is called hiranyavati abuti ); he takes out the piece of gold, casts the blade ( with wbich it was tied) on the vedi and ties the gold piece with a thread. The doors of the hall are opened and the adhvaryu and yajamƒÅna coine out. To the south of the eastern door of the sacrificial hall stands a heifer (called somakrayani), that is one, two or three

History of Dharmainstra

[ Ch. XXXIII

years 8547 old, is tawny, has yellowish brown eyes or is red (but has no red eyes), has not given birth to a calf, has no deficiency and is not tied ( vide Ap. VI. 20.2-5 and Sat. VII. 2, p. 623 for further details). The cow is not held by her ear or her foot is not tied by a rope ( she may be held by the neck, if necessary). She is invoked by the adhvaryu ( who is sitting ) with a mantra *oidasi’(Vaj. S. IV.19, Tai. 8. 1.2.4.1). The cow is led towards the north, the adhvaryu and yajamana follow her. After she goes six steps, at her 7th step, the brahma and yajamƒÅna sit down to the cow’s right, behind her sits the adhvaryu and the nest priest to her north. They keep the golden piece on the spot where the 7th step is put by her (which is first covered with his folded hands by the adhvaryu ) and make an offering of it to Aditi ( adityai idam na mama ). Taking the sphya the adhvaryu draws lines round the 7th foot-print (once with a mantra, twice silently ) from right to left (Ap. X. 23. 3 adds that lines are drawn also with the antelope horn of the sacri ficer); the dust on the lines is gathered with the hand and put into a pot ( sthall ) and handed over to the yajamƒÅna who passes it on to his wife who invokes the cow with a mantra. He washes his hand ( that has the piece of gold in it) on the 7th foot-print ( of the cow ), pours some water on the dust colleoted in a pot, divides the dust into three parts, one of which is placed on the cold ashes of the g√•rbapatya, the 2nd on the cold ashes of the ahavaplya and the third is given to the wife who places it in the house. The adhvaryu ties the piece of gold to his small finger (on which it must be at the time of ƒÅpyƒÅyana and pres sing of soma and at the time of taking the amsu and adabhya oups ). The adhvaryu directs the sacrificer’s servant to bring & piece of cloth for tying soma, another for covering it all round and a turban; the first is carried by the adhvaryu or yajamƒÅna and the rest by the pratiprasthƒÅts. They go with their faces to the east towards the soma which is in a four-wheeled cart

( Continued from last page) gives rules about the accents of the Subrabmanya, According to Lat. and Drilydyana 1. 3. 17 the subrahmapya litanies after the u pasads are finished are recited near the utkara outside the altar. On the Agoypomiya day (day before pressing ) before the reference to sutyd, the words asau yajate’ (this, so and so, offers saorifico ) ocour and the naines :( n√§kpatra, gotra and vyƒÅvabarika namos ) of the sacrificer are mentioned with the names of his ances tors (son of bo and so, grandson of 80 and 80, great-grandson of so and 80 ) and then the names of bis living descendants according to seniority by birth, both males and females, in the words * fatber of such and such a son &.‘Manu IX. 126 refers to this last. History of Dharmasastra

[ Ch. XXXIII

many days, to the soma feast.’ Then he adds. Ye Gods and br√•bma≈Üas I come bither.’ While the Subrahmanya is being recited the sacrificer mutters certain prayers (Ap. X. 28.5). Near the eastern door of the pr√§gvamsa the pratiprasthƒÅtr stands holding by the ear a goat ( as a present to king Soma ) that has white and dark spots of hair or red and dark ones, that is hornless, fat and bearded. The cart is stopped to the east of the prƒÅgvarea with its shafts to the east or north, the yoke-pins are taken out, the oxen are released from the yoke (or only one ox, the northern one, is released). While this is being done prepa rations are made for atithyesti to receive hospitably as a guest king Soma. The adhvaryu and three other priests make ready a stool or couch (√§gandi) of udumbara wood, having feet as high as the navel, with a board one aratni square plaited with cords of mu√±ja grass, on which a black antelope skin is spread. On this the goma is placed after being taken out of the cart. Soma thus geated on the couch is brought inside the sala by the eastern door, is taken to the west of the ƒÅbavaniya and established to the south of the ahavaniya to the east of the seat of the brabmƒÅ priest. Then follows the work of atithyesti. The wife quickly takes out the materials for a cake on nine potsherds for Vi≈ünu ( who is the principal deity in this i≈üti). In all i≈ütis (in Agnistoma ) after the dik≈üaply√§ up to udayaniyƒÅ ( the concluding i≈üti ) there is no agnyany√°dbana, no taking up of vrata, no subsisting on fast food, no gifts and no choosing of brahma. There are only five praydja offerings and no anuyƒÅjas. 3851 Fire is produced by attrition, and the i≈üti comes to an end after the first idƒÅ. For details see Ap. X. 30 and Kat. VIII. 1. After the ida is eaten there is t√§n≈´naptra, a solemn convenant made by the sacrificer and the priests pledging themselves in the name of Tan√ªnapat (the mighty blowing wind, that is the witness of all living beings) not to injure each other. They make this*552 covenant by touching simultaneously clarified butter taken in & vessel of kamsya or in & camasa from the ajya in the dhruva ladle used in the atithy. and placed on the southern hip (south corner of west side ) of the altar. That clarified butter used for this covenant is shaken by the adhvaryu and is kept by him in a vessel (which is not earthen-ware) in a well-known spot

  1. Vide Jaimini X. 7. 38-39 and 40 for the proposition that there are no unayajƒ± offoringa in Stithyep≈£i and that it ends with ide.

Ch. XXXIII

Agniƒôtoma-avƒÅntaradik≈üƒÅ

1147

and is given mixed with the fast milk (vrate-dugdha ) to the saorificer in the afternoon (for eating ). Then follows the ayantara-dik≈üƒÅ (intermediate consecration) of the sacrificer, in which he offers a fuel-stick in the ahavaniya fire ( with ‘agne vratapƒÅs. Vaj. 8. V. 6), the wife also silently offers a fuel-stick in g√•rhapatya; he touches water heated in a vegsel called madanti, clenches his fists more closely, tightens his girdle and drinks only hot milk. All priests also touch the madanti water and together with the sacrificer strengthen*552 the soma stalks with their hands holding golden pieces with the mantra ‘am√°ur-amsu’ ( VƒÅj. S.V.7, Tai. S. 1.2. 11. 1). Then they place their right hands one after another on the prestara which is on the southern end of the vedi with the palms turned upwards and cover the palms with their left palms turned downwards (this action being called nihnaya, aocording to Ap. XI. 1. 12 and K√§t. VIII, 2. 9). Nihnava 8554 is a kind of salutation to Heaven and Earth.

Then follows Pravargya and after that Upasad or the Upasad may precede Pravargya (Ap. XI. 2. 5, Sat. VII, 4. p. 662). Both are done twice, in the morning and then in the afternoon, for at least three days ( 2nd, 3rd and 4th) if soma is to be pressed on the 5th, but if soma is to be pressed on the 7th or any later day (from the beginning ) then there will be more Pravargyas and Upuseds.2555 The same barhis, prastara and paridhis employed in the √§tithyƒÅ are used in the upasads and in the rite of Agni≈üomlya pa≈°u.

Pravargya is separately dealt with in most s≈´tras, as in Ap. XV. 5-12, Kat. XXVI, Baud. IX. 6 ff. It was supposed to provide the sacrificer with a new celestial body 8588, It was an

History of Dharmasastra

(Ch. XXXIII

Independent rite by itself (ap≈´rva ) and was not the modi fication of any other rite ( vide com, on K√§t. XXVI. %.5). It appears from Ap. XIII, 4, 3-5 that the Pravargya rite was not necessarily performed in every Agnigtoma. The gbarma is styled Samrat in Vaj. S. 39.5, is identified with the sun, is said to be the head of Yaj√±a and the hot milk was divine life and light. Vide Ait. Br. IV. 1, Sat. Br. XIV. 1-4, Tai. Ar. IV. 1-4%. V. 1-12; and Haug’s translation of Ait. Br. pp. 41-43 ( note ), S. B. E vol. 44, Intro. XLVI-L. An earthernware veseel, one span in height, is made, the middle of which is contracted ( like a mortar ), whiob has a rim or belt (mekhala ) about three fingers lower down from the top which is & large and deep bowl and has at the end a hole or spout for pouring in liquid, This is called mabƒÅvira and it resembles three pots placed on one another. There are two other earthenware vessels ( which are called mahavira). There are also two milking bowls ( pin vana ) and two round plates called raubi≈Üa for baking two cakes. All the three are heated with the fire of horse dung kindled at the g√§rhapatya ( or dak≈üi≈Üa according to some ) fire, baked in a square pit like ordinary, pans and tben taken out. The two purodƒÅsas baked on the round rauhi≈Ü88 are offered into fire in the morning and evening to Day and Night respectively. The vessel called mabƒÅvira is placed on a raised clay platform and fire is kindled round it, and when it is hot ghee is poured into it. The principal mabƒÅyira is the first vessel and the other two are not to have the different processes performed on them (they are apracaraniya, Ap. XV. 6. 11). These other two are kept covered with cloth on the big √§gandi to the north of the stool on which soma is placed and to the south of the ƒÅhavaniya (Kat. XXVI. 2. 17). To the boiling ghee in the principal vessel are added the milk of a cow and of a she-goat having a male young one. The hot milk thus mixed and contained in the mah√§vira is called ‘gharma’, of whioh offerings are made to Asvins, VƒÅyu, Indra (with Vasus and Rudras and Aditya. ), to Savits, B»õbaspati, Yama. The sacrificer drinks ( the priests only smell ) the remainder by the upayamapl. The hot; repeats Beveral mantras at various stages from the time the mahƒÅyira is placed on the raised platform up to the time when the hot milk is offered and the priest called prastotƒô chants s√§mans. The whole of this ceremony is called Pravargya. A few interesting matters out of the numerous details of this rite are indicated here. All the doors of the sacrificial hall are screened with cloth, the wife’s shed also is so screened and she is to sit in her

Ch. XXXIII )

Agni≈ütoma-Pravargya

1149

shed (and not to see the mahavira,8887 but at a later stage sbe looks at it and repeats & mantra, Kat. XXVI. 4,13). Whatever wooden p√§tras are required in this rite they are 588 made of udumbara and the cords are made of mu√±ja grass. The paridhis were thirteen and of vikankata and the fuel-sticks for boiling the gharma were to be of the same wood or of khadira, palƒÅ≈°a, udumbara and a few other trees. There were three black antelope skins to be used as fans and two rukmas (plates or bars) of gold and silver, two vedas ( bunches of kuga), one of which has its ends cut off. Special rules are laid down about the clay out of which the mahavira vessel is to be made ( vide Ap. XV.1. 9 ff.) viz. 558 it was to be dug from a pit to the east of the ƒÅbavaniya fire; with that earth was to be mixed the dust dug by & wild boar and the clay from an ant-hill, p≈´tika ( a plant), the bair of a goat and of a black antelope skin; on it an aja ( she-goat) was to be milked. The clay so mixed is to be carried only by men of the higher castes and hot water is to be poured on the clay only from madanti vessels 8560 in order to mix the various ingredients. No s≈´dra nor woman is to look at all this. Two Vessels for milking the cow and the she-goat are made of this very clay. The Mahavira is to be lifted up only with two wooden pieces like tongs (called paris√§sa or sapha ) and never otherwise. The asandi ( stool or chair ) on which the mahƒÅvira is to be placed is bigger than the one for king Soma ( thereby bringing out its super-eminence as samr√§t) and it is placed north of the seat for Soma. [Oh. XXXIII

sand) are made to the north of the g√•rhapatya and of the ƒÅbavanlya and a third mound ( oalled ucchi≈üta khara ) is made in the north-east of the pr√§gvarsa, having a channel outside (the sala) for wiping off the leavings. A silver blade or plate of one hundred raktƒ±kƒÅs (berries for weighing ) in weight is inserted in the loose sand of the western mound, sheaths of reed grase kindled at the garbapatya are thrown on the mound and the maha vira vessel is placed thereon. Then pieces of vikankata wood (paridhis) are laid round the MahƒÅ vira by the adhvaryu and pratiprasth√§te, in all 13, the last being placed by the adhvaryu. Then a gold bar or plate (representing the Sun) is placed on the MahƒÅvira pot. The adhvaryu fans the fire thrice by means of the three fans made of black antelope skin from right to left and then thrice from left to right. When a blaze is produced the gold plate is taken away. According to the Ait. Br. IV.2 and Asv. IV. 6. 3. the hotf recites several verges ( 21 in number ) when the empty Mab√§vira is being hented (they constitute the p≈´rva patala) and several operations such as anointing it are being performed. The Ait, Br. IV. 5 further prescribes 21 verses for recitation by the hots when the cow is being milked (they are called uttara patala). Vide Asv. IV.7. 4 also.

According to Sat. Br. XIV. 2. 2. 44-46 and Jai. III. 3. 32-33 the Pravargya was not to be performed at a sacrificer’s first soma sacrifice and it was not to be performed for anyone and everyone, but only for him who was well-known or was & com plete master of the veda. On the day previous to the soma pressing day, the two performances of pravargya and upasad are combined and gone through in the morning and on that day takes place the ' udv√•gana ' ( setting out or orderly discharge ) of the pravargys either by laying out the pravargya apparatus in the form of a human body or by throwing them in the midst of water or in a river island &o. They ( the priests and yaja m√•na ) set out as a general rule ( Ap. XV. 16. 6 ) all the imple ments on the uttaravedi, the prinoipal mahƒÅ vira vegbel as the head is placed close to the front side of the navel of the uttara. vedi, the two other mahƒÅyiras are placed to its east, the bunch of kusa grass ( called veda ) is placed on top of the maha vira to represent sikhƒÅ (top-knot of hair), the two lifting stioks (saphas) are placed on two sides as arms and so on. Vide Sat. Br. XIV. 3. 1. 16, Ap. XV. 15, Kat. 26.7.14 ff. According to Ap. XV. 11. 10-13 the yajam√°ns and some of the priests viz. hotf, adbvaryu, brahmƒÅ, pratprastb√°tr and agnidbra drink the remainder of the milk (gharma) from the upayamani (a large wooden spoon).

Agni≈ütoma-Pravargya

1151

When & person performs pravargys he should not for a year partake of meat, should not approach a ≈°≈´dra woman for sexual intercourse, should not drink water from an earthen pot and should not allow a s√ºdra to eat the leavings of his food ( ƒÄp. XV. 12. 13). According to Sat. Br. XIV, 3. 1. 32 ff the gold plate goes to the brahmƒÅ, the gharma to adbvaryu, while acoord. ing to Ap. XV, 13, 1 the sacrificer gives the gold and silver plates to adhvaryu, the cow to hot·ªá, the she-goat to √§gnidbra and a pregnant cow to brahmƒÅ.

Upasad50) is an i≈üti. The several processes such as agayan vadb√•na found in the darsa-p≈´r≈ÜamƒÅsa are not performed in this isti, but & start is made from the carrying forward of the pranita water. Offerings of clarified butter are made in this i≈üti to Agni and Soma with the juh≈Ø ladle and to Vi≈ünu with the juh≈Ø after pouring therein the ajya taken in the upabhrt ladle; that is, the principal deities are Agni, Soma and Vi≈ünu and that besides the abutis of ƒÅjys to these there are the upasad ƒÅbutis with the mantra ‘ya te’ &o. Vide the com. on Kat. VIII. 2. 35 for all details. All actions done after the atithya i≈üti such as the strengthening of some, the ninbava, the recital of the subrahmanya litany take place in each upasad (per formed in the morning and afternoon for three or more days). There are no ajyabhƒÅgas, no prayƒÅjas nor anuyƒÅjas and no offering to Agni Svi≈ütakst (A≈°v. IV. 8. 8.). The three yerses, Rg. History of Dharmatastra

[ Ch. XXXIII

The upagad mantras show that they have reference to the sieges of iron, silver and gold castles. How these mantras came to be inserted here it is difficult to say. Vide Sat. Br. III. 4. 4. 3-4 (for the cities and their siege). Ap. XI. 4. 8 adds that if a hostile king gives battle or attacks the capital of & k≈üatriya performing a soma sacrifice, on the first upasad a piece of iron should be placed in the aruva ladle and offered along with the clarified butter, on the 2nd upasad a piece of silver and on the 3rd a piece of gold should be so placed. The y√°jy√•s of the morning upasad become the anuvƒÅky√§s in the afternoon and vice versa. Jaimini (X. 17. 43-46) establishes that Upasads are special i≈ütis (ap≈´rva ) and only those parts that are expressly stated in the texts are to be performed in them and not others that occur in the model i≈üti. The procedure of upasad is like upƒÅm uyƒÅja (Sat. VII. 4. p. 666).

On the 2nd day of the upagads after the morning pravargya and upasad rites are performed the great vedi for the soma sacrifice is measured and made (KƒÅt. VIII. 3. 6, Sat. VII. 4. pp. 679-685 and ƒÄp. XI. 4. 11). In front of the ƒÅhavaniya to the east & peg (sanku) is driven in the ground at a distance of 6 prakramas (Baud. VI. 2%) or according to KƒÅt. VIII. 3.7 at the distance of 3 prakramas to the east from the eastern post ( i. e. the middle of the door) of the ordinary agni-sala a peg is driven which is called antaƒßp≈´tya (intermediate ) or talƒÅmukhiya (according to Baud.); 36 prakramas to the east from this peg another peg is driven, which is called yupƒÅvatiya (1. o. connected with the hole for y√ºpa). A cord is stretched between these two pegs and is called prsthya (spine). On both the south and north sides of the first peg (i. e. of antahpatya) pegs are driven at the distance of 15 prakramas and on the south and north sides of the 2nd peg two pegs are driven at & diatance of 12 prakramas each. In this way the west side called fro≈Üi ( hips ) of the mahƒÅvedi is 30 prakramas 3563 and the

Ch. XXXIII)

Agnistoma-MahƒÅvedi

1153

east side called arsa ( shoulders ) is 24 prakramas and the length of the mabƒÅ vedi is 36 prakramas. A rope is passed all round the mabƒÅvedi. Almost all the samsk√§ras that are performed for the vedi in dar≈õap≈´r≈ÜamƒÅsa are performed for the great vedi in somayaga (Sat. VII. 4. p. 685 ). An uttaravedi (a quadrangular platform raised high ) is measured on the mahƒÅvedi in its eastern part. This uttarayedi is on its west side ( ≈õro≈Üi) ten padas ( i. e. five on the south and five on the north of the prsthyƒÅ) and on its east side (ansa) eight padas ( some hold that the uttaravedi is 10 padas on all sides i. e. a perfect square ). The c√£tvƒÅla pit ( i. e. its southern shoulder or the middle point of the southern side ) is 15 padas ( or one prakrama, according to Sat. P. 687) to the north from the northern shoulder of the mahƒÅvedi towards the west, while the utkara near which the √§gnidhra sits is 12 prakramas to the west of the cƒÅtvƒÅla *584 ( i. e. its western side or its middle ) and one prakrama to the north of the line of the vedi. The utkara is about two padas in extent (com. on Sat. VII. 4. p. 687). The way to and from the vedi la between the utkara and the c√£tvƒÅla pit. The vedi is prepared ( i. e. its earth is loosened, clods are broken, roots taken out) with the sphya, a rib (of some holy animal) or an axe. For the n√§bbi vide at p. 1113 above. That day the vedi remains covered with the branches of uduinbara or plaksa tree.

On the next day both the pravargyas and upasads of the morning and afternoon are gone through in the morning. After the udvƒÅsana of the pravargya, the bringing forward of the fire ( agnipranayana ) from the √§havaniya to the uttaravedi takes place. The fire placed on the nƒÅbhi becomes the ƒÅhavaniya for all actions in the soma sacrifice and the original dhavaniya becomes the gƒÅrbapatya (Ap. XI. 5. 9-10). Kusa grass, the fuel and vedi are thrice sprinkled with water and the vedi is covered with that grass with the points of the blades to the east. Two carts, washed with water, with their yokes tightly bound but with no yoke-pins, are brought round from the agnisala and placed in the mahƒÅvodi, one about one cubit (aratni ) to the south of the prsthya line and the other to the north about one cubit. The cart to the south ( called dak≈°i≈Üa-havirdhƒÅna ) is larger than the one to the north and the shafts of both are towards the east. These carta are called havirdhana because

  1. For the otv√•la vida p. 984 above.

  2. D. 1451154

History of Dharmasastra

[ Oh. XXXIII

the some plant (which is the havis in somayƒÅga) is to be placed thereon. 2565 The south and north carts are respectively in charge of the adhvaryu and pratiprasthƒÅtr. They are then covered with grass mats or thatch made of split bamboos. A mandapa (called bavirdbƒÅna-mapdapa ) is erected by having six posts in front of the two carts and six behind them and having two bamboos on the posts from south to north. He suspends from the front part of the mandape & garland-like sheaf of twisted grass (rarƒÅti). Various samskƒÅras are performed on the axles of the carts by the wife and pratiprasth√§tr respec tively. Detailed rules about covering the carts and similar matters are passed over (Ap. XI. 7-8, KƒÅt. VIII. 4). The havirdhana ma≈Üdapa is higher in the east than in the west and has two doors one to the east and the other to the west (Sat. VII. 4. p. 701 ). No one is to take his meals or even to eat idƒÅ inside the havirdhƒÅna mapdapa. The adhvaryu digs four round holes ( in two rows, two in each row ) below the fore part of the shafts of the southern cart (but not far from the axlo), each hole being about one span in diameter, being at a distance of one span from each and all being connected by cross-way subterranean pagsages. They are one arm deep. They are dug in such an order that the hole to the north-east is the last (i. e. first south-east one is dug, then north-west one is dug, then south-west and then north-east or first north-west orie, then south-east, then south-west and lastly north east). On these holes are spread kuƒ£a blades over which two wooden boards ( adhi≈üa vana-phalaka) are placed over which is spread the red skin of a bull (adhi≈üavana carma), on which soma juice is extracted by means of four stones. These holes add to the noise of the stones by the sound reverberating through them and they are therefore called uparava.45*Jai. (XI. 4.52-53 ) states that the mantra ‘rakso ha≈Üo’ is to be repeated at each time when & hole is dug and not only once for all holes. The adhvaryu and the sacrificer

Ch. XXXIII 1

Agni≈ütoma-uparavas

1155

insert their right hands in the holes (the adhvaryu inserting his hand in the south-east hole and the sacrificer in the north west and then a second time the adhvaryu inserts bis hand in the south-west hole and the sacrificer in the north-east) and touch each other’s hands and adhvaryu asks sacrificer, what is there?;’ the sacrificer replies welfare (or happiness )’ and the adhvaryu in a low voice says ‘may that belong to us both.’ This is done twice ( K√§t. VIII. 5. 14-21). At the second time the yajamƒÅna asks ‘adhvaryu! what is there ?’, the adhvaryu replies' welfare' and the yajamƒÅna gays ‘let it be mine.’ The uparavas are sprinkled with water beginning from the south east one and ending with the north-east one with a mantra (*raksohano &o.' VƒÅj. S. V. 25, Tai. S. I. 3,2). Then the rest of the prok≈üani water is poured into them, ku≈°as are spread over their bottoms as in the hole of the y√ºpa ( described above ), a golden piece is placed thereon and offering of ajya is made. To the east of the uparavas or of the adbi≈üavana-carma or of the upastambhango567 a four-cornered mound (khara) is made for keeping the soma vessels on with the earth ( dug up from the uparavas) that is sprinkled with water and mixed with sand. In front of this mound sufficient space is left to move about in the havirdhƒÅna ma≈Üdapa. To the west of the utkara at a distance of six prakramas ( which comes to about the middle of the north side of the great altar ) is prepared the shed for ƒÅgnidhra, which is half inside and half outside the great vedi, which has four posts and the beams of which run from west to east, which has & door to the south and is covered on all sides with mats. This shed is so made that its west side would be a continuation of the end of the western side of the havirdhƒÅna mapdapa and this shed is a square having sides of five aratnis each (com, on KƒÅt. VIII. 6. 13). The sadas is measured at a distance of three prakramas from the western side of the great vedi to its east and bas its length from south to north. The width of the sadas is nine aratnis (or half of its length) and its length (from south to north ) 27 aratnis or as much as would be necessary for allowing room to all the priests, their dhi≈ünyas ( seats) and the pragarpakas ( assistants and spectators). In the midst of the sadas & post of udum bara is fixed which is of the height of the sacrificer above its pit and which is placed at a distance of one prakrama to the south of the prsthy., All samsk√§ras that

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

[ Che IXXIII

are made on the y√ºpa and its pit are made in the case of this post except those referring to takala ( vide p. 1115 above ). The udumbara post has an ear-like protuberance towards the east when it is fixed in the pit. On that protuberance a gold piece is offered with the juh≈Ø and ajya is poured on in such & way that some of it will triokle to the ground. This audumbarl is thioker than any post of the sadas. The posts on the borders of the gadas are as high as the navel of the yajamƒÅna towards its sides, but in the middle they are as high as the audumbari post. On the posts of the sadas beams are placed running from south to north and west to east. The middle of one third of this is covered with three mats that have their ends to the north, and then to the south and north of the middle portion three mats (on each side) are placed in such a way that their ends are turned towards the audumbari post. The sadas is covered with nine mats in all that are well sewn together. The sadas is surrounded by screens and it has two doors to the east and west (just as the havirdb√§ns pavilion has). Some prepare the sadas first and then the uparavas or vice versa (Ap. XI. 10. 19). The doors of the pr√§gvamga, the sadas and havirdhƒÅna are so arranged ( opposite each other) that a person sitting in one of these can see into all. Then eight dhirnyas (seata ) are to be prepared. The first is made in the √§gnidbra shed in its middle in such a manner that between it and the north side of the great vedi some space will be left for moving about. Six more dhirnyas are to be made in the sadas. The earth for all these dhispyas is taken from the c√£tvala pit. The six seats are made in the eastern portion of the sadas leaving between them and the eastern side of the sadas suffi cient space to move about. The earth is spread on the seats by the adbvaryu who faces the north when preparing all the seats (except two) and who is touched by the sacrificer with the sphy&. Over the earth sand or gravel is spread on all the seats. Out of the six seats the adhvaryu facing the west makes the seat for the hotƒô to the north of the prothy, line but touching it about one prakrama from the eastern door of the Badas (or on the prothyƒÅ line itself, according to Ap. XI. 14. 4). Then four more seats are made to the north of the seat of the hots in order for brƒÅhma·πádocharnsin, potr, nestr and acobƒÅyaka respectively, each of which is at the same distance from the next and the seat of the acch√§vaka is (four angulas ) larger than those of the rest. The seats are either square or round ( according to Sat VIL 7. p. 723) and of 18 angulas in diameter

or on each side, and at the distance of one cubit or 18 angulas from each other (oom. on KƒÅt. VIII. 6. 22). 1158

History of Dharmasastra

(Ch. XXXIII

eastern face being curved like the board of a wheel and the western face being straight. In modern practice the boards are not curved on the east, but are straight. The wood is dry and well planed. In sacrifices in which soma is pressed on more days than one the boards are grooved and made to fit in each other and pierced with a nail. The boards are made firm by driving two pegs through them in front, two behind and one each to the north and south ( 80 that they will not recede ). Vide Baud. VI. 28. The space of two fingers between the two is filled with the dust dug out from the uparavas. One board is placed on the two southern uparavas and the other on the two northern ones. On the two boards is placed a hide ( called adhi≈üavana-carma), wbich is red and cut up all round to fit in with the boards, with the neck portion to the east and the hairy portion up. On the bide are placed four stones ( gr√•van) for pressiog soma juice. The adhvaryu then issues directions to spread barhis over the great vodi (except the uttaravedi, the khara, uparavas and dhi≈üpyas, Sat. VII.7. p.727) and for making the sacrificer take only one-fourth of the fast milk on which he is to subsist (according to KƒÅt. VIII. 6. 30, half of the milk ). Then begins the procedure of the sacrifice of an animal to Agni and Soma ( jointly). This is on the same lines as the nir≈´dba. pasubandha which has already been described. The various actions such as paristarana, placing the sacrificial pƒÅtras, pro k≈üapa are gone through, One more ladle called pracarant made of vikantaka wood and resembling a juh≈± is used in addition (Ap. XI. 16.6). The protiprasth√°tr (or no≈ütr according to Sat. VII.8, p.736) brings the wife from her ubual place (the patni≈õƒÅlƒÅ). The sacri. ficer’s near relatives who always share the same roof are called. The yajamƒÅna touches the adhvaryu, the wife touches the sacri ficer, the song and brothers of the sacrificer touch the wife. They are all covered with a fresh piece of cloth and the adhvaryu offers with the pracarani offerings of ajya called Vaisarjina 1589 to Soma ( K√§t. VIII. 7. 1, Ap. XI. 16, 15). Then comes the carry. ing forward (pranayana ) of Agni and Some Fire is kindled on the dhavaniya and is carried to the uttaravedi. Numerous utensils and vessels are taken to the great vedi beyond the sadas for use in the animal sacrifice and in the pressing of soma next

day and kept in proper places.2570 Fire is established in the ƒÅgnidbra dhi≈ünya. The soma stalks are taken to the bavirdhana mandapa and placed in the southern cart (hayirdhƒÅna ) on & black antelope skin. The sacrificer consigns the soma to the care of gods with a mantra ‘God Savitri here is thy soma’ (VƒÅj. S. V, 39, Tai, S. I. 3. 4. 2). Then the yajamƒÅna gives up the intermediate diksa, after offering into the ƒÅhavaniya & samidh with the mantra ‘Agne vratapate’ (Tai. S. I. 2. 11. 1, VƒÅj. S. V, 40) i. e, he loosens his girdle and his fists that so far had been clenched), gives up the vow of silence ( to be observed at both sandhyƒÅs) and his fast food and he hands over his staff to maitrƒÅvaru≈Üa ( Ap. XI. 18. 6). He may on the next day (soma pressing day ) partake of soma and the leavings of sacrificial food. Hereafter he may be addressed by name and food prepared in his house may be taken by others (KƒÅt. VIII.7. 22). (vide note 2550 above). Hereafter wherever the subrahmanya is to be recited it is in this form. The agnisomlya rite ends with the PatnisamyƒÅja ( Sat. VII. 8. p. 757 ). When the subrahmanya call has been made, standing with his face to the west he brings in & jar the water from a flowing river that starts from a mountain,say but he should not pass over & river that is near his place, even if it does not start from a mountain. He takes this water before the sun sets and from & spot in the river where the shadow of a cloud and sunshine meet or ( if that is not possible ) in the shadow of one’s own body or of & tree or of the river bank. He should fill the jar with water against the stream with ‘havi≈ümatir’ (Vaj. S. VI. 23. Tai, 8. I. 3. 1%. 1). Sat. Br. III. 9.%. 8-9, Kat. VIII. 9. 8-10 and ƒÄp. XI. 20. 10-12 suggest other alternative sources for the water. He enters with the jar of Vasativari waterSs78 by the path between the utkara and cƒÅtvala, takes it by the north of the √§gnidhra shed, enters the sala by the eastern door and places the jar to the west of the salƒÅmukhiya**** fire. In the second watch of the night the adhvaryu carries the jar of vabativarl waters on his shoulder and takes it round the altar and fires in several ways (minutely described in Ap. XI. 21. 3-5, Sat. VII. 8. p. 759 and KƒÅt. VIIL 9. 18-23). At that time only the saorificer and his wife are allowed to stay inside and all others have to go out. Ultimately the yasativari jar is placed in the dgnidhra shed (Ap. XI. 21. 5, Kat. VIII. 9. 23) and the soma plant also is placed in the same hut but on the dgandi (a large stool or couch). The last day ( generally the 5th day) is called ‘sutya’(on which soms is pressed). bupatra on the south corner of the eastern side of the great vedt and the antaryƒÅmap√§tra on the north corner and between the two the grdvan (stone) called upƒÅm√°usavana (employed in extracting soma). Then 80 early before dawn that birds have not begun to chirp or men to speak the adhvaryu issues directions, to the hot; to recite the prƒÅtaranuvƒÅka (morning prayer) in honour of the gods that come early in the morning ( viz. Agni, U≈üas and the Asvins), to the brahmƒÅ priest to observe silence, to the pratiprasthƒÅti to take out the materials (nirv√§pa ) for the savaniya cake and to the subrahmanya to recite the subrahmanya litany (he will use the words ‘adya sutyam in the formula) and promises the hots that he (the adhvaryu ) will follow the hotr mentally in the latter’s recitation. The boty sits down between the yokes of the two havirdbƒÅna carts and recites the prƒÅtaranuv√§ka in three parts ( called kratu ), the first for Agni, the second for U≈üas, and the third for the Akvins, 257? In each part he has to repeat at least one hymn in each of the seven metres viz. Gayatri, Anu≈ütubh, Tri≈ütubh, Bphati, U≈üpih, Jagati and Pankti. A≈°v. ( IV. 13. 6-IV. 15, 3) states the hymns to be recited, the minimum being at least one hundred ≈°ks. If all the hymng and verses specified by A≈°v. are recited the total of the ƒÄgneya seotion will be over 1324 (out of which verses in Gayatri are 320, in Tri≈ütubh 591 and only one hymn, Rg. V. 6 of 10 verses, is in Pankti metre).

Agni≈ütoma-PrƒÅtaranuvƒÅka

1163

About 250 verses 2578 are set out by Asv, for being recited ' in the U≈üas kratu and about 407 in the Asvina kratu of the prƒÅtaranuv√°ka (in all about 2000 verses i. e. nearly one-fifth of the whole of the Rgveda ). The prƒÅtaranuvaka is to be recited in the low or base (mandra ) scale (A√∏v. IV. 13.6). Asy, further directs that even when the minimum of 100 verses or any number short of the one prescribed by him are recited, the order of the hymns set out by him is to be followed and that the three hymns Rg. VII. 12 (to Agni in Tri≈ütubh ). VII. 73 (to Asvins in Tri≈ütubh ) and I. 112 (to Asvins in Jagati) are called mangala (auspicious) and that if the darkness of night is still there when he is about to finish the prataranuvƒÅka he should go on repeating Rg. I, 112 till gun. light appears ( Asv. IV. 15. 7 and 9 ).

And placing the vadativarl water in the hot·ªôcamasa the adhvaryu hands the camasa to the sacrificer, which water is thence-forward called nigrabhya (Ap. XII. 9. 1). Then the adhyaryu makes an offering of ourds from a cup (called dadhi graha, Ap. XII. 7. 5-7). He also takes a few soma stalks from the heap of soma, places them on the upara (vide note 2582 ) and pours some vasativarl water over them, beats the stalks with the stone, extraots soma juice, fills a oup with it and offers it (this is called somagraha, Ap. XII. 7, 10-12). Ap. XII. 9 and Kat. IX. 4 describe how soma is extracted to fill the UpƒÅ·πÅsugraha by using the Nigrabhya water, a portion of it is offered in the southern part of fire (the ty√°ga is ‘idam k≈´ryƒÅya’) and a portion is kept in the Agrayanasthall and a large coil of soma stalks is placed in the Upama≈´graha for use in the evening pressing. Vide Haug’s tr. of Ait. Br. p. 489 and S.B. E. vol. 26 pp. 244-245 n. 2 for the method of the pressing of soma for upƒÅ·πÅsu-graba ( they slightly differ). Then comes the mahƒÅbhi≈üava ( the great or prinoipal pressing of soma). The adhvaryu goes near the adhavaniya trough and pours into it all the water that is in the maitr√•varuna camasa and a third part of the vasativarl water also is poured in that trough and also of the ekadhand water. The rest of both kinds of waters is kept in the place of the ekadband water ( viz. to the west of the axle of the northern havirdhana and below it). The adhvaryu sits to the north of the adbi≈üavana-carma towards the east and behind him sits the sacrifioer, to the south of the adhi≈üava≈Üa-oarma sits the pratiprasthat, to the west nestr and to the north the unneti (Ap. XII. 12. 2

Cb, XXXIII)

Ayni≈ütoma-MahƒÅbhi sarƒ±

1165

and Sat. VIII. 3. p. 825 ). A very large portion of the soma stalks is to be taken for the morning pressing and a small one for the midday one (Ap. XII. 9.7). The adhvaryu takes hold of the stone called upara, “588 places it on the adhi≈üavana hide, brings soma stalks thereon, nigrabhya water is poured on them, the stalks are beaten by the priests with the other stones held in their right hands, which have a golden ring or the like. This is called the first turn or round ( paryƒÅga). Then there is a second turn, when the stalks of some scattered about in the first beating are oollected and are again pounded. Then there is a third turn. The texts even prescribe how many times the stalks are to be beaten in each turn ( vide Ap. XII. 10. 4-8, 9 and XII. 12. 8-9). The wet and pounded stalks are collected by the adhvaryu into & vessel called sarnbharani, “588 are put in the adhavaniya trough which already contains water, the adhavaniya contents are thoroughly stirred, the stalks are washed, pressed, then taken out and placed on the adhi≈üavana. carma. The four stones are again placed facing the upara ( the central big stone ), the sediment or dregs (rji≈üa ) 8584 of the soma stalks are put over the face of the stones. The dronakalasa (a big trough) is carried from its place and kept over all the stones by the udgƒÅtr priests, who spread over it & woollen strainer or sieve held on a wooden frame or stool with ite hem to the north and its contre (nabhi) made of the bunch of wool that was handed over to the sacrificer when soma was purchased (Ap. X. 26.11 and XII. 13, 1). The unnetr priest takes in a vessel (camasa) the soma liquid from the adhavaniga trough, pours it into the hotfoamasa containing nigrƒÅbhya water beld by the sacrificer, who pours & continuous stream on to the woollen strainer (from the hotscamasa ). From the stream of soma juice flowing down from the strainer all cups (that are wooden ) up to the dhruva cup are filled, the first being the cup called antary√•ma. The soma that falls in the dronakala≈°a is called ≈õukra (Kat. IX. 5. 15). The Upam≈°u cup is offered before bunrise, while the adhvaryu offers the antary√°ma oup when the sun rises (Ap. XII. 13. 12). The cups filled

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. *XXIII

are Aindrav√°yava, Maitr√•varupa, Sukra, Manthin, Agrayana, Ukthya, Dhruva and they are placed on various spots of the mound ( khara) desoribed at p. 1155 above. As the cups are filled from the stream ( dhƒÅra ) they are called dhƒÅragrahas (com. on K√°t. IX, 6.26). The cups are wiped with the hems of the strainer or another strainer is employed for the purpose (Ap. XII. 14. 10‚Äì11). In the case of the maitrƒÅvaru≈Üa cup the contents are mixed with boiled but cooled milk, those of the manthin with barley flour. The three grahas viz. Agrayapa, Ukthya and Dhruva are filled to the brim. He then fills three oups called atigrƒÅhyas for Agbi, Indra and Surya (Ap. XII. 15. 9, only in Agniƒôtoma and not in other soma sacrifices ). After the cups are filled, the dropakalasa trough is half filled with soma juice, then the stream of soma stops ( Ap. XII. 16. 9, K√°t. IX. 6.26 ), all fluid from the woollen strainer is wrung out into the dronakalasa and the strainer is kept aside. Then he pours from the maitr√•varu≈Üa camasa which is filled with ekadhana waters into the adhavaniya trough as much as would be necessary (for filling all soma vessels in the morning pressing); he spreads the strainer with its hem to the north on the mouth of the p≈´tabbrt trough, pours thereon & portion of the soma juice that is in the adhavaniya trough and then touches all the three troughs with distinct mantras ( ƒÄp. XII. 16. 11). Then the adhvaryu, prastotr, pratihartf, udg√•ts, the brahmƒÅ (being the last) come out of the havirdhƒÅna shed touching each other with the right hand in the order stated (Tandya Br. VI. 7. 12, Ap. XII. 17.1), adhvaryu being the first (some give a slightly different order ). They perform (or according to Kat, the adhvaryu alone performs) what are called ‘viprud-dhomas 2885 When the soma is being pressed drops of it are scattered about. In order to make these drops go to the gods and also as a sort of expiation this offering of djya is made to Soma ( in all the three savanas). Then the five priests touching each other (adhvaryu being the leader, brahm√° being the last and the sacrificer touching him) oreop with heads bent in & stealthy manner (like hunters pursuing a deer, acoording to ƒÄp. XII. 17. 3-4) towards the north for the purpose of the Bahi≈üpavamƒÅna

Ch. XXXIII ]

Agnistoma-Bahispavam≈´na chant

1167

chant that is to be sung. 8586 The adhvaryu takes two blades *from the grass strewn on the altar, throws one in the o√°tv√°la pit and the other in front of the udgate priests or gives a handful of kusa grags to the prastotr with. Vayu makes the him sound’ (Tai. S. III. 3. %. 1). The udg√•tƒô priests ask the permission of the brahma priest shall we chant’ (and also of Maitr√§varu≈Üa, according to Asv. V. 2. 11) and he replies ‘yes, do chant’ (after repeating in the morning pressing ‘bh≈´r indravanta·∏•’, but with ‘bhuvah’ and ‘svah’ in the other pressings ). Vide A√°v. V.2. 12-13. According to Ap. XIV.9.7, X. 10. 1 the brahm√• repeats the text' deva savitar &o.' and then one of the texts oalled stomabhƒÅgas ( in Tandya I. 9-10), the one employed here being the first viz. ‘ra≈õmirasi’ (thou art a ray, to thee for residence, give impulse to residence ) and then gives permission. All pavamƒÅna chants are introduced in this manner (i, e. by giving a handful of ku≈°as to the prastotr &o.). In the case of stotras other than pavamana, the adhvaryu makes the chanters start after giving them two kusa blades with ‘asarji …… upƒÅ vartadhvam’. At the time of chanting the bahi·ªápa vamƒÅna 2589 stotra, the priests and sacri ficer sit inside the vedi not far from the oƒÅtvala pit in a certain order and look at the c√•tv√§la or they sit round the northern shoulder of the vedi. The udg√¢tr sits facing the north, the prastotr site facing the west and the pratihartr faces the south east; in front of them with faces to the west sit adhvaryu and the pratiprasth√§t; and the sacrificer sits to the south of these. 4587a They sit placing their right foot on the left thigh, look at the horizon and hold their mouths straight (neither hanging down nor up-lifted). This is the position of the chanters in all stotras (Lat. I. 11. 18-23). Then the prastots, udgƒÅts and pratiharts chant the bahi≈üpavamana chant. The place where this chant takes place is called ‘astƒÅva’( com. on A√∏v. V. 3. 16).

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

The Bahispavamana of sacrifices lasting for more than one day is chanted in the sadas except on the first day (vide Dr√°hyƒÅyane Sr. IV. 1. 13). The sacrifiber and at least four of the other priests (but not adhvaryu ) aot as choristers (upagƒÅts, Ap. XII. 17. 11-12). According to Lat. I. 11. 26 and DrabyƒÅyana III. 4. 6 the priests sing the chorus ‘bo’ and the sacrificer says’om' continuously in the mandra ( low ) tone in the intervals between the prest√°va and the other elements of the chant and also during the chanting of these elements except the nidhana, according to com. on Dr√§hyƒÅyana III. 4. 6 and stop from doing so at the finale ( nidhana) which is to be sung by the three s√•ma priests together. Jai. (III. 7.30) states that the choristers are some of the priests (ftviks) themselves (except adhvaryu) and not others. At the time of the first prast√°va of the bahispavam√§ng chant, the $588 sacrificer mutters the famous prayer (set out on p. 5 above) ‘asato in√§ sad gamaya …… m√°mptam gamaya’ (Br. Up. I. 3. 28 and com. on Kat. IX. 7.4), while according to ƒÄp. XII. 17. 14 the sacrificer mutters the dagahotr texts (vide p. 993 above for them). The first stotra at each pressing is called PavamƒÅna (Ap. XII. 17. 8-9), that at the morning savana being called BahispavamƒÅna, those at the 2nd and 3rd pressings being respectively called M√§dhyandina pavamana and Arbhava or T»ôtiya PavamƒÅna. The other stotras are called Dhurya (com. on K√§t. IX. 14. 5).

According to Lat. I. 12. 1 and Dr√°byƒÅya·πáa ≈ör. III. 4. 16-17 the prastoty takes the prastara bunch from the adhvaryu, asks the permission of the brahmi and the pra≈õƒÅstr and then hands over the prastara to the udgƒÅtr who touches his thigh with it, and keeps it down with a yajus mantra.

Ch. XXXIII ]

Agristoma-BahispavamƒÅnastotra

The three saman priests then commence the chanting

‚Ä¢ of the Bahi≈üpavam√§na stotra, while looking at the c√§tv√§la (Tandya VI. 7.24). The verses in this stotra are nine, viz.

Bg. IX. 11. 1-3, IX. 64. 28-30 and Rg. IX, 66. 10-12; they correspond to Samaveda II. 1. 1. 1-3 (Benfey) and S. V. vol. III. pp. 4-5, 7-8,10-11. According to the com. on Lat. I. 12.7 the Bahis pavamƒÅna is begun to be chanted after once uttering the syllable ‘hum’, while the udgitha in all cases begins with ‘om’ (Lat. VI. 10.13)25. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡•ã ‡§™‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á ‡•® ‡§Ø‡•Å' ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•å ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•® ‡§π‡•Å‡§Å' ‡§Ü ‡•© ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•å ‡•ß‡•´ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§µ‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê ‡§∂‡§æ ‡•® ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§á ‡§∂‡•´ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ú‡•Ä ‡•ß ‡§®‡•ã ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡•Ä ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•® ‡§π‡•Å‡§Å' ‡§Ü ‡•® | ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•ß‡•´‡••

(‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§µ‡§É) ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ã' ‡§≠‡§æ ‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§æ ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•á‡§Æ‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß‡•® | ‡§π‡•Å‡§Å' ‡§Ü ‡§∞ | ‡§∂‡•ã‡§á‡§∞‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§à‡§°‡§æ ‡•©‡•®‡•´‡••

‘‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•É‡§≠‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•®‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Ä’ ‘‡§¶‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•ã ‡•ß‡•® ‡•ß ‡•® ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•® | ‡§π‡•Å‡§Å’ ‡§Ü ‡•® | ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§•‡•ã | ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•ß‡•´ ‡§ï‡•ç‡••

History of Dharmasastra

(Ch. XXXIII

than once (vide com. on Drahyayapa Sr. III. 4. 22). The Lat. Sr. itself illustrates (in VII. 10. 18-21) how the first verse is ohanted. The nidhanas for the nine verses are (Lat. VII. 13. 7) sat, sam, suvai, ida, vak, s (for the last four verses). The note below will, it is hoped, convey some idea (however vague) of the manner in which the saman verses are manipulated for the purpoge of chanting. It is very difficult (nay, almost impossible) to convey in print how the sƒÅmans are sung. The dificulty is aggravated by the fact that the notations adopted in the mss. and the editions are different and hardly any two Mss. agree in all respects. . Besides the present writer does not profess to have studied the intricacies of ancient Indian or modern European musio and is not in a position to write a dissertation on this topic. He has, however, given below and elsewhere such general and useful hints as could be gathered from Sanskrit works. Those who are desirous of making a

(Continued from last page) ‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§®‡•ã' ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Å ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•® | ‘‡§π‡•Å‡§Å ‡§Ü ‡•® | ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•ã | ‡§ì‡§Ç ‡•ß‡•´‡••

(‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§ö‡§É) ‡§™‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á’ ‡§ï‡§µ‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ' ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‘‡§π‡•Å ‡§Ü ‡•® | ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ã‡•§ ‡§Ü3‡•ß‡•´‡•• ___‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∂ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•É‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á’ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•® ‡§á ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§ß‡•Ä ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•®' ‡§Æ‡§æ | ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§î ‡••

‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ã ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ê‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ã' ‡§® ‡§ß‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•®. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•É‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡•ã' ‡•ß‡•®‡•ß‡•® ‡•§ ‘‡§π‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡§®‡•å‡§Ø‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§ì ‡•ß‡•´‡•• This is taken from a Mb. in the possession of Svinur Kovalƒçnanda of Wai, Dist. Ch. XXXIII

Agniƒôtoma

1171

olose study of the s√§mans may read the following: The Panca. vidba-s≈´tra, edited by Dr. Richard Bimon (Breslau, 1913 ); SƒÅyana’s introduction to his commentary on the S√°maveda in vol. I. of the B. I. edition; N√§radiya-siksƒÅ published in the Benares Sanskrit series ; Satyavrata Samagrami’s learned notes in his edition of the Samaveda in five volumes (in B. I. Series); Burnell’s Introduction to Samavidhana BrƒÅhmana (1873), Introduction to the Jaiminlys text of the Argeya Brabmana (1878, where on p. XV he gives diagrams of the hand and fingers employed in indicating the chanting of the sƒÅmans), Introduction to Rktantra-vyakarana, partioularly p. XXXVIII (1879); “the Vedio chant studied in its texual and melodic form” by J. M. Van der Hoogt (Wageningen, Holland, 1929) which presents & special study of stobhas; translation ( with notes and Introduction) of the Pa√±oavim≈°a Brahmana by Dr. Caland (in the B. I series, 1931); the Introduotion to the rocent edition of the S√§naveda brought out by Pandit Satavale kar at Aundh (1939); ‘the Music of Hindostan’ by A. H. Fox Strangways (Oxford, 1914), particularly pp. 249-279; a booklet

the Ancient Mode of singing sƒÅmagƒÅna’ by Mr. Lak≈üma≈Üa Samkarabhatta DrƒÅvida of Poona. It may, however, be stated here that even on reading these books no thorough knowledge of s√¢magƒÅnas can be acquired. Thorough investigation and research have yet to be made in these g√•nas and the first endeavour must be to collect gramophone records of the methods of chanting adopted throughout India and then compare them. A generation or two hence, it is feared, hardly any learned sƒÅma singers will be left.

Most of the saman ohants are taken from the Rgveda. In reciting & verse from the Rgveda attention has to be paid to the accents called udƒÅtta, anudƒÅtta and svarita. When the same Verge is chanted as a saman, one has to attend besides to the notes of the melody to which the verse is being sung. The way of marking the accents of the Rgveda verse is not followed when it is taken in the Samaveda. The svarita of the Rgveda is represented in the Samaveda M88. in several ways, but generally by the figure % written above the letter and anudatta preceding an udatta is represented in the Samaveda sarbita by the figure 3 and udatta following an anudatta has the figure one placed on the letter. There are further detailed rules about these accents and also other marks which are not set out here. Only one further remark is made. The letter “ra”

1172

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

preceded by 2 is placed over a gvarita coming after the udatta whicb follows another udatta. Modern sama singers have generally no knowledge of these ancient rules and signs but only chant as they learned from their teachers, nor do their obants always agree with the notations in the several M8s. Further there is a certain monotony and sameness in their melodies. If one hears a modern singer sing songs in several rƒÅgas like the Jogi or Jhinjo»õi or Kham≈´ch a person totally ignorant of the rƒÅgas can feel, however vaguely, the difference between the two. But this is not so when a Rathantara melody or a B»ôhat melody is sung. According to the S√°mavidhƒÅpa-brƒÅhma·πáa ( I. 1. 8 and 14 ) these notes (also called staras) are seven, viz. krusta, prathama (1st), dvitiya (2nd), t≈ôtiya, caturtha, pa√±cama (or mandra) and antya (last) or atisv√§rya, 2591 Sayana explains that the seven svaras named above are arranged in a descending scale, though from the words first, second and so on one is apt to suppose that they are in an ascending scale. SƒÅya·πáa further states that these seven svaras are also called yamas. 2583 In the N√°radiya-sik≈üƒÅ ( Benares Sanskrit series) the seven svaras are stated to be prathama, dvitiya, t≈ôtiya, caturtha, mandra, kru≈üta and atisvƒÅra ( 1. 12). The kru≈üta is the highest note and comes before prathama in many texts. The same work (III. 5) mentions the seven classical notes, ≈üadja, psabha, gƒÅndh√°ra, madhyama, pa√±cama, dhaivata and ni≈üƒÅda ( which are indi cated in modern India as sa ri or re ga ma pa dha ni). The N√°radiya-sik≈üƒÅ then (V. 1-2) tries to establish a correspondence between the seven ancient names of the notes of sƒÅma chanters and the seven notes of olaseioal times by stating that the seven s√•man notes mentioned ( from prathama onwards ) are respec tively the same as the notes produced on the Indian vi≈ÜƒÅ (lute) called madhyama, g√•ndhƒÅra, f≈üabha, ≈üadje, dhaivata, ni≈üada and pa√±cama. Pandit S√§tavalekar (Introduction to the edition of the S√§maveda p. 2) holds that the printed N√°radiya-≈õik·π£ƒÅ bas

Ch. XXXIII)

Agniƒôtoma-Sama chant

1179

wrongly transposed the places of ni≈üƒÅda and dhaivata. ***

The notations employed in the North Indian and South Indian M88. of the SƒÅmaveda vary considerably and the confusion is made worse by the fact that the several sakhƒÅs (such as the Kauthumas, the R√§≈ÜƒÅyanlyas and Jaiminlyas ) have various readings and varying notations of their own. The N√°radiya-sik≈üƒÅ further points out (VI. 2-6) that the sƒÅƒ±nans can be sung to the notes of the ordinary vi≈Üa and also to the accompaniment of the movements of the thumb and fingers of the hand (and so it calls the latter gƒÅtrayi≈ÜƒÅ, ‘body-lute ‘). The reciter sitting cross-legged is to place his hands on the two knees, to touch by the tip of the thumb the iniddle parva (joint) of the fingers for indicating the several notes of the song (and not the root of the fingers ) and to hold the band in front of his nose like & cow’s ear. The seven svaras are indicated as follows : 2594 the krusta is on the head ( top ) of the thumb, the prathama (i. e. madhyama of classical notes ) is on the central part of the thumb; g√¢ndhƒÅra, ≈ü≈üabba, sadja and dhaivata (i. e. 2nd, 3rd, 4th and mandra ) are respectively indicated by (touching with the tip of the thumb the oentral joints of ) the fore-finger, the middle finger, the ring finger and the small finger; and ni≈üƒÅda is indicated at that part of the palm below the small finger which resembles a channel when the fingers are closed in a fist.

While the Bahi≈üpavamana is being chanted the innets priest pours the soma juice contained in the adhavaniya vessel on to the p≈´tabh·ªãt trough over which tbe woollen strainer is stretched with its bem to the north. When the chant is finished the adhvaryu issues directions (praisa ) to tbe √§gnidhra priest to kindle fires (on the dhi≈üpyas), to strew kusa grass (on the vedi) and to deck the purod√°bas and to the pratiprasthƒÅtr to come with the savaniya (to be sacrificed on the pressing day) pa≈°u (animal). The agnidhra brings burning coals from the ƒÅgnidbriga fire and kindles fires on the dust (or sand) of the several dhi≈ünyas beginning with that of the hotf(in the order in which the seats were arranged and with the same mantras ). (Ch. XXXIII

Agnidhra spreads kusas beginning from the g√§rhapatya up to the abavaniya, along the prsthy: line and decks the purodagas. He offers Boma into the ahavaniya, agnidhriya and m√§rj√°llya fires and djya in others. The adhvargu, whom the sacrificer touobes, fills the Asvina cup (graha) from the dropakalada with the pariplav√° (& small spoon resembling a sruo without its rod, Ap. XII. 2.7 ) and the other oups that are not dh√§r√§grahas are also filled in the same way.

Then begin the rites for the offering of the savaniya pasu, commencing from the tying of a triple girdle round the post ( y√ºpa ). According to K√•t. IX, 8.1 the girdle (rabang ) that was used the previous day at the time of sacrificing the Agni. somlya animal is again used for the savaniya pasu, while according to ƒÄp. XII. 18. 1% a new girdle is used. In the Agnistoma the animal sacrificed on soma-pressing day is a goat for Agni. In the Ukthya sacrifice another goat (in addition) is sacrificed for Indra and Agni, in the ≈üodasin sacrifice a third pa≈°u (a ram according to Kat. IX. 8. 4, a goat according to Ap. XII. 18. 13 ) is offered in addition and in the Atir√§tra a fourth one (a goat) to Sarasvati in addition. KƒÅt. (IX. 8. 5-6) allows optionally a ewe. These four animals that are offered are called stomƒÅyana (Kat. IX. 8.7 ) and kratupasus (A≈°v. V. 3. 4). Then the procedure of Nir≈´dhapasubandha described above is followed up to the offering of the vapa (omentum) and sub sequent mƒÅrjana (purification with water). Then all the priests and the sacrificer enter the sadas and oocupy places to the east of the audumbari post and to the west of their several Beats ( dhi≈üpy√°s ) *S98 and other places after looking (with man tras for each) at the several cups, the three troughs (adhava niya, p≈´tabbft and dro≈Üa-kalasa), the clarified butter and vessels and the sacrifioer pays homage to all these (with mantras set out in Ap. XII. 19.5 ff).

At this stage the pratiprasthair brings the five gavaniya offerings (vide p. 1163 above). The adbvaryu places them on the vedi, cuts off portions of the offerings, arranges them in one large vessel (or the juh√º) in such a way that the cake for Indra is placed in the middle, the db√•nd is to the east of it, karambha to the south, parivƒÅpa to the west and amiksƒÅ to the

Oh, XXXIII )

Agni≈ütoma-Savaniya offerings

1175

north. The portions meant for svi≈ütakst are placed in the Upabbrt. The adhvaryu issues his direction to the maitr√§varu≈Üa to recite the anuv√°kyƒÅ for the puroda≈õa and other offerings to Indra in the morning pressing and to ask the hots to repeat the yajya for the same. The anuv√°kyas for the puroda≈õa and other offerings in the three savanas are respectively Rg. III. 52. 1,5 and 6 and the apuv√°kyƒÅs in the three sivanas for the svi≈ütakt offering are Rg. III. 28. 1. 4 and 5 respectively. The maitr.. Varupa’s praiga to the hot; and the latter’s formula before the offering is made are given in the note below.1886 The adhvaryu makes the principal offering into fire and then tho svi≈ütakst. Portions of the remainder are cut off for tbe BrahmƒÅ priest, ida lg cut off and placed on the seat of the hots and the rest is kept securely for the sacrificer.

Then offerings of soma from the cups are made to the joint deities ( dvidevatya grahas ) viz. for Indra and Vayu, Mitra and Varupa, and the two Akvins. After this comes camasonnayana. The upnetf fills to the west of the uttaravedi nine camasas for the priests called oamasƒÅdhvaryus, by first pouring in each some soma from the dronakala≈°a (this is upastarana ), then soma from the p≈´tabhrt trough and then again from the dropakalasa (this is abhighƒÅrapa). The order in which the nine are filled is : first that of hots, then for brahmi, udg√§ts, sacrificer, maitr√§varu≈Üa, brƒÅhma·πáƒÅoobamsin, potr, De≈ütr, √§gni. dhra (there is none for unnetƒô and acohƒÅvƒÅka here). The maitrƒÅvaru≈Üa repeats Rg. I. 16, VII. 21 and IV. 35 in the three savanas respectively when the camasas are being filled ( A≈õy. V. 5. 14). Then follows sukr√§manthi-pracƒÅra. The adhvaryu takes the soma cup called Sukra, the pratiprasthat the Manthin cup and the camasadhyaryus the camasas that are placed on the uttaravedi. The camasadhvaryus are not ƒºtviks chosen by the yajamiga but they are assistants chosen by the priests (the ptviks themselves). Vide Jai. III. 7. 27. Jai. (III. 7.26-27) further says

They (adhvaryu and pratipras. thats) cover the cups with two pieces of wood (obiselled off when the y≈´pa was made ) that are sprinkled with holy water, wipe the cups from their mouths downwards with two pieces of the y√ºpa, but not sprinkled ) saying ‘wiped off is Sanda’(adhvaryu says) and ‘wiped off is Marka’ (saya pratiprasthƒÅts). They place the cups on the south and north corners of the western side of the uttaravedi, go to the south and north of the y√ºpa, throw away the unsprinkled chips (referring to the repulse of Sanda and Marka )997 outside the vedi and the sprinkled ones are placed into the dhavaniya and standing on both sides of the y≈´pe they two offer the cups with their faces to the west and the cama s√•dhvaryus ( who are nine here and ten in other cases, vide com. on Kat. IX. 11. 2) do the same with faces to the east and silently. All these offerings are made to Indra (com. on K√§t. IX. 11. 2). The pratiprasthƒÅtr pours what remains in the manthin cup into the sukra cup and the adhvaryu pours the mixture of the soma juice remnants of the two cups into the hotr-camasa. The contents of the cup for Indra-vƒÅyu are drunk twice and of the rest once. There are 6 pairs of months, for the first of whioh the offering is made by the adhvaryu and for the 2nd by the prati prasthƒÅtr with the mantra (VƒÅj S. VII. 30) ‘upay&magƒºhitosi madhave tva’ (and so on). Baud. VII. 16 gives at length all the mantras for the twelve months. The praigas are uttered by the maitr√§varu≈Üa and when the adhvaryu enters the bavir dhana pavilion to make the offering the pratiprasthƒÅtr leaves it and vice versa. The va≈üatk√•ra for the first six is uttered respectively by hots, pots, Bestr, √§gnidhra, brƒÅhma·πáƒÅochamsin and maitr√§varupa and the adhvaryu or pratiprastb√§tf ( as the case may be ) eats of the remains in the cup with that priest who utters the va≈üatkƒÅra. Oh, XXXIII ) Agni≈ütoma-Soma and Ksatriyas

1179

It would not be out of place to remark here that according to the Ait. Br. 35. 2-4 (referred to on p. 140 above) a k≈üatriya sacrificer was not to drink soma, but if he desired he might drink the liquid obtained by pounding the young sprouts of the banyan tree and the fruits of that tree and of the udumbara and of other holy trees mixing them with curds.2600 It is however to be noted that in classical Sanskrit literature some times kings are desoribed as ‘somapƒÅh’. The s≈´tras (0. g. Sat. VIII. 7. p. 88%, Ap. XII. 24.5) say the same. Jai. (III. 5. 47-51 ) refers to this practice and says that the liquid so pre pared and poured into a cup is called phala-camasa and is really an offering made on a coal taken from the ƒÅhavaniya to its north, and not a mere substitute for some eatable. Vide also Jai. III. 6. 36.

The adhvaryu with the stu cup in his hand sits down near the door of the sadas in front of the hot; with his face to the east. mutters the words “Id√£, the summoner of gods’ ( Tai, 8. III. 3. 2. 1). Then the hots performs japa of a long passage for (found in Asv. V. 9. 1), he issues without uttering bisk√°ra a call ( ƒÅbava) to the adbvaryu loudly viz. Som3sƒÅvo3m' (let us both praise ) 2808 and recites inaudibly the prayer called

The adhvargu first partakes of the remnant from the soma cup and then the other priests who bave camasas eat the contents of the camasas (Ap. XII. 28. 1-3).

It will have been noticed from the preceding description that there are six or seven elements oonnected with the recitation of the sastras: (1) the inaudible japa, (2) abƒÅva and pratigara, (3) t√ª≈üpimsamsa, (4) the nivid or puroruk, (5) s≈´kta, (6) japa of words *uktham vƒÅci' (A≈°v. V. 10. 22-24 ) with certain words added that differ at different times (this is called ukthavirya ), to which the adhvaryu responds with ‘ukthasƒÅ·∏•’ &c., (7) the yƒÅjyƒÅ ( A√∏v. V. 10. 21 ).2605 Only the T≈´≈üpƒ±msamee does not ocour in the other sastras.

In the Agni≈ütoma there are twelve stotras and twelve sastras. The words sastra and stotra in their etymological senso mean' praise or laud,' but a stotra is a laud that is sung to a melody and a sastra is a laud that is only recited ( vide Sabara on Jal. VII. %. 17 ). A sastra always belongs to and follows & stotra. In the pratahsavana the hots begins his ahƒÅva after the
