History of DharmadƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

udgƒÅts makes hi·ªânkƒÅra in the stotra he chants and in the other two savanas the hotƒô does 80 after the pratihƒÅra element of the stotra ( Asv. V. 10. 1-3 ) when the prastotr draws his attention by uttering the word ‘e≈üƒÅ’ (this) at the time of the prastƒÅva of the last verse in the stotra. 2908 The ajyasastra is the first Sastra in the Agnistoma and the agnimƒÅruta is the last Jai. (II. 1. 13-29 ) establishes that when the vedio text says ‘he recites the prauga sastra ' or ‘be chants the ƒÅjya stotra,’ what is meant is not that these stotras and sastras are merely some subordinate matters in connection with the devatƒÅ of the rite, but they are really principal matters. In X. 4. 49 Jai. states that in the Agnistut sacrifices there is no uha of the stotras and sastras of the Agnistoma, but they are sung and recited as in Agnistoma. In the morning savana ( pressing of soma ), five stotras are chanted viz. BahispavamƒÅna and four ƒÄjyastotras; in the mid-day pressing five more viz. the m√•dhyandina pava m√•na and four Prsthastotras (vide Haug’s tr. of Ait. Br. p. 193 n. 29 ) and in the evening pressing two stotras viz. the Arbhava pevamana and the Agni≈ütoma-saman (viz. yaj√±√°-yaj√±a vo &c.). The corresponding twelve sastras are: in the morning the Ajyasastra (by hotp), Praugasastra (by hotr) and three ajyasastras (by maitr√•varu≈Üa, brƒÅhma·πáƒÅcchamsin and acobƒÅ vƒÅka, these three priests being called hotrakas); in the mid day pressing the marutvatiya sastra (by hotƒô), ni≈ükevalya sastra (by hots) and three more by the three assistants of the bott; in the evening pressing the two bastras are vaisvadeva≈õastra and √•gni mƒÅrutasastra (both by the bots), The Bahi≈üpavamƒÅna is chanted in the Triv»ôtstoma, the four ajyastotras and the mƒÅdbyandinapava mƒÅna in the Pancada≈°astoma, the four Prstha-stotras and the Arbhavapavamana in the Saptada≈°astoma and the yaj√±ayaj√±iya in the Ekavimsastoma (vide Tandya Br. XX. 1. 1). Stoma means a group of verses and pa√±cada≈°astoma and similar words mean that the verses (usually three) are inoreased to 15, 17, 21 &c. by repetition in various patterns (which are called vi·ªÖtuti). There are three vi≈ütutis of the paboada≈õastoma. These patterns differ in the order and number of repetitions. The prastoty. marks the several turns, the number of verses and the order by means of small sticks & span long (called kusas ) cut from the udumbara tree and placed on 8 piece of cloth spread in the

  1. FITU WTO i gara en gran frasar awataram Terra *uti H. V. 10. 1~3; That segar startani araya II. 6, 11.

Oh. XXXIII ) Agni≈ütoma-ƒÅjyastora and pƒÅ√±cada≈°astoma 1183

midst of the singers. Vide La≈£. II. 6. 1-4. For example, the first ajyastotra (Rg. VI. 16. 10-12 = S. V. II. 1. 1. 4, ed. by Benfey ) is raised to fifteen verses in three paryayas (turns) of five verses each. If the three verses are denoted by a, b, o then the 15 verses will be a & abo (first paryƒÅya), a bb bo ( 2nd paryaya ) and a booc (third paryƒÅya). Vide TƒÅ≈Üdy& Br. II. 4. Tbe 2nd vi≈ütuti of the pancada≈õastoma is represen ted by a a a b c, a bo, a b bbcoc and the third vi≈üguti by 8 b c,& b b bo and a a a boco ( vide T·∫£ndya Br. II. 5-6). The word stoma is to be distinguished from stolra. The latter is a chant of a certain number of verses set to a certain melody out of those mentioned in the g√•nas of the Samaveda. Stobhas are musical interjections and flourishes introduced in the saman obants such as ‘b√§u’, ‘hal’, ‘1’, ‘√º’, ‘hum’ (vide Ch√£n. Up. I. 13). HƒÅu and h√§i are stobhas employed in the Rathantara and V√°madevya s√§mans respectively. Jai. IX. %. 39 defines stobha as that which is in addition to the letters of the sk ( that is being chanted ) and has other varnas than those of the »ôk (adbikam ca vivarpam ca Jaimini·∏• stobha-sabdatvat). The word saman means, no doubt, a chant (giti), but since stobhas are necessary to bring out the melody and help in musical appreciation they are included in the connotation of the word s√•man 2009 (Jai. II. 1. 36, IX. %. 34-38). Sabara states that there are a thousand (numberless) means of adding to the charm of the melody (giti), which only conveys certain notes produced by internal effort and which is denoted by the word s√•man. The chant has a fixed extent and is sung on & ≈ük verse. In order to effectuate that chant resort is made to change of letter (as in ognƒÅyi’ for ‘agna’ in’agna ƒÅyƒÅbi vitaye), to stobha and the other devices stated below 1608. Since the pk verses are

The ‡§¶‡•Å‡§™‡§ü‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ demurs to this and remarks ‘‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§∏‡§ó‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§™‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ò‡§ü‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§’. sung to a certain melody the ≈°ks are the skeleton, the notes of the melody are the flesh that clothes the bare bones, they are. super-imposed over the √ßk, and the stobhas are embellishments or flourishes like the hair on one’s body. This very apt and happy figure is employed by the S√•mavidhƒÅna BrƒÅhma·πáa to illustrate the relationship of the pks, the notes and the stobhas. 1809 Each saman chant is primarily connected with certain verses, 0. g. when we speak of Rathantara without more the verses meant are Rg.   1. V. II. 1, 1. 11 ( Benfey) and 8. V. vol. III. pp. 83-84 (B. I. series); and when one refers to the Vamadevya s√§man without further qualification the verses intended are Rg. IV. 31. 1-3 ( kaya nascitra abhuvat) = 8. V. II. 1. 1. 12 ( Benfey) and 8. V. vol. III. pp. 87-89 (B. I.). These are called the own ( svakiya ) verses of the respective s√•mans ( vide com. on Dr√°hyƒÅya·πáa II. 1. 1) and that one verso oocurring in the p≈´r v√§roika part of the S√§maveda, which is the first in the saman as set out in the UttarƒÅrcika portion, is called the yoni of the s√§man (Jai. VII. %. 17 and Sabara thereon). But the verses that are the own verses of & saman can be sung to another melody. TƒÅ≈Üdya XV. 10. 1 says ‘the kavati verses’ are the verses’ kaya na≈°oitra &c.' which are the svakiya verses of the Vamadevya. When some texts say ‘he chants the Rathantara on the Kavati verses’ what is meant is that, not minding the V√°madevya melody to which the verses “kaya nascitra &o.' primarily attach themselves, they are to be sung to the Rathan tara melody in that particular rite. So the word s√•man as applied to Rathantara, Bphat, Raivata and others means simply & melody and not one or more pk verses that are bung 2010 ( vide Jai. IX. 2. 1-2).

Jaimini deals in about 60 adhikaranas with matters arising out of the relation of the Samaveda to sacrifices in V. 3, IX, 1, IX. 2, X 5-6 and elsewhere. Some of the conclusions are very interesting and may be briefly indicated; viz. the √ºha. grantha is of human authorship (IX. 2. 1-2), the fk is principal and the melody is an attribute of it ( IX. 2. 3-13 ), the whole

melody is to be sung on each pk of the sƒÅman (IX. 2. 14-20 ), the verses of a siman should as far as possible be in the same metre ( IX. 2. 21-22 ), the fk verses set out in the Uttar√°rcika are to be taken for singing the melody on (IX, %. 23‚Äì24), that two verses have to be arranged as three by repetition of the 4th or last pada in certain melodies (IX. 2. 25-27), that in the Yaj√±ƒÅyaj√±lya s√£man for the words ‘gir√§ girƒÅ’ in the original ‘irƒÅ irƒÅ’ has to be substituted in the melody (IX. 1. 50-51 ).

After the recitation of the sastra and the partaking of remnants of soma the adhvaryu takes the Vai≈°vadeva cup, fills it from the dro≈Üakala≈õa, touches it with two kusa blades, hands over the blades to the prastotp priest and urges the saman priests to chant a stotra. This is the mode in all cases of dhurya stotras. Stotras other than the Bahi≈üpavam√¢na are chanted near the Audumbar/ post in the sadas; the prastot: sits facing the west bebind the adhvaryu, the udg√•tr sits to his west facing the north, and the pratihartr sits facing udg√§ts, but looking towards the south-east ( TƒÅ≈Üdya VI. 4. 14, Dr√§hyƒÅyana III. 3. 28). The stotra chanted after the Vai≈°vadeva cup is taken and the three following ones are called ajyastotras2011 (com. on Ap. XII. 28. 6). The 2nd sastra is called prauga ( Asv. V. 10. 6 ) which is recited after the taking up of the Vai≈°vadera cup and is supposed according to the Ait. Br. XI. 2 to confor food. This sastra is made up of Rg. I. 2 and 3 (in all 21 verses), which are divided into seven triplets addressed to seven deities in order viz. VƒÅyu, Indra-v√£yu, Mitra and Varu≈Üa, A≈°vins, Iudra, Vi≈õve Devas, Sarasvati. Each of the seven triplets is proceded by a verse called puroruk. The first puroruk is pro ceded by ‘bim’ and ‘bh√ªr-bhuva·∏• svaro 3m. 2018 The 2nd verse of Rg. History of DharmadƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

“ukthar v√°ci slokƒÅya tva’ (instead of ‘ghosƒÅya tv√•’), and Rg. I. 14. 10 is the yajya of the Prauga-sastra. This oup is' offered and the remnants of it and of the camasas are drunk by the priests. Then from the Ukthyasthall containing some a third is taken for filling three cups to Mitra and Varu≈Üa, Indra, and Indra-Agni. Stotras and sastras follow at each of these three oups, the castras being repeated respectively by the maitr√§varu≈Üa, brƒÅhma·πáƒÅcoba·πÅsin and acchƒÅyƒÅka. For want of space all these three sastras cannot be set out at length here. A≈°v. V. 10. 26 very succintly inctioates them. Each of these sastras has four parts, (1) a triplet called stotriya (because those very verses have been chanted in the corresponding stotra ); () then another triplet called anur≈´pa which should agree in metre, deity and even the sage (according to some) with the stotriya triplet (A≈öy. V. 10. 26-27 ); (3) the core or principal part of the bastra, hence called uktba-mukha (vide S√£≈Ñ. VII. 11. 3); (4) a y√§jy√§ verse. For example, in the maitrƒÅvaru≈Üa sastra, Rg. III. 62. 16-18 constitute the stotriya triplet (those three verses are chanted as the 2nd ajyastotra), Rg. V. 71.1-3 form the anur≈´pa triplet, Rg. V. 68. 1-5 and Rg. VII. 66. 1-9 are the uktha-mukha and Rg. VII. 66. 19 is the y√§jyƒÅ of the sastra. This brings the prƒÅta savana to an end, and the adhva ryu makes an offering at the end with the words ‘May Agni protect us in the morning savana’. At the bidding of the adhvaryu the maitr√§varu≈Üa asks all the priests to come out of the sadas and they come out by the way they went in.

Then before the madhyandina savana begins the priests again enter the sadas, and the yajamƒÅna enters by the eastern door. The procedure of the mid-day pressing is in main out lines the same as that of the morning one (Ap. XIII.1.2). There is no hurry in the first two pressings, but the third press ing is got through with speed (Ap. XII. 29. 12). There are a few points of difference. In the mid-day pressing there are no cups for the joint deities (dvidevatya grabas), no oups for the seasons (Ap. XIII. 1. 4). The great pressing is done as in the morning pressing, but in a loud voice (Ap. XIII. 1.8). In this pressing the vasatiyarl waters are taken in the hotsoamasa, are handed over to the yajamƒÅna and become the nigr√§bhyƒÅ for pressing soma. The oloth in which soma stalks are tied is loosened and given for wearing as a turban to the priest called gr√§vastut and it is taken back from him after he recites the praise of the crushing stone (Ap. XIII. 1. 5 and com.). The cups taken are five, viz. bukra and manthin, agrayana, two marutvatlya and ukthya

Ch. XXXIII)

Agni≈ütoma-Madhyandina-savana

1187

( also taken either before both marutvatiya oups or between the two). The grƒÅvastut (praiser of the stones used in crushing soma stalks ) enters the havirdhƒÅna pavilion by the eastern door, throws away a blade of ku≈°a on & spot which is to the north-east of the northern point of the axle of the southern havirdbƒÅna cart and stands opposite the soma stalks with face to the south-east. He takes the cloth in his joined hands, folds it round his head and face from left to right thrice (so as to make it look like a turban). When the stalks of some are placed for being crushed he should recite certain verses by the middle tone (Asv. V. 12. 7‚Äì8), which is the tone for all vedic texts in the mid-day pressing. The texts repeated by the grƒÅvastut are ( ƒÇ≈õv. V. 12. 9-11): Rg. I. 24. 3, V. 81. 1, VIII. 81. 1, VIII. 1. 1, X. 94 (this hymn is called Arbuda ), Rs. X. 76 and 175. Before the last verse of Rg. X. 94, the two hymns Rg. X. 76 and X. 175 are recited. Either between the latter two hymns or after them or before them he recites as many pavamƒÅna verses as are required up till the taking up of the cups, finishes the last verse of Rg. X. 94 and hands back the turban to the saorificer. A≈°v, further directs that from the hymn Rg. X. 94 which has 14 verses the 4th is taken out and the last is the paridhaniya (the finishing verse ) and the rest ( 12 verses) are divided into four triplets and each of the triplets is either preceded or followed by & triplet out of the following viz. Rg. I. 91, 16-18, IX. 8. 4, IX. 15. 8, IX. 107. 21, VIII. 72. 8, VIII. 72. 16, IX. 17. 4, IX. 67. 14-15 ( which together come to twelve verses ). The four triplets are respectively recited by the grƒÅvastut at the time of sprinkling water on the soma stalks, pounding with the hands, extracting juice, and collecting the soma juice in the adhavaniya trough ( ƒÄ√Ωv. V. 12. 15-19). In the mid-day pressing the place of the Babi≈üpavamƒÅna is taken by the Madhyandina-pavamƒÅna stotra ( ƒÄp. XIII. 3. 7). This stotra consists of Rg. IX, 61, 10-12, X. 107. 4-5, X. 87. 1-3, that is S√§maveda II. 1. 1. 8-10 ( Benfey ) and S. V. vol. III. pp. 22-23, 41-42, 78-80. The yajamƒÅns mutters several texts before the madhyandina pavam√§ng is chanted and during its chanting

(Ap. XIII. 3.1).

After the chanting of the M√§dhyandina-pavamana comes the rite called Dadhigharma, if the sacrificer has performed the Prav√°rgya rite ( Asv. V. 13. 1). The pratiprasth√§tƒô brings ourds in the ladle ( sruo) made of udumbara ; the curds are heated on the dgnidhriya fire. The hotf when asked' is the

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIJI

havis heated' repeats Rg, X. 179. % 88 the anuvƒÅkya and X. 179. 3 is the ydjy√§ and after he says ‘vau3≈üat’ the curds are, offered in the abovaniya, and when he repeatsagne yihi' and also a second vaugat another offering of the heated ourds is made and the remnants of curds are eaten by those who partake of the remnants in the Pravargya rite. Then the pasupurodasa ( of the animal killed in the morning ) and the other offerings (such as puroda≈õa on eleven potsherds ) are made and the remnants eaten. Then ten camagas are filled (including that of acohƒÅvaka ). Then offerings of some from the sukra and manthin cups are made respectively by the adhvaryu and pratiprasthƒÅts and the camas√§dhvaryus offer the soma taken in their camasas and the remnants are partaken by the priests. After this come the offerings of ajya called dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅhuti or

dƒÅk≈üina homa ( Kat. X. 1, 4., Sat. IX. 2. p. 910). The procedure - here resembles the Vaisarjina homa described above (p. 1158). Gold is tied by the hem of the garment that covers the yajamƒÅna and his family, it is placed in the ajya contained in the juh≈´, and two ahutis are offered with ‘udu tyam’ (Rg. I. 50.1 ) and ‘citram (Rg. I. 115. 1) in the g√§rhapatya fire, the piece of gold is taken out and the yajamƒÅna holding that gold piece and djya in his hand approaches the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅs (the various articles that constitute the fee) placed to the south of the mabƒÅvedi. Vide Sat. Br. IV. 3. 4 about dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ ( derived from ‘dak≈üay’ to invigorate) where it is stated that no priest should officiate at a soma sacrifice for a fee less than one hundred cows. ƒÄp. (XIII, 5. 1XIII. 7. 15) gives numerous rules about the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ to be distributed among the sixteen priests. The dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ may consist of 7, 21, 60, 100, 112, or 1000 cattle or an unlimited number or a man may give all his wealth except the share of the eldest son2015 and when he gives & thousand cattle or all his wealth he has to give one mule in addition ( Ap. XIII. 5. 1-3). He may also give goats, sheep, horges, slaves, an elephant, olothes, chariots, corn of various kinds, assos. A man may give his own daughter in marriage ( in the daiva form ) as fee (Adv. V. 13. 7). With regard to the cows meant as fee Ap. states that the yajamƒÅna drives them with the black antelope skin so as to form them into four groups. One group (i. e. of the whole number ) is given to the adhvaryu and his assistants

  1. Prof. Keith in Religion and Pbilosopby of the Veda’ part 2 p. 330 days after which the fees should be givon consisting of 7, 21… … cattle or all the sacrificer’s goods save his oldest son'. He obviously inoang save his oldest son’s sharo'.

Ch. XXXIII)

Agnistoma-distribution of dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ

1189

in such a way that the pratiprasthatƒô, nestr and unnets receive respectively half, one-third and one-fourth of what the adhvaryu gets; that is, as stated by Kat. X. 2. 25 and the com. on Ap. XIII. 2. 12, twelve cows are given to each of the four principal priests, 6, 4 and 3 respectively to each of their assistants in the order stated above in note 2228 (supposing one hundred cows are to be distributed ). Jai. ( as indicated below ) and Manu VIII, 210 refer to this rule of distribution. The √§gnidhra is the first recipient of gifts, receiving a piece of gold, p√ºr≈ÜapƒÅtra and a pillow woven with threads of all colours. The pratihartis the last recipient ( ƒÄp. XIII. 6. 2, K√§t. X. 2. 39). Gifts are made to the priests while they sit inside the sadas and to the adhvaryu and his assistants in the havirdhƒÅna pavilion. To s brahmana of the Atri gotra ( who is not a stvik) a gold piece is given before everybody else or after the ag nidhra ( Ap. XIII. 6. 12, K√§t. X. 2. 21 ). After the ƒÅgnidhra come brahmƒÅ, udgƒÅts and hotr ( KƒÅt. X. 2. 26 ). Apart from the gifts meant for the ftviks something is given accord ing to ability and inclination to the camasƒÅdhvaryus, the sadasya and to sight-seers in the sadas ( they are called prasar pakas), except to those who belong to the Kanva or Kasyapa gotra or those who ask for a gift (Ap. XIII.7.1-5, KƒÅt. X. 2.35). Ap. (XIII. 7.6-7 ) says that generally no gift is to be given to one who is not a brƒÅhmana, but a gift may be given to a non-brƒÅhma·πáa who knows the Vedic lore, while no gift is to be made to a brƒÅhma·πáa who is not learned. K√°t. X. 2. 38 states that the wife also joins in inaking gifts. After the anuv√°kya is repeated by the maitr√§varu≈Üa for the marutvatiya cup to be described below no gifts are made (Ap. XIII. 7, 14, Kat. X. 3,2). On making the gifts the sacrificer does obeisance (namaskƒÅra ) to the priests and utters an invocation as to ani. mals donated in the words who gave to whom ? “8814 Dr√§hy√§. yana (V, 3. 14-19 ) states that before accepting a gift every priest murmurs the famous mantra “I take thee at the impulse of god Savitr…. &c. (TƒÅ≈Üdya I. 8.1 ) and after receiving the gift each donee murmurs ‘who gave to whom’ (TƒÅndya I. 8. 17). The gifts are taken away by the path between the √§gnidhriya sbed and the sadas and then by the tirtha (Dr√°hy. yana V. 3. 13). Jai. ( X. 2. 22-28 ) declares that the making of gifts to the priests is not merely a formal sot as part of the gaorificial rites, but is intended to induce the priests to give

History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

their services in return for the gifte. In Jai. X. 3. 39-49 it is conoluded that in the words ‘the dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅ is 112’ the vedic text refers only to cows and not to the various kinds of corns, in X. 3. 50-52 that the division of the gifts is to be made by the sacrificer and not left to be done by the priests and that all the priests do not share equally, but acoording to the Vedic texts some get half (they are ardhina·∏• ), others one-third ( they are called tftiyina·∏•) and still others one-fourth ( X. 3.53-55). Jai. XII. 1. 32 states that as valuable gifts are given in Somayaga, there is no rice cooked (called anvƒÅhƒÅrya) for the priests in the i≈ütis of SomayƒÅga as there is in dar≈°apƒÅr≈ÜamƒÅsa (note 2390 ).

When the gifts are taken away by the priests the sacrificer casts away the antelope horn in the cƒÅtvƒÅla pit with two mantras ( Ap. XIII. 7. 16 ). Jai. ( IV. 2. 16-19 ) says that this casting away is the final disposal of the horn (it is & pratipatti karma) and (in XI. 3. 13-14 ) that this casting takes place on the last day in sacrifices like the Dr√§da≈õaba. The adhvaryu offers five offerings of ajya called Vai≈°vakarma≈Üa ( i. e. for Vigvakarman) in the ƒÅgnidhra fire with five mantras from Tai. S. III. 2. 8. 1-3 (Ap. XIII, 7. 17 and Sat. IX. 2. p. 911). The adhvaryu and the pratiprasthƒÅtr take two cups for ( Indra ) Marutvat and offer them. The remnants of the oup in prati prasthƒÅtr’s hand are poured in the adhvaryu’s cup; from this mixture a portion is poured in the cup of the pratiprasthƒÅts. The priests partake of the remnants. Then a third Marutvatiya cup is taken to the accompaniment of the bastra called marutvatiya2018

A pragatha is called Barhata when the two verses aro in Bruati and Satobohati metres and it is called Kakubba when thero is a combination of versos in the Kakubh and Satobrhati metros.

(Ch. XXXIII

each followed respectively by the gastras recited by the maltra Varu≈Üa, brƒÅhma·πáƒÅocharisin and acohƒÅ vƒÅka. This closes the mid-day pressing of soma.

The evening pressing commences with the taking of the Aditya cup ( a cup the deity of which is Aditi). In the third pressing the Vedic texts are to be uttered in the highest tone (Asy. V. 17. 1). The procedure in this pressing resembles that of the mid-day pressing (Sat. V. 3. p. 915). The adhvaryu, the sacrificer, the pratiprasthats, √§gnidhra and unnetz enter the havirdhƒÅna shed by the eastern door and the wife enters by the western door ( KƒÅt. X. 3. 2-3). The doors of the havirdhana shed are shut when there are many persons sitting inside the vedi ( ƒÄp. XIII. 9. 2, Sat. IX. 3, p. 915). The adbyaryu takes into the Aditya cup a part of the remnants of the some from the cups for the joint deities. In the middle or western part of the ƒÅditya cup he adds ourds and then again takes the whole of the remnants of the soma from the cups for the joint deities (that has been poured in the ƒÅdity asthall). He stirs the contents of the oup with the up≈´insusavana stone used in crushing the soma stalks and mixes them well together. He then takes out the stone and places it among the stones used for crushing soma stalks. The ƒÅditya cup is not placed down, but is covered with darbhas or with the right hand of the adhvaryu, who comes out after the doors of the havirdbƒÅna are opened, takes it to the uttara vodi, stirs the contents with darbhas in such a way that a few drops fall down out of the cup. After the usual prai≈üa and the other procedure the adhvaryu throws the darbhas on the ƒÅbavenlya and offers the contents of the aditya cup into fire. At the time of offering the contents and also immediately after doing so he does not look at the offering but looks elsewhere ( ƒÄsv. V. 17. 3). He does not partake of the remnants of soma in the aditya oup but keeps it with the remnants of soma therein among the several Vessels. He puts on the fil≈üa ( the dregs of some stalks ) that is left after the two pressings the stalks ( am≈õu ) that are in the adƒÅbhya vessel and the upƒÅmbup√§tra and silently extracts goma juice therefrom. In the agnidhra shed the sacrificer’s wife prepares by churning ‘asir’(milk mixed with soma) and enters the havirdhana shed by the western door. The yajamƒÅna enters by the eastern door, spreads on the mouth of the p≈´tabhrt trough the strainer and pours thereon along with his wife the ƒÅtir with four mantras ( Tai, S. III. 2. 8. 4-5). He

The havis prepared from the various limbs of the (savaniya) pasu sacrificed in the morning is then offered (Ap. XIII. 11. 3, ƒÄsv. V. 17, 4). The √§gnidhra carries lighted roots of darbhas to the several dhispyas and establishes them thereon as fires and the adhvaryu pours ajya taken afresh in a pot over them while the darbhas are glowing (Ap. that, though Rg. III. 6. 9 ( the yajya verse ) contains & prayer about the thirty-three gods, the P√°tnivata is not to be supposed to be offered to them also. The adhvaryu then issues various directions to the several priests ( Ap. XIII. 14. 11, Sat. IX. 4. p. 930). The √§gnidhra sits on the lap 2017 of the neste and par takes of the remnants of the Patnivata cup (A≈°v. V. 19. 8, K√°t. X. 6. 24), while so sitting. He washes that oup on the mƒÅrj. llya and keeps it on the khara. The camases of the hotƒô and others are filled by the unnets in such a way that no soms is left, the two jars of soma are wiped with the da≈°ƒÅs and they are all kept with mouths turned downwards. The adhvaryu starts the udgƒÅts priests on their chant of Yaj√±ƒÅyaj√±iya stotra ( Ap. XIII. 15, 3), which is the principal stotra of the Agnistoma (Sat. IX. 4. p. 931 calls it ‘Agnistoma Sƒ´man’). All those priests who are to chant the stotra and the choristers cover thair heads together with the ears. 2428 Those who come as sight-seers into the sadas should join in the chant as choristers ( ƒÄp. XIII. 15. 6). When the udg√§tr makes the bink√°ra of the yaj√±ƒÅyaj√§lya stotra he looks at the sacrificer’s wife who is brought by the nestr near the udg√§ty. When the nidhana (Anale) of the first verse is being sung the wife removes the garment from her right thigh and with her face to the north pours the pƒÅnnejani water on her thigh up till the prastƒÅvs of the third stotriya of the first paryƒÅya 4828 ( 80 es to leave no water in the jar ). The wife retires to her shed when the udgƒÅts asks her to go or when he has looked at her thrice and she has poured water thrice ( KƒÅt. X. 7. 5-6). While the chant proceeds the sporificer repeats the saptahots mantras (note 2393 above). The Yaj√±ƒÅyaj√±iya saman is Rg. VI. 48. 1-2= S√•maveda

2621, Ap. XIII, 16. 1 and Sat, IX. 4. p. 931 do not apparently liko this sitting on the lap of the Deatr and so give an option to w ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§• ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§' ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§¢.

Verse has a response which is mada modaiva moda modaiva (or-daivom ). 3637

When the last verse (paridhƒÅniya) of the AgnimƒÅruta sastra is being recited (or at one of several other stages, accord ing to Ap. XIII. 16. 2-5 and Sat. When the upayƒÅja homa with reference to the animal killed in the morn ing is performed and the paridhis are cast into the fire, be takes the Hariyojana cup.2088 The unnetr brings into it all the soma contained in the agrayana-sthall and mixes therein plenty of fried barley grains, places the oup on his head, comes out of the havirdhƒÅna shed, steps backwards and forwards several times. Then the contents are offered to Indra ( the ty√°ga by the yajamƒÅna is ‘idam IndrƒÅya harivate ‘) and the remnants are brought to the sadas for being partaken by the priests and the sacrificer. They distribute the remnants into other vessels, drink the fluid only smacking their lips, press the fried grains between their teeth so as to extract and take in all juice out of them and spit out of the vedi the mastioated fried grains and sip water. According to some ( Kat. X. 8.5) the priests only smell the fried grains. They throw chips of the tree from which the y√ºpa was made into the ƒÅhavaniya each with thou art the expiation ( means of removal) of the evil caused by gods, men pitys &o.’ (Vaj. 8. VIII, 13., Tai. History of Dharmatastra

(Ch. XXXIII

grass, squeeze that grass well, impart to the water & sharp flavour ( by the juice of the d≈´rvƒÅ ), pour the water into ten cama888. Each priest smells his camasa ( and those who have’ none smell the one nearest to them) to the west of the c√°tvƒÅla or in the place (called AstƒÅva ) where the Bahi≈üpavamƒÅna was obanted ( Ap. XIII. 17. 9, K√§t. X. 8. 7, Sat. IX. 4. p. 935 ) and pour the water down into the catvƒÅla pit ( Sat. IX. 4 p. 935, or inside the vedi according to Ap. XIII, 18.1). All priests wait upon the ahavaniya with the mindƒÅ mantra ‘yanma atmano mindabh≈´t’( whatever fault has been mine, Agni has mended it' &c. Tai. S. III. 2. 5. 4). The priests then discharge them selves from the vow made at the TƒÅn≈´naptra ceremony. Then the PatnisamyƒÅjas are performed as in the animal sacrifice (Ap. XIII. 18. 3). The adhvaryu offers with the juhu nine sami≈ütayajus offerings in a continuous stream, standing inside the vedi, Then he performs the prayascittas for actions like spilling soma drops about and offers a savanƒÅhuti ( i.e. an ajya offering indioating the completion of the Agnistoma). The adhvaryu issues a direction to the maitrƒÅvarupa to urge the priests to come out of the sacrificial shed and the latter do 80.

Then follows the Avabhrtha (the final purificatory bath ). The procedure of this is an i≈üti. Jaimini, however, in X.7. 47-50 lays down that the avabhrtha is a special rite and therefore all that takes place in the dar≈õap√ºr≈ÜamƒÅsa i≈üti does not follow as a matter of course. A fuel-stick is laid on fire, a veda bunch is made, kuss is strewn round the fires ( that is paris tarans), the necessary yaj√±apƒÅtras are placed with mouths downwards. No idhma is brought and some do not even prepare the vedi. Only four ladlings of Ajya are taken in all the ladies ( sruc). The nirvƒÅpa is only for & cake to Varu≈Üa on one potsherd (Ap. XIII. 19. 3). There are no pranit√† waters (Sat. IX. 5. p. 938), and no girding up of the wife ( vide above p. 1040 for it). The ajya in the ladles and the grains taken out for puroda≈°s are placed on the shoulder ( north corner on eastern side) of the uttaravedi. The sacrificer takes out from its pit the post of udumbara ( audumbari in the sadas ), places it on the hide and board used in extracting soma juice and all other utensils except the four sthƒÅlis viz. the agrayana, ukthya, aditya-otball and dhruv√§sthali ( vide Tai. Br. I. 4. 1 for these four sthalls of olay ) that are smeared with soma in the space between the catvala pit and the utkara or on the northern shoulder of the vedi on the large stool ( Asandi ) used for soma.

Ob. XXXIII )

Agni≈ütoma-Avabh·ªãtha

1199

The yajam√§na casts away the antelope skin in the otvƒÅla pit .( other ways of disposal are also mentioned in Ap. XIII. 19. 8-9). When starting for avabhrtha he offers clarified butter with ‘O1 Fire, that givest life &o.’ (Tai. S. I. 3. 14. 4), a second oblation with the mantra ‘avabb»ôtha, nicumpu√±a &o.’ ( V√°j. S. VIII. 27 ).2839

A third oblation of ajya is made to Rudra (Ap. XIII. 20.1) with ‘namo RudrƒÅya’ (Tai. Br. III. 7. 9). When starting from the vedi or from near the cƒÅtvƒÅla with faces to the north they recite Rg. I. 24. 8 (Tai. S. 1. 4. 45. 1). The adhyaryu isgues a direction to the prastot; to chant & saman. The sƒÅman chanted is oalled ‘avabb»ôthasƒÅman’ (LƒÅt. II. 12. 1). It is ‘agni≈ütapati’ (vide Sat. Br. IV.4.5.8 and Dr√°hyƒÅyana ≈õr. VI. 4.1). When the nidhana of the s√§man is being sung, all the priests, the yaja. mƒÅna and his wife thrice repeat that finale. They do so a second time when they have traversed half of the distance to the reservoir of water and a third time when they reach the water ( Ap. XIII. 20. 4 and Sat. IX. 5. p. 941). The same pro. oedure is followed for the Varu≈Üa purodƒÅsa as in Varu≈Üapra ghages for niskƒÅsa. The dregs of soma are thrown into water with the branch of the udumbara tree and ourds are poured over it. All utensils smeared with soma are thrown into water (Ap. XIII. 21. 12, K√§t. X, 8. 24). Jai. (IV. 2. 19-22) says that this casting into water is merely the final disposal (pratipatti) of these utensils and the fruti passage they approach the water for the final bath with whatever is smeared with soma' does not lay down any subordinate matter about avabbstha. The girdle of the yajamƒÅna and the yoktra, the j√§la ( net on the head of the wife) and the antelope skin of the wife are dipped in water. The yajamƒÅna invokes the water with ‘devirƒÅpa·∏•’ (Tai, s. I. 4. 45, 3) and enters. The deep silent waters of flowing rivers are to be preferred, but in the absence of such waters any water reservoir will do (K√§t. X.8.19). The yajamƒÅna and the wife enter water, splash water on their heads (but do not dip them into water), rub each other’s back. A handful of ku≈°a is thrown into the water and this handful in the water serves as the ahavaniya for all abutis in avabhrtha.

History of Dharmat≈´sira

on. XXXIII

The prayƒÅjas and apuy√°jas are offered as in darsap≈´rpamƒÅsa (except to God Barhis). Jal. (XI. 2. 30-34) lays down that not, only is the principal offering of purod√°sa offered into water but also all subordinate ones like Aghoras. A. portion of the purodaka for Varupa is offered therein. The rest of the purodƒÅsa is offered to Agni and Varuna, which becomes the Svi≈ütakst offering in this case (Kat. X. 8. 27, Sat. IX. 5 p. 944). The unnets at the direction of the adhvaryu leads all out of the water ( the yajamana or hots being the first ). The yajamina and his wife put on fresh garments and come out. The cloth with which some was enveloped is worn as a turban by the yajamƒÅna and that in which soma stalks were tied is worn by the wife and both the pieces of cloth are donated later on in the Udavas√§niya i≈üti to the adhvaryu ( Ap. XIII. 22. 3-4). The priests, the yajamƒÅna and the wife hold each a fuel-stick of udumbara, mutter the Mably√§ pk (viz. apƒÅma somam-ara≈üt√• abh≈´ma, Rg. VIII. 48. 3), proceed following the unnet; towards the sacrificial ground without looking baok at the water, perform m√§rjana in front of the cow-stable (of the Bacrificer) and place the fuel-stick (carried by each) on the ahavaniya with.edhosi &c.'(Tai, 8. I. 4. 45. 3) and wait upon that fire with ‘apo anvacari≈üam’ (Ap. XIII. 22. 6 quoting Tai. S. I. 4. 45. 3). Then follows the UdayaniyƒÅ (the concluding i≈üti). It is performed in the prƒÅgvan≈°a (and not on the specially prepared uttaravedi). The procedure is like that for the prƒÅyaniya i≈üti (already described on p. 1140). In the same sthall (pot) in which the pr√°yaptyƒÅ offering was cooked and to the bottom of whiob some remnants stick be takes the offering for this i≈üti. The wife again ties round her waist the yoktra. PrayƒÅjas are optional and if not offered no djya is taken in the juba. The yƒÅjvƒÅs and anuv√°kyƒÅs of the prayanlyƒÅ become respectively the anuv. kyda and ydjyds of the Udayanly√•. The order of deities is different, viz. Agni is the first, Pathy. Svasti the last for ajya offerings (Ap. XIII. 23. 4, Sat. IX. 6. p. 950, Asv. VI. 14. 3). When the Udayanƒ±yd is finished the anubandhyƒÅ rite follows $630 (Ap. XIII. 23. 6, Sat. IX. 6. p. 951). A barren oow is to be offered to Mitra and Varu≈Üa. The procedure is the same as that of Niradha-pa≈°u-bandha. Some sacrificed three anubandhya cows viz. to Mitra and Varuna, to the Visve Devas and to Bphaspati,

Agnistoma-anubandhya cow

1201

but ƒÄp. ( XIIL 23, 6. 10 and 14) rostriots them to V√°japeye, RƒÅjas√ºya and sattras. KƒÅt. XIII. 24. 10 states that in place of the anubandh·ªπ& cow the followers of Rgveda offered amiksƒÅ to Mitra-Varupa and the offering was made by the hots in front of the havirdhana shed and all the ceremonies in the archetype i≈üti up to Ida were performed in that rite. After the anubandhya (or amik≈üa) was offered came the five offerings called Devika viz. & cake on twelve potsherds to Db√°ts and four oblations of rice cooked in milk in the four sthalis mentioned above (in which soma had been placed) to Anumati, RƒÅka, Siniv√§li and Kuh≈´ (Asv. VI. 14. 15, Ap. XIII. 24. 1-3). The yajamƒÅna shaves his hair and moustache near the southern side of the vedi (Ap. XIII. 23. 16). The abovaniya fire is taken to the north outside the mahƒÅvedi in an earthen-ware vessel and the ku≈°as strewn on the vedi are burnt thereon and the smoke issuing therefrom is invoked with a mantra (Sat. IX. 6. p. 954), the adhvaryu offers on the fire (of the kubas) ground barley from his joined hands (Ap. XIII. 24. 16-17). The fires are then deposited in the ara√±is by repeating ‘ayam te yonih’(Rg. III. 29.10, Tai. 8. 1. 5. 2, V√°j. S. III. 14 ) as stated in ƒÄ≈õv. III. 10. 5. Having given up the sacrificial ground he again produces fire by attrition to the north of the sacrificial ground and the udavasƒÅniyƒÅ isti is performed. 2638 In this i≈üti a cake baked on eight or five potsherds is offered to Agni (Ap. XIII. 25, 5, Sat. IX. 6. p. 956). In this i≈üti (A≈°v. VI. 14. 24) everything is done as in the punarƒÅdbeya, but the mantras are muttered inaudibly in all cases exoept the last anuyƒÅja. A bull is the fee or as much gold as will purchase a bull. Instead of this i≈üti an offering of √§jya was inade by some ( Ap. XIII. 25, 7-8) from the jub≈© in which twelve ladlings were made with sruva with idam vi≈ünur’ (Rg. I. 22. 17 ).

120%

History of DharmadƒÅstra

(Ch. XXXIII

Ingenious theories have been advanced by European scholars about the origin of the soma sacrifices. Considera tions of space forbid the discussion of this topic here. Those who are interested in these speculations may consult Prof. Eggeling’s Introduction to 8. B. E. vol. 26 pp. XI-XXIII (wbere several European works are cited and questions about Boma are discussed), L' Agnistoma (pp. 481-490), Prof. Keith’s * Religion and philosophy of the Veda &o. pp. 331-332 and the works cited there. With the greatest respect for all these learned and industrious European savants it must be said that none of the theories has any great plausibility or carries con vlotion. The cult of the soma is at least Indo-Iranian and no sure traces are left in the ancient Indian religious books of the origin of that cult. We have simply the institution of the sacrifice before us and all else is imagination and speculation. One important question is the relation of the plant soma to the moon (also called some as in Rg. X. 85. 1 and 2). The moon is generally called ‘man’ or ‘candramas’ in the Rg. (Rg. V.51. 15, X. 85. 19, VIII. 94. 2, X. 12. 7, X. 68. 10). In Rg. VIII. 82. 8 occurs the very striking simile 4833 ‘Soma that is seen among the (soma) vessels as the moon in waters’ and the Atharvaveda (XI. 6.7) states that the god whom people call Candramas is soma. In several places soma is addressed as indu (which certainly means the moon in later literature ). Vide Rg. IX. 86. 24, 26, 37, VIII. 48. 2, 4, 5, 12, 13. It is said that soma grew on M≈´javat (Rg. X. 34. 1) and in the Arjikiya country (Rg. VIII, 64, 11) on the river Susom.. Even in the Rgveda soma appears to have become mythical. In Rg. IX. 86.24 goma is said to have been brought from heaven by Suparna ( eagle or bird?) and in I. 93. 6 by a Syena (hawk). Another matter to be noted is that the soma plant had certainly become rare, 36% if not unobtainable, in the times of the BrƒÅhma·πáas, The Sat. Br. IV. 5. 10 mentions several substitutes for soma, among which are Phalguna plants having brown flowers,

  1. gi seg H T HAUEK Tut. VIII. 82. 8; FIAT #Tant EUT VARIETAT PRET I sput XI. 6. 7. Vide Prof. Keith’s remarks on Hillebrandt’s viows of the identification of the plant with the moon (Intro. to T.i. 8. p. CXX ).

  2. Vide 8.B.E. vol. 26 p. XXIV ff for the identification of Soma with cortain plants. Vide 8.B.E vol. 26 pp. 421-422 for the several substitutes for Soma mentioned in sat. Br. Prof. Keith (Intro. to Tai. 8. p. OXIX ) holds that the question of the identification of the soma plant cannot roully be fiarlly determinod,

PB. eskaith (Intro tebe some

Oh. XXXIII)

Agniƒôtomar-soma plant

1203

D√ºb plant and greenish kubas. The Tandya Br. says ‘If one does not secure soma, one may extract juice from p√•tikas’, 3645 *Jai. (III. 6. 40 and VI. 3. 13-17 ) states that this passage res tricts & sacrifioer when no soma is available to p≈´tikas and prevents the employment of other substances similar to soma and in VI. 3. 31 he declares that p≈´tikas are the proper prati nidhi ( substitute ) for soms and not any other substance even if it may be more similar to soma than p≈´tikas, but that if both p≈´tika and soma are unavailable then another substance similar to soma may be employed. A≈°v. (VI. 8. 5-6) states that if soma stalks be not available thon p≈´tika stalks and Phalguna plant should be used or other plants mired with p≈´tikas may be employed (and the com. adds that those others are d√•rv√•, kusa and the like). In the Deccan the plant that is taken to repre sent soma when soms sacrifices are rarely performed is called

r√•nsera' (in Marathi) which grows in the bills of the Deccan.

  1. Tra ### forg: gumagayu guingua IX. 3. 3.

GTKCHAPTER XXXIV OTHER SOMA SACRIFICES

The s√ºtras speak of seven forms ( samstbas ) of soma sacrifices. These seven forms are Agni≈ütoma, Atyagnistoma, Ukthya, Sodasin, Vajapeya, Atir√§tra and AptoryƒÅma (according to Kat. X. 9. 27, ƒÄ√°v. VI. 11. 1, Lat. V. 4. 24). The first of these has been described in some detail above. Owing to restrictions of space only a few words can be said about the other goma sacrifices. All sutras do not state the same number of soms sacrifices. Ap. XIV. 1.1 and Sat. IX.7. p. 958 expressly say that Ukthya, Sodasin, Atir√§tra and AptoryƒÅma are the modifications of Agnistoma and the commentaries of both point out that there were several views on the number of the modifica. tions of the Agniƒôtoma. In the Brahmapas the Agni≈ütoma, Ukthya, Sodasin and Atiratra are generally mentioned as formg of Jyoti≈ütoma (vide Sat. Br. IV, 6. 3. 3, Tai. Br. I. 3.% and 4, which last mentions Vajapeya also ).

Ukthya or Uktha. - In this there are three more stotras (called uktha stotras ) and sastras (called uktha sastras ) to be chanted and recited in the evening pressing, thus bringing the total of stotras and bastras to fifteen (Ait. Br. 14. 3, Asv. VI. 1. 1-3). Ap. XIV. 1. 2 says that the Ukthya, ≈ûodasin, Atir√§tra and AptoryƒÅma are respectively performed by him who desires cattle, vigour, progeny and cattle, all objects. In the Ukthya an additional victim, & goat (over and above those offered in Agnistoma ) is sacrificed for Indra and Agni on the pressing day. Vide Ait. Br. XIV. 3, A≈°v. VI. 1.1-3, Ap. XIV.1, Sat. IX. 7. pp. 958-959, Haug’s tr. of Ait. Br. p. 251 n, 8. B. E. vol, 41, pp. XIV-XVI. .

Sodasin. In this sacrifice in addition to the fifteen stotras and fifteen sastras of the Ukthya there is an additional stotra and a corresponding sastra called ≈ûodasin in the trtiya savana (both the sastra and the sacrifice have the same name, as the com, on Asv. VI. %. 1 days). There is an additional oup in the morning or at all pressings according to some ( Ap. XIV. 2. 4-5). It is made of khadira wood and is quadrangular in shape ( Sat. IX. 7. p. 960 ). The stotra for the sodatin oup is begun to be chanted

Oh. XXXIV) Other Soma Sacrifices

1205

about sunset after the adhvaryu hands over a piece of gold to the sƒÅma singer (instead of kusa grass, Ap. XIV, 3.1 ). Soma is purchased for a cow that is of very small stature and has red coloured ears. In this rite an additional victim viz. & ram is sacrificed for Indra. The fee is & reddish brown horse or a female mule. Vide Ait. Br. 16. 1-4, A≈°v. VI, 2-3, ƒÄp. XIV. 2. 3 ff, Sat. IX. 7. pp. 959‚Äì962, Haug’s tr. of Ait. Br. p. 255-256n, S.B.E. vol. 41 pp. XVI-XVII for further details.

Atyagni≈ütoma. This form is obtained by adding the ≈üodasistotra, the ≈üodasin cup and an additional victim for Indra to what prevails in the Agniƒôtoma ; vide S. B. E, vol. 41, p. XVII.

AtitƒÅtra. This soma sacrifice is referred to even in the Rgveda ( VII, 103.7). As this sacrifice is not finished in one day but only after the day and night pass away it is called Atir√§tra. Ap. X. 2. 4 notes that according to some the AtirƒÅtra is performed even before Agnistoma. The Atir√§tra has 29 stotras and 29 sastras. In this the additional stotras and sastras are repeated at night in four rounds (called paryayas ) of three stotras and sastras. A≈°v. VI. 4. 10 points out these 12 sastras. In this sacrifice the sastra called A≈õvina is recited, but before it six √§hutis are offered at night. The Asvina-sastra closely follows the procedure of prataranuyaka, must comprise at least a thousand verses and was to be recited till sunrise (vide Haug': tr. of Ait. Br. pp. 268-269n for description of this sastra ). At twilight is chanted a stotra appropriately called Sandhistotrs (Haug’s tr. of Ait. Br. pp. 266-267n). It is in the Rathantara melody. If the sun did not rise by that time the hotƒô was to continue reciting Rg. I. 112 and when the sun rose he was to recite gaurya hymns (viz. Rg. X. 158, I. 50. 1-9, I. 115, X. 37). A fourth animal viz. en ewe (or ram according to some ) is offered to Saras vati on the pressing day (Sat. IX. 7. p. 963 ). The principal camasaa in the night are offered to Indra Apidarvara ( Sat. IX. 7. p. 963.). A purodaja on two potsherds is offered by the pratiprasthƒÅts to Afrins ( ƒÄ√∏v. VI. 5, 23 and Sat. IX. 7 p. 965) and a homs cup is offered to the Asvins. Jai. X. 8. 6 notes that as a vedic passage says there is no sodasin oup in Atiratra' and another says there is, the first is a prohibition and there is an option. For details vide Ait. Br. 14. 3 and 16.5-7, Akv. VI. 4-5, Sat. IX.7 pp. 662-665, Ap. XIV.3.8–XIV. 4. 11, S.B.E. vol. 41 pp. XVII-XX.

1206

History of Dharmasastra

( Oh. XXXIV

AptoryƒÅma-This sacrifice is similar to Atiratra of which it appears to be an amplification. Only there are four additional stotras (i. e. 33 in all) and four additional sastras recited by the hoty and his assistants, and there are four camasas in relation to these last respectively for Agni, Indra, Vi√üve Devas and Vi≈ünu (Ap. XIV. 4. 12-16, Sat. IX. 7 pp. 966-967, San. XV. 5. 14-18 and Sat. X. 8. p. 1111). Accord ing to A≈°v. (IX. 11. 1) he whose cattle do not live or who desires to secure cattle of good breed should perform the AptoryƒÅma. A≈°v. (IX. 9. 22-23 ) says that in this the fee is more than a thousand (cows) up to an unlimited number and the hotƒô gets a special gift of a white chariot (plated with silver) to which female mules are yoked. This sacrifice is generally joined with others. The TƒÅ≈Üdya Br. ( XX. 3. 4-5) states that the rite is so called because by its performance one seoures whatever object one desires ( from ‘ap’ to obtain ).

Vajapeya-(lit, food and drink, or drink of strength or of food or of a race ).8038 Though this rite is said to be a form of Jyoti≈ütoma and though it follows the procedure of Sodasin (Ap. XVIII. 1. 4) it has so many special features of its own that it may be said to be an independent sacrifice. One chara cteristio feature is that the number 17 is predominant in this sacrifice ( Ap. XVIII. 1.5, T√°pdya XVIII. 7.5), viz. there are 17 stotras and 17 sastras, the 17th being the VƒÅjapeya stotra and sastra, 17 animals sacrificed for Prajapati, 17 objeots distributed as fee, the y√ºpa ( of bilva or khadira wood) was 17 aratnis in length, at the time of enveloping the y√ºpa with a girdle in this rite 17 pieces of cloth were employed for the purpose ( ƒÄp. XVIII. 1. 12 ), it lasted for 17 days (for 13 days dik≈üa, 3 upasad days and one pressing day) or there were 17 dik≈üas (and then the rite lasted for 21 days). Vide A≈°v. IX, 9. 2-3 and Ap. XVIII. 1. 6-7. Another feature was that there were seventeen oups of surƒÅ ( wine) for Prajapati as well as 17 cups of soma. Another peculiarity was that there were seventeen chariots to which horses were yoked and a race was run, when seventeen drums that were arranged on the northern ≈õroni of the vedi were simultaneously beaten ( Ap. XVIII. 4. 4 and 7, Kat. XIV, 3. 14 ) to the west of the √§gnidhra shed,

Ch. √ÖXXIV)

Va apeya

1207

This complicated rite was undertaken by one who desired overlordship (adhipatya, as A≈°v. IX. 9. 1 says) or prosperity (Ap. XVIII. 1.1) or sv√•rƒÅjya ( the position of Indra or uncontrolled dominion). It was performed in the autumn.8887 Only a brƒÅ. hma≈Üa or a k≈üatriya could perform it, but not a vai≈õya 2638 (KƒÅt. XIV. 1. 1 and Ap. XVIII. 1. 1). In the case of a brƒÅhma·πáa the reward aimed at must have been the attainment of the position of a super-eminently learned or prosperous man. All the priests, the sacrificer and his wife wear chains of gold, and Asv. IX. 9. 5 adds that the chain worn by the hotr has a hundred lotus like pendants studded with precious stones. The golden chain worn by each priest becomes part of his fee. Besides the three viz. for Agni, Indra and Agni and for Indra (a ram), & barren cow for Maruts and ewe for Sarasvati and 17 hornless, young and virile goats of one colour (or all of dark colour) for PrajƒÅpati are offered in this rite ( ƒÄp. XVIII. 2. 12-13, Kat: XIV. %. 11-13). For the 17 cups of wine (called parisrut, prepared from several herbs ) the pratiprasth√§tr prepares & separate mound ( khara ) to the west of the axle of the southern havirdh√£ng cart on which the wine cups made of clay are to be kept. The soma cups are to the east of the axle of the cart and wine cups to the west and they are to be kept separate. According to KƒÅt. ( XIV. 1. 17 and 26) it is the nestr priest that gets ready the mound and the wine cups. In the midst of the wine cups a golden cup of honey is placed (Tai. Br. I. 3.3, KƒÅt. XIV. 2. 9). The wine is purchased ready-made in exchange for lead from a long-haired man at the time when soma stalks are purchased, or the material, for making wine is bought, and is entered into the sacrificial enolosure by the southern door and is boiled on the dak≈üi≈Üa fire (K√°t. XIV. 1. 14-17). The y√ºpa has four angles (and not sight as elsewhere ) and has no top protruding beyond the oa≈üƒÅla, but its top is even and is slightly depressed in the middle. The ca≈üƒÅla of the y≈´pa ( which is 17 aratnis high ) is made of wheat flour ( Tai. Br. I. 3, 7, Ap. XVIII. 1. 8, Kat. XIV. 1. 22). A race is run in connection with the mid-day pressing in the

History of DharmadƒÅstra (Ch. XXXIV following way (Ap. XVIII. 3. 3 and 12-13). The Tai. Br. I. 3. % refers to the race won by Bfhaspati and connects the VƒÅjapeya with that race. Seventeen chariots are got ready to the east of the dhavaniya with their yokes to the north or east. One of them is the sacrificer’s chariot to which three horses are yoked with mantras and a fourth runs along the third but is not yoked. These horses are made to smell the caru of wild rice ( niv√•ra ) which is meant for B»ôhaspati. To the sixteen other chariots four horses each are yoked outside the vedi but without mantras (com. on Kat. XIV, 3, 11). A ksatriya ( rƒÅja putra according to Ap.) shoots an arrow from the space between the cƒÅtvƒÅla and utkara and notes the spot where it falls, from which he shoots an arrow a second time. This is done seventeen times. On the spot where the arrow falls at the 17th shooting, he plants a post of udumbara wood as the goal for the chariot race ( ƒÄp. XVIII. 3. 12 and Kat. XIV. 3. 1-11 and 16-17). When the race starts, the brahmƒÅ priest fixes an udumbara ohariot-wheel (having seventeen spokes according to K√§t. V. 12. 11 ) on an axle (or udumbara post navel-high ) implanted on a spot between the c√£tvƒÅla and the utkara (or near the utkara ) and ascends on that wheel with at the impulse of God Savitr may I win vƒÅja (vigour, food or race) with the help of Bphaspati, the winner of vƒÅja' (Ap. XVIII. 4. 8, KƒÅt, XIV. 3. 12 which mentions Vaj. S. IX. 10). When the wheel is revolved from left to right ( it is revolved thrice) the brahma chants the VƒÅji-saman 2688 (Ap. XVIII. 4. 11, ƒÄ√∏v. IX. 9. 8. LƒÅ»õ. V. 12. 14). According to L√§t. ( V. 12. 13 ) the brahm√£ only rests his arms on the wheel. The yajam√§na ocoupies the chariot on which mantras were recited and the adhvaryu ( or his pupil ) also gets into it to instruct the yajamƒÅna to repeat the Vedic formulao he has to utter. Other persons (called vƒÅjas»ôt) join in the race and sit in the other sixteen chariots and a ksatriya or vaisya site in one of them and the race starts with speed. All the seventeen drums are beaten on the northern sropi of the vedi to urge on the horses. All the horses are made to smell the caru of wild rice ( nIv√°ra ) cooked in 17 pots for Bphaspati. The chariot of the sacrificer is in front and the others follow his, but do not overtake it. The adhvaryu makes the yajamina

Vajapeya

1209

recite the formulae of victory such as ' agnirekak≈üarena' (V√°j. S. VIII. 31-34, Tai. S. I. 1. 11 ). When the chariot reaches the goal, the chariot is taken to its north and then turned round to the south. All the chariots return to the sacrificial ground and the horses are again made to smell the caru of niv√§ras and a homa is offered for dischar ging the drums ( dundubhi-vimocanlya-homa ). A berry ( krsnala, gold of that weight) is given to each of those that rode the chariots, but that gold is taken back from them and is donated to the brahm√£ who also receives the golden jar of honey (Kat, XIV. 4. 17, ƒÄp. XVIII. 5. 5 ) after it is presented to and taken back from the k≈üatriya or valby. The oups of Boma are taken up by the priests (the adhvaryu taking the hotr-camasa), and the camas√• √§hvaryus take up their cups ; while the pratiprasthƒÅtr takes up the principal wine cup and the other sixteen are taken up by those who joined in the race. The adhvaryu starts towards the east with the soma cups with * sam prca·∏•' (Tai. Br. I. 3. 3 ), the pratiprasth√°tr to the west with the wine cups and stands near the m√§rjallya shed. After the adhvaryu offers the soma cups, the wine cups are shaken and given to the sixteen persons who took part in the race and they quaff them on the southern groni of the vedi. According to K√§t. (XIV. 3. 20 and XIV. 4, 16) the ksatriya or vaisya who sat in one of the chariots receives all the wine cups. When preparations are made to chant the Mahendra stotra, the nestr requests the wife to put on short undergarment of darbha and the yajamƒÅna wears a silken garment (tƒÅrpyam ) 2040 inside the garment which he wears as a dik≈üita. A ladder is raised against the y√ºpa to its north or south (KƒÅt. XIV, 5, 5) and when the sacrificer climbs to the top of the y√ºpa a dialogue ensues between the sacrificer and his wife (Kat. XIV. 5. 6-11, ƒÄp. XVIII. 5. 9-11). The sacrificer addresses ‘wife, come, let us ascend to heaven’. The wife responds ‘let us ascend’. They engage in this dialogue thrice. According to K√§t. XIV. 5.8 both husband and wife climb to the top of the y√ºpa, while accor ding to Ap. (XVIII. 4. 12) only the husband does so who finally says ‘out of us both I shall ascend to heaven’. On reaching the top he touches the oa≈üƒÅla of wheat flour and mutters' we reached the heaven, the gods' (Tai. S. I. 7.9. 2, V√°j. S. IX. 21). Thence he looks at his house with May I live long with my children'

History of Dharmatasira

(Ch. XXXIV

(Tai. S. I. 7. 9, 2) or in the several directions with V√°j. 8. IX. 22 ( K√§t. XIV. 5. 11). Vaisyas (explained as his children by the com. on Kat. XIV. 5. 12 ) throw up to him 17 bags of Balt or saltish earth enveloped in leaves of asvattha or (acoord ing to Ap. XVIII. 5. 16-18) the adhavaryu, brahmƒÅ, hots and udgats raise up the bags to his face on long poles respectively from the east, south, west and north with mantras (referring to food, vƒÅja and winning of vƒÅja) Ho receives them and descende. He plants his right foot on a piece of gold placed over a goat-skin spread in front of the y√ºpa on the ground with its neok to the east and hairy side outside and his left foot on the skin itself and from thence he sits down on a couch placed on the west side of the uttaravedi. The offerings of the omentum and other limbs of the animal for Sarasvati and of other animals are made, the wild rios caru for Bphaspati is offered and the priests partake of the remnants as usual. The animals for PrajƒÅpati are offered at the time of the mid-day pressing. Before the offering to Svi≈ütak√Ωt of the wild rice caru is made water and milk are poured in a vessel of udumbara and food of seventeen kinds of grains or of as many as the sacrificer remembers except one is also put therein and seven offerings are made of all this with the sruva and the yajamƒÅna is sprinkled with the rest (Kat. XIV. 5. 20-24). He does not eat throughout his life-time the food of the one kind of grain that was omitted. The adhvaryu declares thrice after taking the name of the sacrificer ‘he, so and so, is samrat’ (overlord). Ap. XVIII. 7. 18 says that on performing vƒÅjapeya & man is entitled to use the white parasol. After the performance of VƒÅjapeya the sacrificer had to observe certain rules of conduct (vide L·ªÑt. VIII, 12, 1-4, Ap. XVIII. 7. 16-17). He should act like a k≈üatriya (i. e. he may study and make gifts, but should not teach or accept gifts ), he should not rise to receive or do abbivƒÅdana or carry #1 errands for or sit on the game couch with a person who had not performed that sacrifice. The adhvaryu receives the horses and the chariot in which the sacrificer sat (Ap. XVIIL 3. 10) and receives also all the 17 olothes with which the y√ºpa was enveloped. As to other fees there is some divergence among Ap. XVIII. 3. 4-5, A≈°v. IX. 9, 14-17, Kat. XIV. 2. 29-33 and LƒÅ≈£. VIII. 11. 16-2%. VƒÅjapeya

1211

horgos, seventeen animals which men ride, seventeen draught oxen, seventeen carts, 17 slave-girls decked with golden ni≈ükas round their necks, 17 elephants with golden girt bs-these consti. tute the fee in VƒÅjapeya and A≈°v. suggests other alternatives. Ap. XVIII. 3. 4 is almost the same but adds seventeen goats and ewes. Lat (VIII. 11. 16-18) is also practically the same as A√∏y. but adds several alternatives about cows. In the Kuruva japeya ( variously explained in the com.) cows donated are only 17, in other V√°japeyas 1700 or 17000 cows may be given. Lat. further says that the gifts may be equally divided among all the priests, that the chariot ocoupied by the sacrificor over which yajus mantras were recited and the couob with its coverlet are given to the udg√§tƒô, the goat-skin with the golden piece is taken by the hots.

It will have been noticed that this sacrifice has several picturesque elements in it. In the race and the drinking bout of seventeen cups there is a popular element. In the climbing to the top of the y√ºpa by the sacrificer and in the boiled wild rice for Bphaspati there is & symbolism of holiness and eminence.

Asv. IX. 9. 19 says that after performing V√°japeya a king should perform Rajas≈´ya and & brƒÅbmana should perform Bphaspatieava, 3648 while ƒÄp. XVIII, 7. 15 recommends the SautrƒÅma≈Üi after it. Kat. ( XIV. 1.2-8) states various views.

Jaimini in several adhikaranas deals with the fruti texts about V&japeya. They may be briefly indicated here. In I. 4. 6-8 he shows that in the sentence one desiring to seoure overlordship should sacrifice with VƒÅjapoya' the word VƒÅjapeya is the name of & rite (karmanƒÅmadheya) and that that sentence does not lay down some subordinate matter ( such as what material is to be used ) in the model sacrifice and that the word vƒÅjapeya does not mean gruel or similar substance. In Jai, III. 1. 18 it is said that the taxt of the V√°japeya the y√ºpa is 17 aratnis'

(Ch. XXXIV

means that the y√ºpa required for the sacrifice of animals in the VƒÅjapeya is to be 17 aratnis high and not that any other thing like the Sodasipatra was to be 17 aratnis. When the T·∫°i. Br. ( I. 3, 4 ) says that seventeen animals are to be killed for Prajapati, they are 17 separate yƒÅgas and not one rite ( karma). When it is said that caru is prepared in milk in seventeen sarƒÅvas ( pots), the method of taking out handfuls of grains ( as in dar≈õap√ºrnamƒÅsa ) is not applicable. Jai, says (in XI. 4. 30 ) that the vessel ( kumbhi), the ≈õ≈´la and the spit for roasting the omentum are the same for all the viotims, that the omentum of the victim for PrajƒÅpati is not sprinkled with the ƒÅjya remaining after the prayƒÅja offerings are made ( IV.1. 33-39) and that the chariot which was ocoupied by the sacrificer is to be specially given to adhvaryu and not any one of the seventeen chariots i.e. there is a restrictive rule about the share in chariots for the adhvaryu, while there is none as to the other priests ( X. 3. 74-75 ). 2018

The Agnistoma and the other forms of some sacrifices so far described are ekƒÅha ( one day ) soma sacrifices i. e. in them soma is offered in cups on one day thrice (in the morning, mid day and evening ). The s≈´tras (e. g. A√∏v. IX. 5-11, Baud. XVIII, 1-10, K√°t. XXII), however, mention and describe several other one day soma sacrifices, such as B·ªãhaspatioava, Gosava, Syena, Udbhid, Visvajit, Vr√°tyastoma (already dese cribed above on pp. 345-347) which are left out for want of space. 8644

  1. The Visvajit from among the ok≈´bas is a very striking saori foo. In this the sacrificer either gives a thousand cows or all wealth after separating the share of the eldest son (and excepting land and Sudras who serve him as a duty). Jai, sets out several propositions about this sacrifice in IV. 3. 10-16, VI. 7. 1-20, VII, 3., 6-11, X. 6. 13. After this rite, the sacrificer stays three days at the root of an uduin bara tree subsisting on fruits and roots, for three days in a sottlement of pisadas ( where ho may subsist on nivaras i. e, on rice, dyauaka and the filesb of deer ), for tbree days among vaidyas (jana, also explained as porsons of another gotra ‘:) and three days with kpatriya :(savƒÅnajana,

Ch. XXXIV

Ahina sacrifices

1213

The abina sacrifices 8045 are those the duration of wbich is two to twelve days of soma pressing, which always end with an atir√§tra and wbich together with the dikgƒÅ and upasad days should not extend beyond a month. They should be begun on & Full Moon day. Among them there are groups of sacri. fices that last for two days, three days (e. 8. GargatrirƒÅtra ), four days, five days (called pa√±oarƒÅtras of which Pa√±caƒüƒÅra diya is one ), sadabas and so on. Among the numerous rites called ahinas, the Asramedha and DyƒÅdasƒÅha deserve notice. The A≈õvamedha will be described later on. The DvƒÅda≈õƒÅha is both an ahina and a sattra ( A≈õy. X. 5. 2). There are several varteties of DrƒÅda≈õaba, one being called Bharata-dv√•dasƒÅhs (Aby. X. 5. 8., Ap. XXI. 14. 5). The twelve days of the DvƒÅ. dasƒÅha 88 & sattra are constituted by the PrƒÅganiya ( the com mencing rite, an Atiratra ), Prsthya ≈ûadaba 2646 ( 6 days), Chan domas whioh are Ukthyas (3 days) and a tenth day which is

( Continued from last page) also expalined as sagotras ). For it yoar ho should aot refuse what is offered but should not beg. Vide Kat, XXII. 1. 9-33, L√§t. VIII.2. 1-13. Tbo Gosava is a very strange rite. Tho Tai. Br. II. 7.6 briefly describes it. One who desires ov√°rajya may perform it and Ap. ( XXII. 12. 12-20 and XXII. 13. 1-3) states that for a year thereafter he should be pasuvrata (act like cattle ) i, n. should drink water like them and cut grass (with his teeth ) anil approach his mother &c. (probably only as & make-believe ). TOT HTAR Tan Tai gergruiainfo meso FUTC 1 JT ATATLATTEO FRE 2 1314. XXII. 13. 1-3. Another very striking ekabe sacrifice is the FETT. This is porformed by one who desires to die ou perforining it and to obtain heaven. History of Dharma≈õƒÅstra (Ch. XXXIV

an Atyagnistoma (called Aviv√°kya, on which no speaking or dispute about errors is allowed) and the Udayaniya (conr cluding rite, which again is an Atiratra ). The principal differences between the Dv√•da≈õaba as an abins and a sattra are: (1) & sattra can be performed only by bribmapas, while a dv√°dasƒÅba may be performed by any one of the first three varpas ; (2) the sattra may extend over even long periods ( such 28 a year or more ), while a dvadasaha cannot so extend ; (3) in the sattra the distinction of yajamƒÅns and priests does not exist but all are yajamƒÅnas and all work as priests, while in dvadasaba that distinction exists ;(4) ( as a consequence of the above) in & sattra there are no dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅs. Kat. XII. 1. 4 states that wherever in the vedio texts the words ‘upayanti’and’ Agate’ ocour it is a sign of a ‘sattra’ (and so in that case the rules about sattras will apply ) but where the word ‘yajate’ or ‘yƒÅjayet’ is used it is a sign of an ahina. In an abins only the last day is an Atiratra, but in a sattra both the first and last days are Atir√§tras (Kat. XII. 1. 6).

It is now necessary to say something about a few other striking sacrifices.

RƒÅjas≈´ya.‚ÄîThis is strictly not a purely soma sacrifice, but it is a most complex ceremony extending over a very long period (more than two years) and comprising a number of separate i≈ütis (like the one to Anumati), Soma sacrifices (like Pavitra) and animal sacrifices (K√§t. XV. 1. 3). Even the briefest statement of the several rites will ocoupy many pages. An attempt will be made to indicate only a few salient features.

This ceremony could be performed only 2647 by a ksatriya. There was a difference of view, some holding that it could be performed only by him who had not celebrated the V√•japeya (K√•t. XV, 1.2), while others held that it should be celebrated after V√°japoya (Asv. IX. 9. 19). In the Sat. Br. IX, 3, 4.8 it is said ‘by performing the Rajasaya one becomes a king ( rƒÅjan )

RƒÅjas≈´ya

1215

and by the V√°japoya an emperor ( samr√§t) and the position of the king is (obtained) first and thereafter of emperor.’ On the first day of the bright half of Phalgune the sacrificer under goes diksa for a soma sacrifice called Pavitra, which follows the procedure of Agnistoma (L√§t, IX. 1, 2, Asv. IX. 3. 2, K√§t. XV, 1. 6). There was difference of opinion as to the number of dik≈üƒÅ days (Lat. IX. 1. 8, Kat. XV. 1. 4). The Abbi≈üecaniya ceremony which is the principal among the rites of RƒÅja s≈´ya took place exactly a year after the Pavitra sacrifice was commenced (Lat. IX. 1. 4). At the end of the Abhi≈üecaniya the sacrificer did not actually enter into water for the final bath (avabhrtha ), but wearing shoes made of boar-skin be repaired from the sacrificial ground (devayajana ) to the water, put into the water black antelope horn or the foot portion of & black antelope skin and returned wearing shoes of black antelope skin (Lat. IX. 1. 23-24),

There are five offerings oommencing the next day after the Pavitra sacrifice, one each on one day. Then on the Full Moon of Ph√•lguna there is an i≈üti to Anumati (& purodass being offered ). Vide Kat. XV. 1.9 and ƒÄp. XVIII. 8. 10. There is an offering to Nir»öti prepared from the particles of grains that fall to the west of the samyƒÅ from the mill-stone when the grains for the purodaga to Anumati are being ground. The particles are taken in the sruya and a firebrand being lighted from the dak≈üi≈Üa fire, the offering is made to the south of the vihƒÅra on that fire-brand or on some baltish land. On the full moon day of PhƒÅlguna are begun the citurmƒÅsyas (1. e. first the Vai≈°vadeva, then after four months Varu≈ÜapraghƒÅsas and so on). This goes on for one year. Between the parvans of the c√¢turmƒÅsyas, the monthly full moon and new moon sacrifices are performed. The c√§turmƒÅsyas come to an end with the SunƒÅsiriya parva on the first of the bright half of Ph√§lguna. After that several rites follow such as the Pa√±osv√§tiya in five fires in the four directions and in the middle (Ap. XVIII. 9. 10-11, Kat. XV. 1. 20-21 ), the ApƒÅmƒÅrga-homa ( Ap. XVIII. 9. 15-20, K√§t. XV. 2. 1 ff.). Then there are twelve offerings called ‘ratnin√°m 2648 bavim≈üi’ performed on twelve days one

after another in the houses of the ratnas' (jewels ) viz. of the sacrificer himself, his queens and state functionaries (K√§t. XV. 8 and ƒÄp. XVIII. 10). The deity to whom an offering is made is appropriate to the person in whose house the offering is made and the offerings and fees algo differ. The twelve persons ( according to KƒÅt.) are the sacrificer, the commander of the army, the purohita, the crowned queen, the sata (minstrel ?), gr√•mani ( village headman), the k≈üatt; ( chamberlain), samgra hits ( treasurer or charioteer?), aksƒÅ vƒÅpa ( superintendent of gambling), govikarta (hunter?), d≈´ta or pƒÅlagala ( courier), pariv√Ωkti (the discarded queen) and the deities respectively are Indra, Agni Anikavat, Bphaspati, Aditi, Varuna, Maruts, Savits, Asvins, Rudra (for both aksƒÅvƒÅpa and govikarta ), Agni, Nirsti ( the offering in this case is a caru of black rice husked with the nails). The dak≈üi≈ÜƒÅs also vary ( vido ƒÄp. XVIII. 10. 15-30, K√§t. XV. 3. 16-34). Then follow several offeringe. Then comes the Abhi≈üecaniya rite which is the central ceremony in RƒÅjas√ºya and which lasts for five days ( one day dik≈üƒÅ, three days upasads and one suty√• day of some pressings). The dik≈üƒÅ of Abhi≈üecaniya (anointing rite ) is performed on the first of Caitra. It is performed on the southern part of the sacrificial ground while the Dasapeya is performed on the northern portion. In the Abhi≈üecaniya and Da≈õapeya the hots must be of the Burgugotra (Tandya Br. XVIII. 9. 2, K√§t. XV. 4.1, ≈ö√§n. XV.13.2). The Abbi≈üecanlya follows the procedure of the Ukthya. Soma is bought for both Abhi≈üecanlya and Dagapeya at the same time, but half of it (for Dasapoya) is deposited, after being carried in a cart, in the house of the brahmƒÅ priest. Then there are eight offerings of caru called Devas√º-havin≈üi viz. to Savitr, Agni G»ôhapati, Soma Vanaspati, Brhaspati, Indra, Rudra, Mitra, Varu≈Üa. According to Ap. XVIII. 12. 7-8 after these eight offer. ings the brahmƒÅ priest announces to the ‘ratnins’ that the sacrificer is their king and refers to the tribes or people occupying the country.2646 Vide K√§t. XV. 4. 15-17 also. At the end of idƒÅ in the case of these caru offerings the priest brings waters of seventeen kinds in seventeen vessels of udumbara wood, viz. of the Sarasvati river, flowing water of a river, water from ripples produced by the entrance of a man or animal, water

RƒÅjas≈´ya

1217

from a river drawn against the ourrent, water of the sea, of ocean waves, of whirl-pools, of deep steady reservoirs always exposed to the sun, rain water in sunshine before it falls on the ground, of a lake, of a well, of frost &o. (K√§t. XV. 4. 21-42, Ap. XVIII 13. 1-18). All the waters are poured into a vat of udumbara which is placed near the seat of Maitr√•varupa. After the Marutvatly& cup is offered in the Ukthya rite, he spreads to the east of the vessel of water a tiger skin on the western end of which lead is placed. Six homas called P√°rtha660 are offered (Ap. XVIII. 15. 8, Kat. XV. 5. 34 ) and then with a gold piece tied in two kusa blades the water in the big vessel is cleansed (that is utpavana is performed) and is distributed in four Vessels made of pala≈°a, udumbara, nyagrodha and asvattha. The sacrificer wears a silken garment ( tarpya, explained by KƒÅt. XV, 5.7-11 ), a white turban ( one end of which hangs from the shoulder ) and a mantle. The sacrificer recites the Avid formula 2651 (Ap. XVIII. 14. 10, Kat. XV. 5. 21, which refers to Vaj. S. X. 9). The adhvaryu gives a strung bow and three arrows to the sacrificer, who puts & copper piece in the mouth of a long haired man ( eunuch ) for averting evil (from spirits and snakes ? ); vide V√°j. S. X. 10. The sacrificer treads upon the piece of lead and brushes it away with his foot and stands on the tiger-skin with a gold piece under his foot and has a fillet of gold on his head. The sacrificer holds up his arms. He strides in the quarters. The sacrificer stands facing the east and the adhvaryu, standing in front of him, first sprinkles him with the holy water contained in the vessel of palasa, the other priests follow viz. the brahm√• sprinkles him from the right with water in udumbara vessel and so on. Besides, the king’s brother ( K√°t. XV. 5.30) or another ksatriya (Ap. XVIII. 16. 3) sprinkles him with water from the udumbara vessel, a friendly ksatriya from the third vessel and a vaibya from the fourth (Ap. XVIII. 16. 3-5 days a k≈üatriya sprinkles water from udumbara vessel, a vaisya sprinkles from behind the king with water from asvattha vessel and a friend from the common people sprinkles from the north side with water in the nyagrodha

(Ch. XXXIV

Vessel). These actions are probably symbolic of the consent of all people to the anointing. The sacrificer rubs with the antelope horn over the whole of his body the holy water sprinkled over him ( Kat. XV. 6.8). According to Kat. XV. 6. 1-2 at this stage or after the dice play ( to be described later) the hotr priest sitting on a cushion inlaid with gold reoites the story of Sunahgepa858 for the sacrificer’s benefit. Ap. XVIII. 19. 10 places this recital after the dice-play, A√∏v, IX. 3. 9 gays that the story of Sunahsepa is recited to the anointed king after the marutvatiya sastra in the Abhi≈üecaniya rito (and before the Ni≈ükevalya sastra ), the king being seated on a golden cushion and surrounded by his son and ministers. The adhvaryu also sits on a cushion inlaid with gold and utters the responses (pratigara) uttering ‘om (as the pratigara) at the end of each fk and’ tathƒÅ' at the end of eaob gƒÅtha. 2858 At the end of the recitation the sacrificer donates a hundred or a thousand cows to the hotr and to the adhvaryu and donates also their respective cushions. The king takes three strides called Vi≈ünukrama on the tiger-bide. All the remnants of the anointing waters are poured in the palƒÅsa vessel and are handed over by the anointed king to his son with the words ‘May my Bon continue this my work and this my prowess.’ Then two homas are offered (called n√°mavyati≈üa√±janiya ) in which at first the son is declared to be the father of his father and then secondly the relationship is rightly put.2856 Vide A.p. XVIII, 16. 14-15, K√§t. XV. 6.11. Then there is a symbolic maroh for the plunder of cows. As in Vajapeya & chariot is made ready, four horses are yoked to it, the sacrificer ascends it, takes the chariot in the midst of a group of hundred or more cows belonging to his kinsmen collected to the north of the Abavaniya,

Cb. XXXIV 1

RƒÅjas≈´ya

izig

touches one of them with the string of his bow and says ' I seize these.' Then he restores to the owner as many cows as are collected or more and returns to the sacrificial ground and makes four offerings called Rathavimocaniya. Vide Kat. XV. 6. 13-23. LƒÅ»õ. (IX. 1. 14-22) gives & more graphic acoount that at the time of giving gifts, the king’s kinsmen are collected with their wealth, arrows are discharged at them by the sacrifoer, they themselves bring back the arrows and deolare “O king, may you be victorious.' One-third of their wealth is distributed among the priests, one-third is given at the time of the Da≈°apeya to the worthy brahma≈Üas brought in that rite, one-third is returned to the kinsmen, villages are bestowed on them and they become r√§janyas ( king’s nobles) but not worthy of coronation. Before getting down from the chariot he puts on boar-skin shoes, bows to the earth with ‘O mother earth! do not injure me nor may I injure thee’ (Vaj. 8. X. 23, Tai. S. 1. 8. 15. 1). The king tben sits on a chair or throne made of khadira that is placed in front of the √§gnidhriya shed (Ap. XVIII. 18. 5-8, KƒÅt. XV. 7.1-4). The priests and the ‘ratnins’ take seats round him; the brahmƒÅ priest ( the purohits or adbvaryu according to KƒÅt. XV. 7. 11 ) hands over the sphys to the king, from whom it passes on to several persons viz. the king’s brother, s√§ta, sthapati, village headman, kingman ( ƒÄp. XVIII. 18. 14-16). According to Kat. ( XV. 7. 13 ) the kinsmen and the pratiprasth√§tr mark out a place for dice play with the sphya ( according to Ap. XVIII. 18. 16 the superintendent of gambling does so). On the ground so marked a quadrangular hut or shed is erected. Five dice are handed over to the king who is lightly struck by the priests with sticks of sacrificial trees. The king calls as umpires ( upadrastr) the samgrabits, the bhƒÅgadugba ( collector of taxes ) and the k≈üatt≈ô ( Ap. XVIII. 19. 6-8). The play is so arranged that the best throw ( of the dice) comes to the king and the worst to his kiasman.865‚Ç¨ It appears that the dice play required golden pieces also beyond a hundred or a thousand in number (Ap. XVIII. 19. 1). According to Kat. ( XV. 7. 25‚Äì26 ) the king actually undergoes the avabhitha bath, wbile Latyayana as stated above differs. After the offering of anubandhy: cow and the performance of the udavasƒÅniya i≈üti, a cake prepared from a mixture of rice

and barley and baked on twelve potsherds is offered to Indra and Vi≈ünu. For ten days after the Abbi≈üecanly& he offers successively on each day offerings called ‘sa·πÅsrpƒÅm havim≈üi’ respectively to Savitr, Sarasvati, Tva≈ütr, P≈´≈üan, Indra, B»ôhas pati, Varuna, Agni, Soma, Vi≈ü≈Üu ( KƒÅt, XV. 8. 1-4, Ap. XVIII. 20. 7 which says they are ten or seven and they begin with Agni; A≈üv. IX. 4. 6 speaks of only seven). Each of these is offered in fire set up in a devayajana to the east of the prece ding one and the last of the ten is offered in the shed prepared for the Da≈°apeya rito ( ƒÄp. XVIII. 20. 8-10, Kat. XV. 8, 2-3). On each of the ten (or seven) i≈ütis ( of samspƒÅƒ±n hav√≠m≈üi) he offers to the priests ordinary or golden lotus flowers and on the tenth day he wears & garland made of those flowers. That becomes his consecration (dik≈üa) for the next rite, viz. Da≈õapeye. Jaimini declares (in XI. 2,57-62) that though som& is purchas ed for both Abhi≈üecaniya and Dadapeya at the same time ( vide p. 1216 above), yet in the two ekƒÅhas the whole procedure of soma sacrifices is repeated. A different proposition is stated in K√§t. XV, 8, 10-13 (except as to dik≈üƒÅ and avabb·ªôtha which are repeated in both rites). On the tenth day after the Abhi≈üecanlya is finished the Da≈°apeya is performed (LƒÅ≈£. IX, 2.1, K√¢t. XV. 8. 14 says on the 7th day i. e. on 7th of the bright half of Caitra ). This rite is so called because in it each of the ten camasas ( cups ) of soma aro partaken of by ten brƒÅhma·πáas ( A≈°v. IX, 3. 18, Ap. XVIII. 21.3). The brƒÅhma·πáas are the ten ≈°tviks who ordinarily partake of the soma in camasas plus 90 more (called anuprasarpakas ) who poseels special qualifications, viz. whose ten ancestors on the father’s and mother’s sides were masters of Vedic lore, had rigorously performed their duties and were engaged in holy sotions and who had no sexual or marital alliances with non-br√§hma≈Üas2858 ( vide A≈õv. IX. 3. 19-21, S√§n.
